Dear Sir:

Referring to our letter 108/13 of December 1st last, to you, inclosing copy of letter and plan of suggested laundry sump at the Chibougamau School, received from the Mining District Chief Engineer, of the Dominion Water Power Branch & Reclamation Bureau, Winnipeg.

The sump is now blocked again, and continuous pumping has to be undertaken every day, to take the waste away. This is pumped into a trough and drained over on to the land, and the smell is most offensive and dangerous to health, as well as causing a lot of work to the School authorities, which should be unnecessary.

We shall be glad, therefore, if you will give instructions, you may think advisable, to the Dominion Water Power Branch & Reclamation Bureau, Winnipeg, to remedy this situation.

We would not recommend this expenditure, but it is absolutely necessary for the health of the children at the School, and unless something is done, the Department of Public Health is liable to make us close down the School.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Extract from Mr. E. W. Dyers' letter dated March 27th, 1931, to Mrs. McKerroll.

"I would like to state that owing to the very mild winter we have been able to pass the winter without much freezing, but still with a lot of discomfort in the Residence. The Department had an Inspector make a report on the system last fall, and the Inspector made the same recommendations as I had been stating for, namely a proper lining up on the return pipes and the installation of a pump for the return to the furnaces of the condensed steam. His tender for the complete job was somewhere around $650.00 and after the tender was received nothing further was done. Owing to the residence being situated so far from the furnaces we never get heat throughout there is a heavy head of steam which means a great deal of unnecessary firing, and adds greatly to the fuel bill. It is impossible to ever expect the furnaces to work properly with the pipes lined up as they are. Several places in the system the return water must run up hill in order to clear the pipes, and this water will not do without force behind it. I am of the opinion that something should be offered if a small heating unit were installed in the Residence and that part cut off from the main furnaces. A small oil burner would take care of this heating, and would secure a more uniform heating of the Residence, and would require less pressure on the main boilers. If at all possible something should be done before another winter sets in, because if we have to face a severe winter such as we usually have, I doubt if we could keep the system from freezing up. Last night was very cold and one of the classrooms was too cold for holding School."
Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Doctor Scott,-

I am sorry to have to write again about the furnaces at Kenora. When Miss Cameron was in town on her way home, she told me that the school in which she had been teaching in the Ojibwa Jeffrey school, had to be closed several days just before she left, because they could not get it warm enough to have the children sit in it. I wrote at once to Mr. Byers, asking for another report, as I had hoped things were now better. I am enclosing you a copy of his reply. That can be done to get this into better shape.

Thanking you for your consideration,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Secretary, Indian Department.
OTTAWA,
May 6, 1921.

Dear Mr. Gow,

You will remember our conversation with reference to the disposal field at the Emma B. C. School and also the laundry camp at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

I have today received a telegram from Captain Ricardo in which he states that the sewage disposal plant at the Emma B. C. School is not working properly and the sanitary Inspector is likely to close the Institute, and also that the sewage at the Cecilia Jeffrey School is not working properly and it is necessary for them to use a pump to empty and the discharge is allowed to run on the surface. From this information it would appear that things are rather serious at both the schools, and I would be glad to hear from you with your suggestions.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

R. GILBERT ORE,
Architect for the Department.

D. D. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a tender from Mr. D. G. Sinclair for the painting and papering in connection with the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The matter of painting was taken up with the Department last year, and I was given to understand that it would be done this year.

The walls have never been painted since the School was built, and owing to the fact that the walls are just putty-coat finished, we cannot wash the stains from the plaster for this reason. But after a coat of sizing and paint they can be washed, and we will be able to keep the walls clean.

This tender is very reasonable, and would be much higher if times were brighter. I hope the Department will see fit to authorize having this done right away, as the Residence walls have been badly stained ever since it was completed, and the school walls are badly stained also, and as I said before the plaster will not stand washing.

KENORA, ONT.—June 4th. 1931

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re Laundry Sump

In the absence of Captain Frank Edwards, who is away on Treaty, I am taking the liberty of writing direct. I wish to state that for almost a year I have found it necessary to have the boys pumping from the above Sump almost every day. This was necessary through the Winter weather and on rainy days, and the boys are very much disgusted with the job. Furthermore all this water pumped runs over the surface of the ground close to the School building, and creates a very offensive smell, and is very unsanitary.

I have made several requests through the Indian Agent to have something done to remedy this, but nothing of a permanent nature has been done. I feel satisfied that it would not be a very expensive job if a competent man were given the work. It is an Engineer's job, and one who is experienced in such work. The ordinary Contractor is not qualified to properly handle this situation.

I scarcely know what to recommend, but am sure of this part, that the bottom of the present sump consists of sand of too fine a texture, and I know there is a vein of gravel underlying this strata of fine sand. It appears that if this were lowered to this coarse gravel, that the water would seep away.

In order to do this work I believe the cover will have to be removed, as men refuse to work in the sump as it is at present, owing to the heat and the foul gases. I sincerely hope that the Department will take immediate steps to have this very unsatisfactory condition remedied.

June 25th, 1931.

Jant. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We have from time to time been called upon to pump out existing cisterns at the Jessie Jeffrey school, the trouble with which seems to be that wooden walls are coated with soot and creosote from the laundry and only possible seepage is from bottom which appears to be coated in a similar manner. Last winter we bored with root auger to a gravel strata about four feet, which seemed to draw off liquids until it also choked up.

The trouble we think, is as follows:

1. Present tank too small.
2. No seepage field.
3. Walls should be porous.

To rectify this trouble we recommend the following:

1st. Construct a concrete tank 12'-0 X 12'-0 by 6'-0 foot in height with porous tile pipe in layers spaced one foot apart on horizontal and two feet on perpendicular. The cistern to be constructed about forty feet farther east of building.

2nd. An open joint outlet pipe of six inch glazed tile with Y branches every four feet on to which are connected about four feet of wearing tile. Then these are set a strip of light weight roofing is laid over joints and coarse clean gravel placed over same about one foot deep.
We do not think that anything really satisfactory can be done for less than the amount estimated.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Kenora, Ontario.
June 27th, 1931.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your telegram of 26th inst., re Sump at the Cecil Jeffrey Residential School, we wired you today that Mr. Lyons, the Engineer of the Northern Development Branch, Ontario Government kindly visited the School, and we interviewed the Principal today.

Mr. Lyons's suggestions are, that the old Sump be discarded, and that the present pipe line be carried out about 250 feet towards the Lake, and a small permanent manhole of Concrete be constructed there and disposed of by means of a Lake with a length of 50 feet and leaving an opening for an extra one, should it be required later. The ground to take care of the seepage, and if this is done Mr. Lyons does not consider there would be any further trouble, but if there should be, it could be easily remedied at practically no cost.

Messrs. Kelly & Kimberley estimate the cost of this work at roughly $995.00.

We inclose their letter and suggestions made before Mr. Lyons visited the School, but they now agree that Mr. Lyons's suggestions are the best.

The School holidays commence on July 15th, and we would suggest the work be carried out while most of the Pupils will be away.
July 4, 1931.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 27th instant, with further reference to the map of the Cecilia Jeffery School, the Department approves of the recommendation of Mr. Lyons, and you may arrange with Sally and Kimberley to have a new map constructed in accordance with Mr. Lyons' suggestions. It is noted that the cost will be approximately $75.00. This amount must not be exceeded and if possible the cost should be kept lower.

When the work is completed vouchers should be forwarded to the Department in the regular way. These vouchers should show in detail all material and labour used on the work.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

A. P. MacKenzie,
Superintendent.

Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

We have always experienced considerable difficulty with our furnaces and the suggestion was made that we cut off our hot-water tank but we could not do this as we required so much hot water for the school.

I tried to have the tank heated by electricity but the town refused to allow the use of the extra current. Just recently I interviewed the council and succeeded in obtaining permission to heat the tank if we wished to do so.

I enclose herewith a tender from Mr. Cheyne for the complete installation of this heater. The amount is not large and I hope you can secure the necessary authority to have the heater installed.

Thanking you for your attention to the above,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Russell Ferries

Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

Re the furnaces in our school.

Is it possible, Mr. Ferries, to have something done to better the operation of our furnaces.

There is seldom heat in the Residence. It is always cold and damp and Mrs. Byers and myself are contracting colds throughout the Winter season. The sewing-room is always cold and also one of the class-rooms.

The furnaces cannot heat the building with the present piping of the hot water pipes. There are water-pockets in several places and the steam will not go beyond these.

I have had the advice of several steam engineers and they are all agreed that we cannot heat the building as it is installed at present.

Mr. Brown of Kenora recommended raising the returns and installing a pump. Mr. Campbell recommends raising the returns and installing a pump. Mr. Wood of Winnipeg recommends raising the returns and installing a pump.

In the school I had in Brandon there was continuous trouble in getting any heat. They changed the piping and the mains but without results and finally they installed a pump and the trouble was over.

I just dread the cold weather coming on. All we can use the fireplaces for sleeping. We cannot go in there in the evening and enjoy a moment's rest and chance. If you were in the residence one day you would realize what it is like. The sewing-room is so cold we are obliged to keep an electric heater going all the time. Frequently we have to close one of our classrooms. Other parts of the building are not heated.

I believe a pump is the only solution and I shall greatly appreciate your immediate attention to this matter.

Thanking you for your consideration of the matter.

I remain,
Your obedient servant,

Memorandum: Mr. Williams,

With reference to the attached letter from Mr. W.K. Beatrice, Plumbing and Heating Contractor at Winnipeg, regarding the heating system at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I beg to say that the specifications for this building, which was erected in 1929, provide for the standard type firebox boiler. At the request of the Minister at that time the contractor was authorized to install two Spencer boilers. Such boilers are not of the same type or construction as the one specified, but I understand that they have given good satisfaction in other buildings. The trouble experienced with the heating system at the Cecilia Jeffrey School was due, I think, to improper management on the part of the staff, also on account of the heavy bush to the rear of the building. An improvement was made by raising the chimney 10 feet. I understand that the heating system has worked satisfactorily during the last winter and I do not think it necessary to change the boilers.

Dear Sir:

Re Heating System at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Referring to the Engineer's inspection of the Heating System of the above job, I wish to advise that the Radiators and Steam and Return Mains have been carefully checked, and the following changes would be necessary in order to put the system in shape, so that it would satisfactorily heat the entire building and residence to a temperature of 70 degrees, even an outside temperature of 30 or 40 below zero. All the return mains in the Basement should be raised to provide free drainage of condensation. Steam Mains in Basement should be dripped at various points to drain condensation from the mains, providing dry steam for radiators. All Steam Risers running from Basement mains to 1st. and 2nd. floors should be dripped more frequently, traps being installed any possibility of these risers being choked with condensation. All basement radiators should be provided with thermostatic radiation traps on return ends connected with return mains. All the branches from steam mains in basement connecting these mains to the basement radiators, should be altered as shown on details, eliminating possibility of water collecting in radiators. An automatic vacuum and backwater防止器 should be installed in boiler room which should be capable of removing all condensation and air in the heating system and return condensation automatically to the boiler.

Regarding the residences it would be necessary to install two small radiators in the basement space, and add radiator in the vestibule on the ground floor. The radiator in the dining room, living room and kitchen should also be slightly increased in size, by addition of extra sections.

Details of necessary changes of piping and connections will be clearly shown on drawing which we will provide
When the above alterations are completed, we will guarantee that the building will be satisfactorily heated under the temperature conditions previously stated. We would like to point out, however, that in the cold winter weather it will be necessary that all windows in the building be kept closed, as far as possible. You will understand that it is not possible to satisfactorily heat the building, if windows are left open for any length of time and the building becomes chilled.

We would also like to point out that the above alterations will not produce an even temperature throughout the entire building, as there will be a natural tendency to overheat certain sections. This overheating would have to be overcome by the proper adjustment by hand of the various valves placed throughout the system, and we believe that this failure can be easily overcome by slight experience in operation when the changes are made.

I estimate that the above work would cost $2000.

Dear Captain:

There are several items of vital importance that I discovered while on an inspection tour during Fire Prevention Week in the two residential schools for Indian children that I wish you would bring to the attention of the proper authorities because if anything occurs it may reflect on some of these features that should have been attended to. There were several fireplaces in the Cecilia Jeffery School which are landing places for fire escape doors that are not properly installed and would interfere with the proper escape of children if an emergency occurred at the foot of the stairs and March wide which is the inside side of the bottom of the escape ladder right up against the chapel wall and at the North end of the landing which is the boys' landing there is no landing the boys end up on the furnaces or boiler room roof which is certainly a very dangerous place to have to pass over in case they would be needed all if that happened to happen when the escape doors were closed they should be able to run straight down off the landing and not have to climb the rear wall right off that those defects are not only against the rules of fire escape but they are against the principles of safety which is what the escape was put up for in the first place. Having had several experiences of handling patients from the hospital wards of that school we found that it is impossible to take a person out of the wards in a stretcher to be taken in our ambulance and had trouble to make even a small child in that situation in the hall, there should be doors direct out of the wards instead of the present ones, more harm can be done than is necessary in serious cases and so the Officer in charge of the Municipal Ambulance I wish to state that it is dangerous business to move patients out of those wards as they are today and I certainly do not wish to be the one responsible for any further injuries that might occur. To offset these doors should be strengthened quickly as possible, there should also be a fire hydrant on the house reel and this house reel should be in proper order and the water hydrant should be put in proper shape where it would be ready for instant use, if it had not been for this house at the last fire at the school there would have been a great deal more damage caused, therefore I strongly recommend that this house reel and hydrant be given immediate attention, the fire drills are excellent and the fire protection equipment is in good condition but I would recommend that proper action be taken in the above mentioned items because you never can tell when a serious mishap may occur.

Yours truly,

Chief Fire Dept.
Dear Sir,

The Grand Jury in their report to the Judge at the last session of the Court at Kenora made the following remarks regarding the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School:

"We would respectfully recommend that the Fire Escape System in this School be thoroughly examined by a Government Official, as we consider the present Fire Escape system inadequate. Cupboards and Clothes Closets are an absolute necessity for the comfort of the students in this building. The Plastering requires to be attended to, and if brought to the attention of the proper authority, will undoubtedly be taken care of."

We include a letter received from the Fire Chief, which we asked him to write us after our inspection of the school.

The School is of the standard plan as used by the Department, but the Fire Chief claims that doors should be made for the children to escape to the fire escape instead of the main windows. The stairways on the girls' side should run out from the building instead of along the side of the wall. Short iron ladders should be put up on the boy's side, from the ground to the top of the boiler room so that they would not have to travel along the boiler house roof to get down. A sliding door should be made between the Hospital and the passage, as it is difficult to get beds or stretchers out of the wards, into the main building. A new fire hose should be purchased for use from the main building to the outbuildings, as the present hose has perished through exposure, and a small house should be built, which can be heated, to house this hose reel, and the water hydrant should also be placed in this house."

In going over the Fire Chief's recommendation with the Principal, we are of the opinion, that the expenditure would be in the neighbourhood of $300.00 for this work, with the exception of the hose, which would cost $225.00.

We shall be glad to receive your instructions, but will refer you to your letter 129-3-5 of 2nd inst., in which you inform us that there are no further funds for expenditures at this school this year.

Dear Sir,

We have had some more trouble at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

One of the water pumps at the pump house at the Lake has broken (the block, piston, and piston rods are broken). The Principal went to the Campbell Heating Company and Mr. Campbell has been in to see me and informs me the cost of repairing the pump would be in the neighbourhood of $460.00. (Parts $275.00 labour $185.00) A new pump, less the cost of new parts which is not required would be $320.00 and cost of labour installing.

Mr. Cheyne, Electrician, informed me he had been to the school and requested the Principal, and found all the fittings in the pump house in a terrible state. He claims the following repairs and replacements are required: The main switchboard to be scrapped and replaced with a new one or larger, new switch for #2 pump, switch for #1 pump, screws and cables, new hand control switch, all electrical wiring renewed, new automatic starter. The cost of the above would be in the neighbourhood of $100.00 not counting the cost of the automatic starter ($25.00) and he does not a price, but estimates the cost of all the electrical repairs would be in the neighbourhood of $200.00.

On making enquiries as to the cause of these troubles, it appeared that the two motors were not used by the action of the storm from the generator mixer, one of the containers had a leak and was empty and the blame was placed on Messrs. Wallace and Tiernan who supplied it, for the past correspondence and vouchers for repairs. The Principal informs me Wallace and Tiernan Inspector occasionally inspects the machines and has not informed him there was anything wrong, but it seems to me that this should have been noticed before and amounts put in the estimates to take care of any trouble that might be expected to arise.

I am also informed the motors for the pumps are getting affected and should be looked into and relubricated to prevent further trouble.

These matters are all most imperative, as the water supply for the school will be stopped if anything goes wrong with the one pump that is operating, and the consequent danger should a fire occur with inadequate water supply.

Mr. Byers also requests that a check valve be placed in the water pipe at the school to prevent water returning down the pipe to the lake when the pump is not working.

I would refer you to my letter of the 16th instant re expenditure incurred as recommended by the Grand Jury and Fire Chief, and to your letter 129-3-5 of 2nd instant calling my attention to the fact that no further funds are available for this school.

There is no question there is more money spent at this
school, than at any other of the four in my agency; I hesitate to lay the blame on the Principal, but it appears that he should be at least able to prepare for the expenditure by putting an amount in his estimates to take care of this instead of having things until they go wrong; and then informing us that the expenditure must be made, when no provision has been made.

Wallace and Tiermans man should be instructed to visit the school, and report on the damage done and to give advice so that more damage will not be done by the action of the chlorine.

I shall be glad to receive instructions as soon as possible, as you can understand the urgency.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the condition of the pumps in connection with the water system at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. It is noted that one of the pumps has completely broken down and that the cost of repairing same would be excessive, in comparison with the supplying of a new one. It is noted, further, that it would be necessary, also, to have all fittings in the pumphouse repaired and the electrical wiring renewed. You were authorized, by telegram of the 26th instant, as follows:

"Reference letter nineteenth, re Cecilia Jeffrey School, may arrange to have new pump installed, also repairs to electric wiring. In performance of work, be guided by lists of firms already supplied you."

It is noted that the cost of a new pump, less a new pulley, which is not required, would be $520, which includes the cost of the labour in installing same. It is noted, further, that the cost of all the electrical repairs, new equipment in the pumphouse and the supplying of a new main switch board, of the larger type, would be $575. As stated in the telegram, you should take immediate steps to have the new pump supplied, installed and the repairs made to the electric wiring, etc. The Department notes that the electrician who examined the fittings in the pumphouse found them in a "terrible state", and it would appear that there has been a certain amount of carelessness in the operation of this pump. Has the school a competent man in charge, who is able to operate the pumping equipment?

The Department has no funds provided for the above equipment and repairs, and it was necessary to obtain same by diverting needed expenditure at other schools. Should occasion arise for other expenses at this school during the present fiscal year, it will be necessary for the school authorities to provide the cost of same from per capita allowance or other receipts.

After the new pump has been installed and the electrical equipment repaired, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Dear Sir:-

In connection with our inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school I wish to present you with the following report as requested by you.

The conditions in the school could be improved upon as regards to cleanliness and order especially in the hallways; too much material is allowed to be left piled in there hallways and obstructions are being left on the fire escapes; these appliances should be kept absolutely free from obstacles. The hand extinguishers should be charged every year and none intended for fire purposes should not be used for any other purpose except for occasional practices; some of this hose was found lying outside and is generally subject to damage from the weather. I would suggest that the Principal appoint one of the staff an special caretaker of all fire protection appliances whose duties could be to see that all the hand extinguishers are recharged properly at least once a year and that the fire hose on the reels be not interfered with and the hose on the hose reel intended for the outside sections be kept on the reel always ready for use and hose to be tested and properly dried out at least twice a year.

The fire drills held by the pupils showed that they keep themselves very efficiently trained in this respect and the fire alarms are always in good order but they should be tested frequently.

The firehose for outside fire protection should be long enough to reach any of the outside premises; this item should be checked up and if found unsatisfactory should be remedied at once.

Yours truly,

F. Dubois.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing the report of the Kenora Fire Chief on his inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Please advise the Principal that he is to keep the corridors in a cleanly condition and that no material is to be left piled in them. Further, it is absolutely necessary that no obstruction be left on the fire escape. You should inform the Principal that it is expected he will comply with the Department's requirements, as mentioned above. He should also take proper care of the fire hose. It is noted the Fire Chief found some of the hose lying outside, exposed to the weather. The fire hose should not be interfered with, and whether intended for inside use or for the outside sections, it should be kept on the reels, always ready for use. It should be tested and dried out at least twice a year. The suggestion of the Fire Chief, that the Principal appoint a member of the staff as special caretaker of all fire protection appliances, should be carried out.

You may arrange for the purchase of the chemicals required to refill the fire extinguishers; and, when these are delivered at the school, the Principal should see that the refills are installed, that the extinguishers are overhauled and placed in good condition, ready for immediate use. After the refills have been purchased, please obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, covering the cost.

These extinguishers should be thoroughly overhauled once each year; and, if refills are required, application should be made for the necessary authority to purchase same.

You should impress upon the Principal the necessity for having all fire equipment at his school in good condition, ready for use in case of fire.

Your obedient servant,

At the present time, this boat is in need of extensive repairs. A new engine was installed by the school authorities last summer.

Besides, a certain revenue could be obtained by the rental of the boat for excursion purposes and for handling freight. The boat would also be used for all school purposes - trekking, recruiting and for transporting the children to and from their homes. One of the main reasons for requesting the transfer is that, if the boat was owned by the church authorities, there would be no criticism of its use for commercial purposes.

have no funds to repair and overhaul the boat or to pay for the engine. Personally, I can see no objection to the transfer of the title on this boat to the Presbyterian Church authorities, on condition that it be available at all times for school purposes.

Dear Sir:

I have examined all windows and doors on Cecilia Jeffrey School, with a view of giving an estimate on installing "Peace Metal Weatherstrip" wherever required.

I find windows loose and rattling when wind blows, which is bound to make building difficult to heat. This building, you know, is situated so that it has no protection on south and east sides at all, and the fact that school buildings have large window areas, the consequent draft through windows and doors cause the fuel cost per annum on this building to be much higher than it should be.

I feel confident that at least 10% could be saved in fuel each year, which would soon pay for job and add to comfort of both teachers and pupils.

Peace Metal Weatherstrip, is manufactured in Winnipeg and manufacture and installation runs around $6.

Weatherstripping is a recognized part of all public buildings of recent construction. Dear Sir,

Quite a long time ago I received a communication from your Dept. re the advisability of employing a night watchman. My reply to you was that I was of the opinion that with the arrangements I had in the school that I could manage without one.

We have a very different situation now because of a number of things which have transpired during the past few months. I am fully convinced now that a night watchman is very necessary.

For one thing there is considerable unrest and agitation amongst the local unemployed and many of these are demanding food and lodging and will take shelter wherever they find a warm building.

Then there has been a lot of thieving of poultry, feed and tools. On one occasion some one entered our hen-house and thinking he was turning on the electric light, turned the switch for the heater and this was left on all night and almost caused a fire. We have disconnected this switch entirely.

Now we have a man in our employ who has been with us each summer during the busy work and he has proven to be very reliable and I would like to engage him for the Winter season as night watchman. Our school funds are not sufficient to provide for this and I shall very much appreciate it if the Department will allow me a grant of $100 towards the paying of a night watchman.

I shall appreciate an early reply as I am allowing him to leave unless arrangements are made for further engagement.

Thanking you for your attention to the above,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, November 25th, 1934.

Sir,

I enclose, for your information, a copy of a letter, dated the 25th instant, from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

The Department considers that, as the Cecilia Jeffrey School is a comparatively new building, there is no great necessity for the employment of a night watchman in order to guard against fire hazard. Reasonable care and supervision on the part of all members of the staff should be sufficient.

However, the Principal's letter suggests a situation that might cause considerable damage and the Department is inclined to allow him $50 a month for the period December 1st, 1934, to March 31st, 1935, in order to enable him to engage a night watchman. Please let me know, at once, if you consider this expenditure necessary.

MAY IT PLEASE YOUR HONOUR,-

We, the members of the Grand Jury summoned at the
sittings of the General Sessions of the Peace and District Court
at the Court House in the Town of Kenora, November 13th, 1934, beg
to present the following report,-

We considered the indictment brought before us and after
its consideration, and according to your instructions we visited
the Public Institutions of the Community.

The Court House.- We found the Court House in excellent condition
and the installations of the new boilers a vast improvement on the
old heating system.

The District Jail.- We found the premises in an excellent condition
and the inmates were all satisfied with their treatment and general
comforts. We find that there is no accommodation or kitchen utensils
and dishes in the Kitchen and would strongly recommend a cupboard or a
kitchen cabinet be installed. We would also recommend that the windows
of the Jail be caulked and weather stripped, there being no steam
windows this would be a great saving in the fuel problem.

The Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School.- We found the School to be well
managed but the fire hose in bad condition and suggest that they
be inspected by an expert. The boilers we maintain are obsolete
and the furnace room exceedingly hot owing to the fact the boilers
were not properly insulated and would suggest the windows of this
building be also caulked.

Kenora General and St. Joseph's Hospitals.- We inspected both
of these buildings and found them to be in perfect condition in
every respect. We took up the matter of changing the date of the
General Sessions and the majority of the jurors were of the opinion
it should not be changed.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

W.A. Whittle,
Chairman of the Jury.

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

After our recent inspection of the Cecilia Jeffery Indian residential School I wish to present to you my report on the conditions found as follows:

Several Thermex hand extinguishers used sometime ago on a bush fire require recharging; none of these machines is not fit for further use and should be replaced, besides recharging these machines there should be at least two spare ready charged at hand.

The fire hose on hose reels in the building are all in good order except two, one of these hose sections is full of holes and is therefore unfit for use, another one that showed signs of wear was taken to our firehall and put through a test, it had several holes in it and leaked so badly that it also is not fit for use, therefore two new sections of linen hose should be procured to replace the two found in the above mentioned condition. I might also state that one of these hose sections appeared to have three or four joints and when it is laid on the ground it seems that all these hose be rolled up instead of laid in layers the same reels can be still used and this will allow less bends and kinks and also much quicker obtained when needed for use. I would recommend that this hose be not used except for fire purposes.

The hose on the reel in the reel shed appears to be in good order but it should be long enough to be able to reach the furthest buildings, i.e., from the hydrant at least two more sections are required to make it long enough to reach these buildings and this hose should be tested and dried out properly at least twice a year, this could be done in connection with practices by the employees.

The main valve that controls the water for the fire hose standards of hose reels should be kept always free from obstructions as it may be hard to be handled very quickly sometimes just at the present a few objects are in the way and they should be removed.

The fire escapes all appear to be in proper order I would suggest that they be kept free from snow or ice in the Winter time.

Respectfully submitted by

F. Dubois.
Chief Fire Dept.

Dear Sir:

Re Operation of Pumps.

I wish to inform you that something is wrong with the valve or pipes out in the lake.

The pumps are loosing their priming and will not start pumping without allowing some water to return through the main valve. This loss of priming is caused by either the foot-valve not closing properly or a leak somewhere in the pipe-line.

Sir:

The Department has received, through the office of His Honour Judge Dowler, Judge of the District of Kenora, the report of the Grand Jury on their inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. They report as follows:

"We find this building to be well managed and attendance above the average. The building itself, however, is badly in need of painting, both inside and out, and is deteriorating on this account. The doors are shrunken and windows need weather-stripping and caulking. If this were done a huge saving could be effected in fuel. We also note that sewage from seepage field is rising to surface and seeping into lake, endangering the purity of the water supply. If this condition is not remedied an epidemic might result. We would, therefore, recommend that additional tile piping be added to existing distribution field to obviate this nuisance by increasing the area of seepage field."

There is an amount of $300 in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for the carrying out of general repairs to this school. I would request, therefore, that you take up the matter with the Principal and inform the Department definitely as to the amount of repairs, etc., that are urgently required; at a cost not exceeding the above mentioned amount.

There will be no funds for the exterior painting of the building. However, the Principal and yourself should decide what work is recommended to be carried out in the way of general repairs, including the cost of material and any outside labour that may be required.

Dear Sir,

Sometime ago a representative from this Department investigated the method used for the disposal of sewage at the Protestant Indian School at Kenora. I believe that you are in charge of this matter, and consequently I should like to draw to your attention the findings of our engineer.

It would appear from the information obtained at the time of the inspection, that the septic tank is badly in need of some supervision. The liquid is not filtering through the soil and tiles as one would expect, but is reaching the surface and is flowing down a surface ditch leading to the lake. This causes objectionable odours and also tends to pollute the water.

We are very much concerned with the pollution of the water and would ask that you look into the question of either cleaning out or enlarging this installation. It would appear to be necessary to dig up some of the tiles to see whether they are choked or whether the bed had an insufficient number of these for satisfactory disposal of the liquid. Our representative points out that the plant is built so close to the lake that the ground waters over the distribution bed, is somewhat high. He believes that by underdraining the area it might be possible of more effective functioning of the system.

We shall appreciate a reply from you with reference to this matter.

Sir:

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School:

In accordance with the instructions contained in your letter of September 26th, the writer visited Kenora on October 22nd and 23rd in connection with the above mentioned investigation. The sanitary conditions at this school were discussed with Dr. Ferguson, Medical Health Officer for the Town of Kenora, with Captain Edwards, Indian Agent, and also with Mr. Byers, Principal of the School.

I was informed by Dr. Ferguson, Medical Health Officer of the Town of Kenora, that the Town of Kenora had made no complaints whatsoever to the Director of the Division of Sanitary Engineering of the Department of Health at Toronto concerning the conditions at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School or as to the pollution of Round Lake. Accordingly, any criticism of conditions at the school as regards the pollution of Round Lake does not come from the local authorities but comes as a result of an inspection made by an official of the Department of Health from Toronto.

As a result of the examination made of conditions at the school, the writer wishes to report that the water from the disposal bed comes to the surface at two or three places throughout the disposal bed and trickles over to a small depression near by and seeps into the sand. Also there is a discharge from the laundry drain in the vicinity of the disposal bed - this being due to the fact that the laundry drain was extended to this vicinity some two or three years ago. There was a slight odor from the discharge through the disposal bed but it was not particularly offensive. The writer is of the opinion that at no time has any leakage from the disposal bed reached the waters of Round Lake, although it is possible that upon one occasion some discharge from the laundry drain might have reached the lake. This discharge would not cause pollution. The fact that the Medical Health Officer of the Town of Kenora takes samples of the water from Round Lake and has made no complaint as to pollution, is very good evidence that no pollution of the waters has taken place as a result of the installation at this Indian School.

I would draw to your attention the fact that this disposal bed was constructed in 1929 at a total cost of $864.17, to which of course must be added the Contractor's profit. At that time the water supply and sewage disposal systems were designed for a total population at the school

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.
of One Hundred. Today I am informed by the Principal of the School that the population of the school is 170. It will thus be seen that both the septic tank and the sewage disposal bed are greatly overloaded and it is only to be expected that leakage from the disposal bed will come to the surface in order to find an outlet from the overcrowded conditions. It is probable that some displacement has now taken place in the distributor line or the disposal bed and that some of the tile is out of alignment and possibly blocked, inasmuch as a disposal bed after six or eight years will always require attention, unless particular pains are taken at the time of construction to prevent settlement.

I would also point out that no maintenance work has been done upon the disposal bed at this school and in fact the site has been allowed to deteriorate and to become very uneven.

The writer is of the opinion that no possible contamination of Round Lake can possibly take place as a result of the condition of the septic tank and disposal bed and the writer is also of the opinion that the conditions at the disposal bed are not such as to be even slightly offensive to the operators of the school. Nevertheless, it is a fact that the population of the school is now such that overloading of the disposal bed has taken place and it is not operating efficiently. I would, therefore, recommend that examination of the distributor line and some of the feeder lines take place in order to determine whether or not any blockage of the system has occurred and furthermore that the disposal bed be enlarged from its present capacity. At present there are approximately 1600 linear feet of tile in place and this should be increased to approximately 2400 linear feet. This work cannot be carried out after July 15th next - at which time the school closes for a six-weeks period, insofar as the children are concerned. It is recommended, however, that this work be carried out immediately following July 15th next and that provision be made in the Estimates for the

The writer need not point out that the condition existing is not due to any faulty design upon the part of this office but is due entirely to greatly increased numbers of inmates in the Institution and also due to the lapse of six or seven years since the disposal bed was installed. At the time of installation the disposal bed was put in very cheaply and it was to be anticipated that maintenance work would be entailed after a period of five or more years.

The Principal of the School complained to the writer about the offensive odors in the Boys' playroom and washroom in the basement and intimated that this was caused by the condition of the disposal bed. However, the condition complained of within the school has no relation whatsoever to the condition of the disposal bed.

At a later date this office will draw up plans providing for the extension of the existing disposal bed and will also furnish estimates of the anticipated cost. These will be forwarded when prepared and in ample time to be included in the Estimates of the Department of Indian Affairs for next year.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 8, 1926.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who recently visited the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, has drawn attention to the condition of the bake oven. He states as follows:

"When the bread is baking a gas is given off, which makes it impossible to stay in the room. This gas strikes one when 20 ft. from the door and before entering the room one is blinded by tears. It also affects the throat, making it almost impossible to speak. The children are unable to do any of this work and Miss Reichart is practically overcome at the close of each baking day. The oven is an electric one but most unsuitable."

The Department is surprised to learn that there is an escape of gas from this oven and would like to be informed as to what occasions this condition. The oven supplied in September, 1925, was a Model "C" Economy Electric Bake Oven and was obtained from A. T. Fife & Company, Kenora. As far as we are aware, there is no gas used in the operation of the oven. A full report is requested regarding the condition of this oven. You should state if it would not be possible, by making some alterations, to overcome the present difficulty. An oven of the type installed should give service for a considerably more lengthy period than the one now in use at your school. Any suggestions or recommendations you care to make, regarding the oven, will be appreciated.

The Inspector states, further that, while the dormitories are all well aired and tidy, there is a shortage of beds and that three pupils were sleeping on the floor and one on a broken bed. He states that 4 to 6 beds should be supplied. There may be funds available at the beginning of the new fiscal year for the purchase of beds, and I shall be pleased if you will state the size - length and breadth - and the type of new beds required. They should be similar in type to those at present in the dormitories.

The Inspector reports, also, that the shower baths are not used. These rooms are located, one next to the children's dining room and one next to the staff dining room. The shower floors are not properly laid and water seeps through into the two dining rooms. You might report regarding the floors, stating what you would recommend be done to improve conditions. If possible, please give an estimate of the cost.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. H. Hyers, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.
EX'D.

Ottawa, March 3, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, reporting on your recent inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

The Department is pleased to note that satisfactory work is being performed in the classrooms and that the children are making fair progress. It is noted, also, that the interior of the school is kept in a satisfactory, cleanly condition.

Regarding the condition of the bake oven, need of more beds and the condition of the cement floor of the shower baths, I have to say that the Principal is being written and requested to furnish a report. The was supplied in September, 1929, and, as far as we are aware, there is no gas used for its operation. We are therefore unable to ascertain the source of the gas which you report as escaping from this oven. Consideration will be given to authorizing the supplying of a few extra beds and also repairing the cement floor.

It is noted that you will endeavour, in the future, to visit this school twice each year. It is considered that this would be advantageous to both the school and the Department.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I have for attention your letter of August 19th with enclosed letter from the Department of Indian Affairs stating that funds to the amount of approximately $1400.00 are now available for the enlargement of the disposal bed at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora. It is noted, however, that before this work is authorized it is desired that a check up be made on the water supply system for that Institution to make reasonably sure that the supply is safe for the school's purposes.

We have had no adverse reports with respect to the water supply at this school for some years past. It is possible that the reference in the letter of the Department of Indian Affairs relates to possible contamination of the source of the water supply from the sewage disposal and laundry disposal systems at the school. However, we reported on this matter under date of October 25, 1935, at that time we pointed out that the Ontario Medical Health Officer of the Town of Kenora had no complaint to make regarding the possible contamination of the water supply for this school. However, should there be any possible contamination from the Institution itself, this contamination is insignificant as compared with contamination from the surrounding area. To overcome this contamination a chlorinator was installed at the school and I understand that periodic inspections are made by the Medical Health Officer at Kenora to see that the chlorinator is kept in efficient operation.

As regards the water supply installation itself, I believe it is operating efficiently and has done so since the time the trouble in connection with intake was eliminated.

CHLORINATION OF SMALL WATER SUPPLIES
Type MSP and MSPM Chlorinator

Liquid Chlorine is the cheapest and most efficient agent for the sterilization of drinking water, and for the disinfection of sewage and the sanitation of swimming pools. Applied in minute amounts, it will absolutely destroy any disease germs that may be in a water supply. Its use will completely eliminate drinking water as an agent in the transmission of typhoid fever, dysentery or similar diseases.

Every water supply should be sterilized. A supply continuously subject to pollution is often less dangerous than one subject to only occasional pollution, because with the first the city or provincial health authorities insist on proper purification. Many of the most severe typhoid fever epidemics of the present day are the result of the chance pollution of water supplies ordinarily considered excellent. The effluent of filter plants should be sterilized as an additional safeguard.

Chlorination sterilizes 100,000 gallons of water for three cents or less. Liquid chlorine is safeguarding the supplies of over 8,500 municipalities aggregating six billion gallons of water a day. It furnishes the cheapest health insurance in the world. The only safe water is a sterilized water.
W & T Apparatus for Small Communities

The majority of water supplies are those of less than one million gallons per day, and therefore can usually be sterilized with less than five pounds of liquid chlorine. To efficiently apply chlorine in such small amounts, a specially designed Chlorinator Type MSP or MSPM chlorinator has been developed.

Where water pressure is available for operation, automatic control is possible by far superior methods than direct application of chlorine gas. It gives better diffusion of the sterilizing solution in the water being treated. It results in greater efficiency, substantial saving in chlorine costs, and better conditions of water in winter months. The primary aim has been to produce a machine which will not only accurately control the very minute amounts of chlorine needed but will also be of such simple construction as to be readily understood by the practical water works man. The operation of this equipment is explained by the drawing.

The capacity of Type MSP or MSPM apparatus varies from a minimum of six lbs. per 24 hours (comprising the first second) up to maximum of 15 lbs. of chlorine per 24 hours. The amount of chlorine required to sterilize water depends on the bacterial, physical and chemical condition of the water to be treated. This apparatus is applicable to water supplies as small as ten thousand gallons per twenty-four hours and up to one million gallons per twenty-four hours and may be used on supplies as large as one million gallons if the chlorine requirements of the water supply total less than ten pounds in twenty-four hours.

Over 16,000 installations of "W&T" chlorination controlled equipment have been made throughout the world. Approximately 8,000 Canadian and American municipalities chlorinate their drinking water supplies with our equipment. Over 75% of the population of North America drink chlorinated water. It is estimated that this is equivalent to over 6,000,000 gallons of water per 24 hours or the flow would be equivalent to 300,000 gallons a half hour.

Over half of these installations are water supplies of cities of less than 10,000 population.

Practically every city of importance in Canada and the United States, and many cities in foreign countries use "W&T" chlorination equipment. Toronto, Hamilton, London, Windsor, Ottawa, Brantville, Kingston, Guelph, Chatham and Niagara Falls, Ontario; Quebec, Trois-Rivieres, Lachine, Murray Bay, New Brunswick, Halifax, Saint John, Fredericton N.B.; Regina, Moose Jaw and Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, San Francisco, London, England, Dublin, South Africa, Melbourne, Australia, Lima, Peru, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Havana, Cuba, Shanghai, China, and Kyoto City, Japan, use "W&T" apparatus in their water purification plants.

The Operation of the Chlorinator

The MSP and MSPM Chlorinator is designed to meet the varied requirements of the average small water works. With the Type MSP Chlorinator the chlorine solution is applied under pressure to the suction side of the gate clamp. With the Type MSPM the point of application will be in the suction main or pipe line. Pressure application as well as gravity feed of the chlorine solution is possible, it being only necessary that a water supply under sufficient pressure be available for operation.

The minimum water pressure required for a gravity feed installation is ten pounds. Where electric or other means of applying pressure to the water supply for operating the chlorinator must be under at least three times the pressure existing at the point of application. The quantity of water required will usually range from two to four thousand gallons per minute. In those cases where a water supply under the pressure necessary to operate the chlorinator is not available, a pumping unit operated either by electric or hydraulic power is used.

The chlorine gas after passing through the pressure compensator where the pressure is reduced, is measured by a volumetric meter chart visible and adjustable. After leaving the meter the chlorine passes through the suction chamber to the injector where the solution of chlorine and water is formed. It then flows directly to the point of application.

Reliefs are provided on the machine which prevent moisture being drawn back into the chlorine gas control parts of the equipment, and also prevent the escape of chlorine gas into the room in the event of accidental failure of the water supply to the equipment.

This equipment is ideally suited for swimming pool sanitation where the point of chlorination is generally near the filter effluent tank or is also adaptable to the small sewage disposal plant. Introduction

ADAPTABILITY to the changing conditions of life, to the demand for pure water for domestic and industrial purposes has been the cause of the development of Chlorination as a highly satisfactory means of sterilising water for varied purposes in a simple and economical manner.

The Bell Chlorinator, which is fully described in the following pages, is the outcome of a long experience in the treatment of impure waters of all kinds coupled with a technical engineering experience of over forty years' duration.

This apparatus has a high degree of efficiency as a sterilising agent, is adaptable for domestic water supplies; the Chlorination of Sewage Effluent, a means of treatment which is meeting with approval among many of the most eminent Sewage Engineers; the sterilisation of swimming bath water, a practice which, following the suggestions made by the Ministry of Health, is now almost universal. For industrial purposes it will do good work in the Paper Mill, Textile Work and in fact anywhere where a bacterially free water is required, particularly is it useful for the sterilisation of condenser cooling water.
CHLORINATION OF WATER FOR INDUSTRIAL & PUBLIC SUPPLY

The provision of an adequate supply of sufficiently pure water is essential to the maintenance of life and the conduct of industry. It is, therefore, obviously impossible to exaggerate the importance of finding a solution to the difficulties with which the problem of such provision is beset.

Impurity in water may be organic or inorganic and, whether organic or inorganic, may occur either in suspension or solution.

Though many substances and various types of bacteria may be present without constituting any danger to health, the presence of pathogenic (i.e., disease bearing) germs may render any water affected dangerous in the highest degree.

When present in water in such quantity as to be dangerous, inorganic impurity is often distinctly perceptible to the senses. For example, various salts render water "hard" and nauseating, and many of the iron compounds result in both obvious taste and colour.

In general, ground water taken from certain depths is sufficiently free from bacteria as a result of the natural filtration effected by its percolation through the ground, but surface water must always be looked upon with a degree of suspicion.

Most of the bacteriological contamination of water may be traced to human or other organic pollution, and it is obvious that water supply chiefly becomes a serious problem when numbers of human beings are congregated into a community.

More especially with industrial communities is the provision of an adequate supply of sufficiently pure water a complicated matter, although the nature of the problem may vary a little for wide ranges of populations.

As the water for purposes of domestic consumption has to conform to standards and fulfill requirements rather different from the standards and requirements which obtain in the case of the supply of water for technical and industrial purposes, it is obvious that the respective processes of water purification for these two purposes are best considered separately.
Chlorine in sufficient quantity is an absolute sterilizing agent but owing to the fact that raw water may vary materially and rapidly in quantity of matter in suspension and organic content a varying proportion of free chlorine is consumed in the oxidation of these substances. It therefore becomes necessary, in order to ensure the continuous destruction of all bacteria, to treat the water with an excess of chlorine and this excess may become apparent in taste and smell. It follows therefore that so far as concerns the supply of water for domestic purposes, the use of chlorine is best employed after preliminary treatment of the water in filters since the rate of dosing should be restricted to a maximum which does not make the water at all objectionable to taste or smell.

The small quantity of chlorine necessary to effect the requisite degree of final purification necessitates very careful proportioning to obtain the best results; and the difficulties attendant upon the efficient use of chloride of lime, the comparatively large storage accommodation required, its deterioration during storage, its smell and lack of uniformity in constitution, and the disposal of its residual sludge, have resulted in the introduction of free chlorine compressed in cylinders to liquid form.

Chlorine in this form is more easily and accurately controlled and of lower cost, and the advantages attending its use are perhaps best illustrated by the fact that in many instances, under practical working conditions, as many as from 3 to 4 pounds of chloride of lime have to be provided to effect a reduction of bacterial content similar to that effected by one pound of chlorine in the same water.

Other methods, electrolytic and so on, have from time to time been evolved, but at the present time we can claim that the method we advocate—of using cylinders of compressed chlorine gas—is generally superior from every point of view to any of them.

These features gradually became very apparent during the Great War, and were turned to such advantage that lorry and barge outfits were enabled to filter and sterilize 1,200 and 6,000 gallons per hour, respectively, of badly polluted water.

Free chlorine compressed to liquid form is undoubtedly the best of all sterilizing agents for practical use in connection with water supplies.

PURIFICATION OF WATER FOR INDUSTRIAL PURPOSES

One of the essential differences between the treatment of water for human consumption, and the treatment of water for industrial purposes is that a slight overdose of chlorine, which is usually consequent upon such dosing, will absolutely ensure sterilization of water varying slightly in constitution from time to time, in the one case is open to objection, but in the other is usually quite unimportant. It follows therefore that complete sterilization of most industrial waters may, without resultant nuisance, be ensured by treatment with chlorine.

For many industrial purposes river or canal water is used in large quantities. In many cases the water before use is subjected to sedimentation in tanks, but this process is only partially successful in its operation as it cannot eliminate bacteria nor can it, without an undue period of storage, eliminate all the other very fine organic or inorganic matter in suspension.

Such water is unsatisfactory and often gives rise to trouble and avoidable expense. For example, if it be used for cooling surface condenser tubes a slight film of matter will generally be deposited upon the tubes and in time will be found to adhere so tightly as to necessitate the employment of stiff brushes for its removal. This film will prevent the maintenance of a good vacuum which is a matter of considerable importance as it has been found that a variation of one inch affects the steam consumption (and consequently the fuel consumption) in steam turbine work as much as nearly six per cent.

Examination has shown that the adhesive properties of the slimy deposited matter are due not so much to matter in suspension as to micro-organisms and that if these microorganisms are sterilized the remaining mineral matter to a large extent ceases to be a cause of trouble.

In such cases as these chlorine has proved to be a clean, cheap, simply-admixed sterilizing agent and to have effected relatively enormous reductions in cleaning charges.

The elimination of risks of septic poisoning, the bleaching of materials used in textile and paper manufacture, the deodorizing of fats and oils, the treatment of water for public swimming baths are but a few of the increasing number of uses to which chlorination may with advantage be applied.

Used in connection with the sanitary services of Hospitals, Institutions, and on board ship, it has proved a reliable and convenient sterilizing agent. Its cheapness renders it an economical proposition for use in the sterilizing of farm buildings, and any place where disease producing matter is liable to collect.

Chlorination should be seriously considered by all users of water which is contaminated by organic pollution.

CHLORINATING PLANT

It is apparent that the chlorination of water for industrial purposes differs from the chlorination of water for domestic supply in little except the amount of chlorine used, and that a type of Plant which successfully admixes the chlorine for the treatment of the one is equally suitable for the treatment of the other.

A careful investigation of the problem of correct admixing has resulted in the production by us of a Plant which is designed to be completely self-contained and to occupy the minimum possible space.

The principle upon which the Plant functions is usually that of the solution feed, as it has been found that chlorine is most easily and efficiently admixed in the required proportion if first dissolved in water and added as a solution.

The chlorine is delivered to the users of the Plant in steel cylinders containing, when fully charged, 70 lbs. of chlorine at 120 lbs. pressure per square inch. These cylinders are easily and safely handled and are readily recharged as and when required. It may also be obtained in 10 cwt. and 15 cwt. drums.

On page II is illustrated a plant capable of discharging up to 1 lb. of gas per hour when working with one cylinder only in actual use. When the first cylinder is exhausted, the position of the second enables the change-over to be effected with only a momentary cessation of the supply of gas. The empty first cylinder is then replaced by a full cylinder and in due course is recharged ready for future use.

With both cylinders in use the Plant is capable of discharging up to 2 lbs. of gas per hour. There are cases, however, where the few minutes' delay in the discharge of the chlorine, consequent upon the removal of the two cylinders when empty, would not be permissible, and in such cases the Plant must be considered as capable of discharging up to 1 lb. only of gas per hour.

The cylinders AA stand together upon a platform-weighing machine, which may be supplied if required and which is provided with a suitable arrangement for holding the cylinders and with a visible scale by means of which the attendant is able to perceive when the cylinder in use at the time is about to become empty. The weighing also serves to check the consumption of chlorine as recorded by the meter J.
This Instrument embodies the Gravity Feed Type Chlorinator with the addition of a closed solution tank from which the solution may be fed direct to the suction side of one or more pumps. A float valve is incorporated to control the supply of the water to the tower and keep the solution in the tank at constant level and prevent overflowing in the event of the pump being shut down.
The chlorine is permitted to escape from the cylinder by the opening of the valve B, and the auxiliary valve BI, and, on issuing, passes through the pipe E to the combined junction-box and filter C, at the pressure indicated by the pressure gauge D, and thence to a pressure reducer F. The gas usually leaves the reducer at a pressure of 14 lbs. per square inch, a second pressure gauge, G, being provided to indicate the reduced pressure. Both pressure gauges are specially arranged in such a way that their working parts are effectually isolated from direct contact with the gas.

From the pressure-reducer, F, the gas is admitted by the micrometer valve, H, to the meter, J, which upon a graduated scale gives a direct reading of the chlorine passing. The meter can be calibrated to give readings in terms of lbs. per 100,000 gallons of water treated or to indicate the quantity of gas passing per day or per hour. The amount of chlorine is adjusted, as and when necessary, by means of the micrometer valve, H. The details of the meters are shown on pages 12 and 13.

In the particular example illustrated the chlorine is passed from the meter through the outlet valve, B2, to an absorption-chamber, L, constructed in glazed acid-resisting stoneware. Water is introduced into the top of the absorption-chamber through a perforated plate designed to ensure effective distribution. The water flowing down through the chamber absorbs the chlorine and the resultant solution is finally passed from the bottom of the absorption-chamber through outlet pipe, R, into the main supply at the selected point.

A drying apparatus is provided at K in order to inhibit the passage of any moisture from the absorption-chamber to the control apparatus when the flow of gas ceases.

MANOMETER TYPE

The Manometer type meter consists of two tubes, one inside the other.

The centre tube is connected to one side of an orifice plate through which the gas passes and the annular space between the two tubes is connected to the other side of the orifice.

The tubes are filled with manometer liquid to the zero level on the scale provided. When the gas is turned on the difference in pressure on the two sides of the orifice causes the liquid to rise in the inner tube and the scale is calibrated to give a direct reading of the amount of gas passing in lbs. per hour or day or any other unit desired. The zero on scale is only set to level of liquid when no gas is passing and does not require adjustment for each individual reading.

The usual range for an orifice and scale is 10 to 1. The capacity of any instrument can be further altered in a few moments by inserting a different orifice and scale to correspond. For very small quantities of gas the pulsating meter is used, as the size of orifice with the Manometer type would not be practicable in actual practice.
CHLORINE METER
PULSATING TYPE

The Pulsating Meter consists of two tubes placed one inside the other, the inner tube having a small syphon pipe fused inside it as shown in the illustration.

The gas passes down the outer tube and depresses the liquid therein until it reaches the bottom of the syphon when the gas rushes through to the centre tube the pressure is thus reduced in the outer tube and the liquid returns to its original level.

The pressure then again builds up in the outer tube forcing down the liquid and the cycle is repeated. The number of pulsations per minute are counted and the amount of gas used is given on a table according to the number of pulsations. The pulsating meter is capable of measuring very small volumes of gas and has a range of approximately 30 to 1. The volume of each pulsation is controlled by the syphon pipe and the capacity of the meter may be altered by inserting another centre tube with a longer or shorter syphon as may be desired. The illustrations show the meter at the commencement (Fig. 1) and at the end (Fig. 2) of the pulsation.
POINT OF APPLICATION

The point of application of the chlorine solution should be determined only after a careful examination of the conditions obtaining. In the very usual case of a water containing a large and varying amount of organic matter preliminary sedimentation and filtration is very desirable in order that the variation, which otherwise would make the correct apportionment of chlorine a difficult matter, may be reduced to a minimum, and also this pre-treatment reduces the dose of chlorine necessary.

The position of the sedimentation tank or tanks and filtration where provided for Preliminary treatment must of necessity influence the choice of a site for the Chlorination Plant.

In the case of supply for domestic purposes where it is found impracticable to provide a suitably long period of contact, or otherwise necessary continuously to overdose the water in order to ensure complete safety to the consumers, it may be desirable subsequently to dechlorinate the water by the addition of the requisite small quantity of sulphur-dioxide or other approved means.

The fact that an overdose of chlorine leaves an objectionable taste is generally of no importance when the water is treated for use in connection with an Industrial supply, but a continuous and unnecessary overdose is obviously to be avoided if only on the ground of cost.

The Plant should be enclosed in a dry warm room where the temperature should be maintained above 50° Fahrenheit (10° Centigrade) in order to prevent trouble resulting from the freezing of the chlorine in the cylinders through loss of heat by evaporation. This consideration also determines the maximum rate—never more than one pound per hour—at which the chlorine may be drawn from each cylinder.

The point where the chlorine solution is applied to the water under treatment should be as near as is practicable to the Chlorinating Plant. These general conditions will usually determine the selection of the best site for the Plant.
ESTIMATION OF CORRECT QUANTITY OF CHLORINE TO BE USED

The correct proportion of chlorine to be added to water for use in connection with supplies for human consumption may be, and generally is, a problem necessitating expert determination.

The method of bacteriological investigation usually adopted is directed to ascertain the smallest volume of the water in which are found traces of B. coli. and its congeners, and the results are usually expressed in terms of the minimum number of cubic centimetres of water in which these traces are discovered.

We can supply, if required, a simple laboratory apparatus and the necessary cultivation media to enable the determination to be made upon the site as and when necessary.

To enable us to consider the requirements of any particular case, it is desirable that we should be supplied with detailed information upon the following points:

1. Source of water supply.
2. Constitution of the raw water (typical analyses).
3. Quantity of water to be treated per hour.
4. Purpose for which the water is to be used.
5. Present treatment if any.
6. Capacity of storage or settling tanks, if any.
7. Period of contact allowable.
8. Rate of pumping.
9. Diagram of water system.
10. Is there a separate supply of water for the feed to tower or injector? If so state pressure.
11. What is the pressure in main at point of application?
12. Is the supply constant in quantity? If not give max. and min. flows.

The "BELL" Automatic Chlorinator has been designed to meet the requirements of clients who desire to administer Chlorine Gas to Water Supplies in such a manner that the amount of gas being added will vary proportionately to the volume of water being treated.

As will be seen from the illustration on Page 17, this instrument comprises a Standard Type Board on which is superimposed a specially designed Control Valve. COST OF CHLORINATION

The cost of labour involved in operating the Chlorinating Plant is very low, as apart from the periodical examination and adjustment of the gas supply and the changing of the cylinders, the Plant requires practically no attention.

The actual amount of chlorine used in the treatment of any water is relatively very small. In comparatively few actual cases would the rate of dosing exceed one pound of chlorine to one million pounds of the water treated; and at this rate of dosing the cost of chlorine for treating one million gallons of water (with chlorine at 2½ pence per lb.) would be approximately 25 pence.

The economic consideration of the advisability of installing a Chlorination Plant in connection with an industrial supply chiefly consists in a comparison of running charges. The small cost of the requisite chlorine is set against the saving to be effected in the reduction of labour costs, as for example in the cleaning of pipes, condenser surfaces and pumps, and in the reduction of material costs, as for example in coal consumption by the maintenance of efficient vacuum. The making of the comparison is usually an easy matter. In most cases, too, the result of the comparison will admit of no doubt as to the economy to be effected by the installation of the appropriate Plant.

The valve is so arranged that when the water supply is turned on sufficient pressure is created to keep the valve open, but immediately the water supply fails the valve shuts, and thus automatically cuts off the supply of gas. This device is primarily a safety device, and particularly useful where the instrument is housed in places which are difficult of access, and which would be dangerous in the event of anyone endeavouring to get close enough to the instrument to shut off the gas at the cylinder.

The Automatic Shut-off Valve may be adapted where the Chlorinator may suddenly be called upon to deal with large volumes of water as in the case of a fire. In this instance the Chlorinator may normally be working at a very low rate, and in the event of a fire when large volumes of water are introduced into the main the rising pressure operates the valve and thus increases immediately the amount of chlorine being added, and by this means prevents the possibility of pollution by the increased quantities of water which are often drawn from sources liable to pollution.
