TEST SETS

In connection with the treatment of water supplies by Chlorination it is essential that some simple form of test should be provided whereby the amount of free Chlorine left in the water may be easily and simply ascertained at any time. Two forms of Test Sets are put forward for this purpose as follows:

1. A small Test Set consisting of two standard colour tubes and one test tube, this Set being particularly useful in connection with Swimming Bath Water where the free Chlorine content should be maintained between .2 and .5 parts per million. In this Set the two tubes provided are for the two limits given, that is, .2 and .5, and when testing, a sample of the water is placed in the test tube, and a pre-determined quantity of re-agent added, and if the resultant colour falls between the two standard colours then the free Chlorine content is between .2 and .5 parts per million. Other colour standards can be supplied if required.

2. In the larger type of Test Set the number of standard colour tubes varies according to the particular requirements of each individual enquiry, and although the actual testing procedure is similar in each case yet in this instance as there is a greater range of colour it is, of course, possible to obtain more exactly the free Chlorine content of the treated water.

With the above sets once the correct dose has been decided the attendant can at any time test and see in a few moments if the correct dose has been maintained.

Therefore, on the basis hereof if you were normally treating the water only during the period of pump operation, one same cylinder of chlorine would last roughly eight years. In other words, with the existing layout you are wasting chlorine twenty-one hours out of each twenty-four.

Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter 129-3-5 dated October 19th and would recommend that immediate action be taken in reference to the sewage disposal. The season is well advanced and if any work is to be done it must be started at once.

I was at the school this week and would say that the disposal bed is filled and useless. At 80 ft. from the septic tank the water comes out on top of the ground and continues in a steady stream to the lake. It empties into the lake about 80-100 ft. from the intake pipe.

The water from the septic tank is quite clear but I cannot understand why there is a continuous steady flow. One would imagine the septic tank was allowed to fill up and the water simply passed through. The overflow amounts to a small creek and this would further indicate that the pump supplying the school with water must be working almost continuously. If the septic tank is working properly it should discharge at intervals, thus making it possible for the disposal bed to handle the overflow.

The old disposal bed should be renewed and enlarged as I am sure it is filled up and altogether too small. I am instructing the agent to have the principal arrange for cleaning out both chambers of the septic tank and these should be checked over as well as the plumbing system, by a qualified plumber. I think the school is wasteful of water, which increases the need for a larger disposal bed and affects the chemical action of the septic tank.

In closing I would say we leave ourselves open to severe criticism if we continue to allow this steady stream of water from the septic tank to flow into the lake from which the drinking water is obtained. The estimate of $1400.00 appears high and I am inclined to think the disposal field can be renewed and enlarged for much less. The services of a plumber to check all waste of water should not cost much and if his

The Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School at Kenora, Ontario, was completed early in 1929. The installation of the water supply and sewage disposal systems was carried out under the direction and supervision of this district office.

The school is situated on a sandy hillside some 60 feet from and 60 feet above Round Lake, the source of the water supply. Back of the school the ground rises steeply and rock outcroppings occur. Consequently, the only possible drainage of the school site is into Round Lake. It was necessary, therefore, to treat the sewage from the school in order to prevent pollution of the water supply. The method of treating sewage by means of a septic tank and disposal bed was selected as best suited for continuous service with a minimum of attention. As washing compounds used in the laundry were considered harmful to septic action in the tank, a separate laundry sump was provided.

EXISTING SEWAGE SYSTEM:

The existing sewage system consists of septic tank, disposal bed and separate laundry drainage system. The system was designed for a total school population of one hundred. The septic tank has a capacity of 4,000 gallons and the siphon chamber 525 gallons additional. The disposal bed contains 1,600 lineal feet of 4" field tile laid in sand.

About two years after the school was put into operation, trouble was experienced with the laundry sump failing to dispose of laundry drainage. The sand surrounding the sump had become almost impervious by the accumulation
of grease etc. The sump was enlarged and measures were taken to convey the drainage to a gravel strata to permit more rapid seepage. This work was not carried under our supervision and at present we do not know to what extent if any, this work interfered with the disposal bed.

The present disposal bed has been in place nearly seven years. It has received no attention and the surface is now very uneven, overgrown with weeds and covered with some rubbish. Doubtless, the tar-paper covering on the tile joints has deteriorated, permitting the coarse sand to enter and clog the tile. The clogging of the tile and the 70% overloading of the bed have resulted in some of the seepage reaching the surface of the bed. The close proximity of the bed to the school makes it essential that the surface seepage be eliminated.

The present population of the school is about 170 or 70 in excess of the number for which the sewage disposal system was designed. While the usage of water at this Institution does not increase proportionately to the increase in population, yet it is fairly certain that clogging of the disposal bed has taken place. The septic tank is slightly undersized for a population of 170 and the syphon chamber in particular should be enlarged for efficient results.

PROPOSED ENHANCEMENTS TO SEWAGE SYSTEM:

It is recommended that the capacity of the existing syphon chamber of the septic tank be increased from its present capacity of 525 gallons to 1,000 gallons; that the existing disposal bed containing 1,600 linear feet of 4" tile be opened up and if necessary be reconditioned and that an addition be made to the disposal bed so as to increase the total length of field tile to 2,800 feet.
The accompanying plan shows the location of the proposed extension to the disposal bed and sections of either side of the extension. However, the location of the new disposal bed will depend upon additional ground surveys which it is intended to carry out in order to determine the most economical location and most favourable soil conditions. Uncertainty exists as to the drainage from the laundry sump and its effect upon the disposal bed and this must be cleared up by examination on the ground.

The enlargement of the syphon chamber of the septic tank will present no difficulties and the enlargement will reduce by half the daily number of discharges into the disposal bed and permit of greater efficiency in the working of the disposal bed.

ESTIMATES OF COSTS:

The following estimates of costs are based upon the costs of the original construction and revised to allow for additional costs arising from the fact that the original work was carried out in conjunction with the original school construction job.

(a) Septic Tank:
   Enlargement of Syphon Chamber ------------ $150.00

(b) Old Disposal Bed:
   Unlaying and Relaying ------------------ 275.00

(c) New Disposal Bed:
   Excavation ----------------------------- $300.00
   Laying Tile and Surfacing -------------- 250.00
   Glazed Pipe ---------------------------- 40.00
   Field Tile ------------------------------ 130.00
   Cartage --------------------------------- 20.00
   Total ----------------------------------- $740.00

Supervision, etc. ------------------------ $1165.00

Total Estimated Costs:--------------------- $1400.00
REMARKS:

The work should be carried out during the brief summer period in which the school is not operating; viz: in July. There will always be some inmates at the school, but the extensions can be carried out without completely closing down the sewage disposal system.

The Honourable the Minister,

For the past two years we have been receiving complaints regarding the sewage disposal system at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ont., but, owing to lack of funds, we have been unable to make necessary improvements.

As the season is advancing and so the necessity for improving the sewage disposal system appears very urgent, I would appreciate having your authority to advise Inspector Hamilton by wire to have this work proceed at once. Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter 129-3-5 dated October 16th and would recommend that immediate action be taken in reference to the sewage disposal. The season is well advanced and if any work is to be done it must be started at once.

I was at the school this week and would say that the disposal bed is filled and useless. At 80 ft. from the septic tank the water comes out on top of the ground and continues in a steady stream to the lake. It empties into the lake about 80-100 ft. from the intake pipe.

The water from the septic tank is quite clear but I cannot understand why there is a continuous steady flow. One would imagine the septic tank was allowed to fill up and the water simply passed through. The overflow amounts to a small creek and this would further indicate that the pump supplying the school with water must be working almost continuously. If the septic tank is working properly it should discharge at intervals, thus making it possible for the disposal bed to handle the overflow.

The old disposal bed should be renewed and enlarged as I am sure it is filled up and altogether too small. I am instructing the agent to have the principal arrange for cleaning out both chambers of the septic tank and these should be checked over as well as the plumbing system, by a qualified plumber. I think the school is wasteful of water, which increases the need for a larger disposal bed and affects the chemical action of the septic tank.

In closing I would say we leave ourselves open to severe criticism if we continue to allow this steady stream of water from the septic tank to flow into the lake from which the drinking water is obtained. The estimate of $1400.00 appears high and I am inclined to think the disposal field can be renewed and enlarged for much less. The services of a plumber to check all waste of water should not cost much and if his

I would ask, if possible, that the Department arrange for this work to be started immediately. Otherwise, it will be too cold.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter L29-3-8 dated October 19th, 1937, I would submit the following report.

The teachers' convention was in progress. Consequently the children were not in class-room. There are three teachers - Mrs. Burgess (senior room), Miss Keith, M.A. (intermediate room) and Miss Lamb (primary). The teachers are all well qualified and I have always found the class-room work well above the average. The children number 131 and these seem were well dressed and neat in appearance.

The building throughout I found in fair condition. The dormitories were all clean and well aired. The beds were neatly made and provided with plenty of blankets. Some of the mattresses were past repairing and at least thirty new ones should be provided.

The sewing room is well managed and I believe the girls receive a good training in plain sewing, mending and patching. The school receives a large number of bales of clothing and there is no store room provided. Mr. Eyers stated he would arrange for the labour of building if the Department could supply the material. I think this is a reasonable request and if funds are available, I would recommend that a suitable building be provided.

The halls throughout the building are dark and gloomy and if re-decorated at any time, I would
recommend a lighter shade of paint.

The dining room and kitchen are well kept and I have no reason to doubt that the children are supplied with sufficient wholesome food.

The boys' play-room was dusty and showed some lack of care, as did also the washroom.

In reference to the toilets, I am not prepared to recommend any change. On the girls' side everything is in good condition and there is no reason why the boys' toilets should not be kept the same. I pointed this out to Mr. Myers and he remarked that boys were naturally more careless. I added that this should be a part of their training and I considered it a very necessary one.

An Indian boy graduate is boys' supervisor and I doubt if conditions will improve under this arrangement. The boys' toilets need a thorough cleaning and this work continued day after day and not forgotten days and weeks at a time. I would recommend a different supervisor - one not only to look after this side of the work but a man who could instruct the boys in clean, healthful sports.

I think the toilets should be regulated to flush more often. This would reduce the odor and would not increase the water used because the quantity at each flushing could be greatly reduced. This is one place where I think a good practical plumber could offer some useful advice.

The outside of the school presents a good appearance. The front lawn is nicely kept and the lake adds to the beauty of the rocky surroundings.

Mr. Myers informed me he has at least 60 tons of hay and threshed 700 bushels of oats. I understand he rents some land adjacent to the school and it was from this he received his grain.
The cow barn has been whitewashed and cleaned but I found in them two head of cattle, a cow and heifer, which had been purchased to butcher. I objected to bringing in these cattle because this might just defeat the effort of having a clean gum-free stable for some tested cattle. I asked concerning the proposed herd and Mr. Myers stated he had partly arranged to get four Ayrshire heifers from a man near Teulon, Manitoba. The school needs milk cows not heifers and I would recommend that six or eight cows be purchased and these should be just fresh or about to freshen. If we are not going to get milk for this winter, I hardly see the use of buying cows before spring. If and when the cows are to be purchased, would it not be advisable to secure the services of a veterinary from the Health of Animals Branch here. I am informed they are willing to cooperate in any work of this nature. I would also point out that Mr. Myers has a good short horn bull which he purchased last spring at the Brandon Bull sale. I advised him at the time to wait for the results of the Bang's test in his herd; but he was determined to buy the bull, and did. I think it is a mistake to jump from one breed to another and we all must admit that the short horn cattle are hard to beat, for an all around general purpose breed. On the other hand, if he is only desirous of milk, then either Holstein or Ayrshire should be selected.

As stated in my report dated January 27th, 1929, I repeat that we should not attempt to go into extensive farming at this school as a matter of fact the country does not permit of farming as we think of it in Manitoba. I travelled all over the George's farm, which comprises 167 acres. There are perhaps 56 acres under cultivation. I would judge that another 35 or 40 acres might be obtained but this would
cost at least $25.00 per acre to brush and break. The balance of the farm is swamp, rock and hills. In fact, the rocks are so high along one side that a fence is not necessary. The house is frame (about 18 x 34 with 16 ft. corners). It has never been painted and is finished inside with wall board. The other buildings are useless and of no value. In my other report I stated that "it was doubtful if the farm was worth the mortgage against it." The mortgage is approximately $600.00 and after talking over the farm I definitely am of the opinion that it cannot be sold for nearly this amount. The farm is located approximately three miles by road from the school and this makes it undesirable as part of the school property. If Mr. Syers is determined to farm more I think it best to let him continue to rent as he has done in the past. However, a school in this locality should confine its outside work to gardening, poultry, and the keeping of a small herd of cows—not at any time over ten head. The keeping of bees might be a sideline worthy of consideration.

I hope the information desired will be found in this report.

Under separate cover I wrote the Department re the urgent work needed to repair and improve the disposal bed.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Re File 129-3-5:

Regarding your communication re the cleanliness of the boys' toilets I wish to offer the following explanation:

The school is equipped with the oil platoon system which is considered by the experts as the most suitable for public institutions. The toilets are exposed and flush only as the tank is filled with a fresh supply of water.

We have no urinal in the school and the boys' toilets with their present seat is impossible to keep them clean.

It is not workable to have a supervisor present every time each boy uses the toilet and as there are 600 pupils a boy must be impossible to use the seat toilette and not get some wet on the seat.

I am being criticised for a condition which I can see no way to overcome.

The toilets look unclean but if they are examined under a flashlight the appearance is caused by rust having corroded the seats.

The toilets are scrubbed daily and we have installed a hose to wash them which has been doing this job regularly.

I really do not know what steps we can take to improve the situation with our present layout and if the situation were fully understood I doubt if anything could be improved.

I shall appreciate any suggestions which you may offer to improve the condition of the toilets but I do not see that closer supervision will produce results.

We should have a proper urinal installed.

I remain,

Dear Sir:

Re: your letter 129-3-5 of the 10th instant, returning Voucher #638, for $701.90, covering wages paid in connection with the sewage disposal plant for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

On October 7th, in reviewing the statement of wages, I asked for a quantity of return of Labour forms #638, but was unable to obtain them. I have completed the returns for the Cecilia Jeffrey School work, and erasing logs for the houses on the Lac Seul Reserve. The order requisition was sent in yesterday, I applied for a further quantity.

In the past, in all cases where we have employed a large number of men, it has been the custom to have me sign the original Labour Sheet, and I have done so this time. I have enclosed the original form, and have signed it. I have also enclosed one copy for the file here and three for the Department. Up to date, there have been no complaints on this system.

We did not have a sufficient number of Labour Sheets to provide the necessary copies, to pay the extra .05¢ per hour on the Cecilia Jeffrey School job, but have ruled out for this purpose which will be acceptable. We have enclosed the copies signed by the men, and also the typewritten copies, which have returned. We have notified the men to call at
this Office to collect the extra money due them, and it will be better to have the warrant copies signed, than to wait until the end of next month. It will mean the men would not receive their pay for a while, and it would necessitate their calling at the office several times. The men seem anxious to get paid, and the Indians who supplied teams would probably be the end of the month, or later, before no returns could be sent to Ottawa.

I have on hand $48.10 and shall be glad to receive your cheque for $13.15 to enable me to make payments.

Regarding the Labour Board, I have heard that Lac Seul work, in most cases, is obtained by only obtaining one meet, and, as these Indians are scattered all over the country, trapping, etc., it would be absolutely impossible to obtain suitable labourers from this district. I believe they will want it in the course of a few days, and I trust that, under the circumstances, they will be acceptable. In future I will see that the Regulations are complied with. I only wish I had known of this before these men were paid off.

The same condition also applies in connection with the work done at the Arrow. It will be done, I believe, in the spring, and quadruplicate, as some of the men have left for the winter.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

I was hoping that we might be able to carry on until spring without disturbing the main pipe-line for several weeks. It seems to be evident that there is something escaping that the pumps will not shut off automatically owing to lack of pressure when pumping.

I am very much afraid of its cutting off entirely.

As the break is located in a very inaccessible place it is impossible to decide from surface indications. The water is running out of the side of the hill near the pump-house but the water may be following the line. Last summer the ground was very dry and the soil was very small and thin so thought it was an account of the heavy rains we had had. Now I assume this cave-in may have some connection with the break in the pipe-line.

I would like to suggest that two men be engaged to make test holes and if they are lucky they could locate the break within two or three days. They would not be very busy gathering wood and as they have to make long trips they are away all day.

As to the probable cost it is impossible to estimate. Under ordinary circumstances $500.00 would be sufficient. But it might mean replacing a large portion of the line. This would take probably $200.00 if it has to be done in the Winter while the ground is frozen.

I would suggest that if the break can be located and can be stopped sufficiently to make it safe until spring it might be better to do nothing until spring and then repair it.

I feel this is very urgent and that something should be done immediately as anything might happen at any time.

This is a very important matter and I am sure that help and will always serve a valuable purpose. It he meant a great saving on the pumps.

I shall very much appreciate very early action on the matter.

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 129-3-5 dated February 18th, I understand from the Dominion Water & Power Bureau here that in 1929 they designed a sewage disposal system for the Cecilia Jeffrey School. The plan was designed for the accommodation of 100 people. I understand this plan was submitted to our Department for their approval.

For some years past, I am given to understand that with the pupils and staff the number at the school has totalled from 160 to 170. Consequently, you will see that the original design was altogether too small.

Last fall a new disposal field was laid and this was enlarged to accommodate the increased number. I understand the syphon chamber should also be enlarged in proportion to the enlargement of the disposal bed. This will naturally reduce the number of discharges and each discharge will fill the disposal field. I understand this is what is desired.

It is estimated that the cost of enlarging the syphon chamber will be approximately $150.00. However, this will depend largely on the condition of the present syphon chamber when the work is undertaken and I think it would be well to provide at least another $100.00.

KENORA, ONT., March 4th 1938

Dear Captain:

I hereby wish to present you with my report after making a thorough inspection of all the fire protection appliances and other safety installations in both the Indian residential schools.

I found the premises at the Cecilia Jeffrey School very clean and tidy and all appliances well kept and in their proper places, but after testing out all the linen fire hose on the hose standards I found that two fifty foot sections of it is of no more use and shall have to be replaced. The hose on the hose reel in the yard is about perished and about five hundred feet of the rubber lined hose should be procured for outside protection; this hose should not be used nor any of the linen hose for any purpose except for fire.

The chemical extinguishers are in good order and the fire alarm system is also in proper working order although it does not extend to the furnace room or the Superintendent quarters as it should.

It may be a good idea to have a large bell installed on the building for in case of a fire when the Boys and Girls are out playing or on other outside exercise they could be called in to assist in extinguishing any fire that may start from some inside source. I wish to recommend that an extension be added to the roof of the building on the North side to keep snow and ice from falling on the fire escape, as it is at present all the snow and water runs immediately on these escapes off of the main roof.

I also believe that in having hourly tours made by the night watchman to all sections of the premises including outside buildings this should assist in not only detecting fire early but it should also assist in preventing the pupils or others from rambling around the dormitories or other rooms during the night hours and do away with having the doors kept under lock and key.

One employee should be appointed to keep all the fire protection appliances as well as the fire escapes always in proper condition and periodical inspections made should be reported upon to the Superintendent in writing; fire drills should be periodically held from the class rooms and dormitories; the fire pump should be tested out several times during the year and the rubber lined hose should be tried out at the same time then thoroughly drained and dried out and placed back on the reel for instant use.

Respectfully submitted by

Chief Fire Dept.

Dear Sir,

The Grand Jury in making their report to Mr. Justice MacKay, yesterday, report; in connection with the two Indian Residential Schools in Kenora, as follows:

"St Mary's Industrial School (R.C. Residential School). The school was found to be well managed. The building is in urgent need of painting and decorating throughout. The fire hose, command by the Fire Marshall should be replaced. The fire extinguisher should be re-charged once annually. The last inspection was in December 1935. They also require new enamel plates and cups for dining room use. One verandah needs a new roof, and one more fire escape is needed in the girls dormitory.

Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School. The school appeared to be well managed, and the pupils contented. We found that no dormitories are provided with direct fire escapes. The existing fire escapes in centre of building should be repaired. Floors in all dormitories and class rooms should be covered with linoleum."

In reference to the above reports:- the painting, fire hose, and floor covering does not come up to us, as all estimates come under the Inspector now, and not through this office, as we do not see them.

No Fire Marshall has ever to my knowledge ever inspected any of my schools, but I do ask the local Fire Chief to inspect these building with me annually, and to give me a written report, as to anything he considers should be done, so as to make the schools as safe as possible from fire. These reports are always sent to Ottawa, and most of his recommendations are usually carried out.

I have enclosed herewith for the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School, the letter sent by the Purchasing Branch of the Department of Indian Affairs, dated 27th March, and the Fire Chief has been requested to see that all inspections are filled. They are inspected every year by him, but are not marked by us, as so considered they should be marked by the person who fills them. They were all inspected by us in March.

Our letter of the 23rd ult. gives the requirements for the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and your letter No. 45-5 of 23rd ultimo informs us the school will be supplied with hose. As regards the extra fire escapes I will discuss this with the Town Fire Chief. But this is a standard school, and no such recommendation has been put in before by any Jury or Fire Chief.
Neither of the two schools approve of your and the Jury's suggestions, that the dormitories be kept unlocked, shall I give definite instructions to the Principals on this point. They claim they cannot be responsible for the children, if doors are left unlocked at nights, and the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School says, if there was a bell put from the doors of the dormitories to the persons room who is supervising the dormitory at night, that person would quit, as her rest would be broken all night, and she would not get proper sleep, I cannot agree with his contention, but would like to know if I should instruct both schools, that some arrangement must be made so that the doors would not be locked.

As regards direct fire escapes from the dormitories at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, the children have to leave the dormitories and come down a few steps to reach the escapes, which are near the staircases, and there is no doubt a certain amount of danger in this, but as I pointed out to the Principal, if escapes were placed at each dormitory, this would give another avenue of egress to the pupils should they wish to get out at night.

I am informed that a verandah is being built at the Sioux Lookout Residential School (which is the same design) as the Cecilia Jeffrey, this will act as an escape in case of fire, but will also allow the children to get out at night should they wish to do so.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions,

Gent. Frank Edwards,

It happened in an Indian school, in this Agency, a short time ago, some boys having made use of a ladder to gain access to the girls' dormitory.

We have a night watchman for only six months in the year, and even when he is on duty, he has to make his inspection of the barn and the pump house, and would be away for several periods during the night. While he was absent, the girls and boys could easily mix in the dormitories.

I have found that the strictest supervision has to be exercised at all times, to keep the boys and girls in their places, and when discussing this problem with other principals, I find they have the same difficulties.

I hope the Department is not going to ask our School to put into practice methods, which are not required by the other schools. I certainly would not appreciate working under such conditions, and I would like to receive further instructions from the Department, outlining how one might proceed to run a mixed school and at the same time safeguard the morals of the pupils.

The system we use is to lock the doors with padlocks, that can be removed almost as readily as turning the knob of the door. We arranged it this way, in the event of fire, so that we could feel we were using a system that would not, in any way, endanger our pupils.

Dear Sir:

[1935-04-29]

In reply to your letter, I wish to make the following observations.

In the first place, I feel that there must be some misunderstanding as to which of the doors of the school are to be locked and which are unlocked. It has always been the practice in our school to see that all doors leading to the fire escapes are unlocked during the nights but the dormitory doors have been locked. I notice, in your letter, that you state that the procedure followed at other Indian Residential Schools is to have the dormitory doors unlocked. I have communicated with six different Indian Residential Schools and inquired regarding their procedure, and they all inform me that they lock their dormitory doors at night.

In addition to this, I have visited some other Indian Residential Schools, and they, too, locked their dormitory doors. In fact I do not know of any Indian Residential School that does not lock their dormitory doors during the night.

I would very much appreciate having the addresses of some of the schools which leave their dormitories unlocked, as I would like to communicate with them, with a view to obtaining their methods of keeping the boys and girls under control. SIOUX LOOKOUT, ONT.
May 4th, 1936.

Mr. E.W. Byers,
Oceilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Last Saturday night I received a wire from you, "Do you leave dormitory doors unlocked at night?" We replied, "Boys' dormitories locked, girls' dormitories unlocked."

Now I presume from your haste in a wire that you must be up against some difficulty. I have visited a good many Indian Residential schools and others in the course of my work and in some of the very best schools I notice that they lock both girls' and boys' dormitories at night. In some schools I have even noticed padlocks on the doors as the principals of these schools said these boys were experts at picking locks. We got into difficulty here some years ago when the Boys' Master left a dormitory door unlocked because he had a boy who needed constant attention. While he was watching, a few hours after three boys slipped down stairs and started a fire in the wood room and were heard returning to the dormitory by one of the men of the staff. He went downstairs to find out who had gone down and found one of the boys still in the wood room adding coal oil to the flames.

Whatever your difficulties may be I certainly would not leave boys dormitories unlocked under any consideration. But we do leave the key turned in the door from the hall side so that any member of the staff can open them. We have not found it necessary to lock the girls in, although, they know that the same thing would happen to them if they disobeyed rules.

As for having some member of the staff sleeping in the dormitory I cannot agree with it. It is trying enough to work with these children in the daytime without having to sleep in the same dormitory and continually getting the Indian odor from them. As for the trusted boy or girl who could have their bed close to the door I have never seen one who hasn't been sound asleep and you could have moved the whole dormitory out before they could have awakened up. I know this from years of experience and before my illness I walked through this building every night and walked past every child's bed to see if they were properly covered, sometime about midnight.

If you are confronted with some difficulty do not hesitate to write and I will give you the benefit of my knowledge and experience not only as Missionary and Principal but as eight years Police Magistrate with the Mounted Police.

The best policy I know of to follow is good common sense.

With kindest regards, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Rev. J.F.J. Marshall
Principal

Sir:

Re: Sewage System, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

Following the receipt of your letter of March 25th in connection with the above, the writer made an inspection of the new disposal bed constructed last fall but snow covered the ground and a later inspection was desirable. On May 30th, I again examined the system, while in Kenora on another matter.

The Indian Residential School is built on a sandy shelf from which the ground slopes fairly steeply to the shore line of Round Lake to the source of the water supply for the school. The slope is composed of fairly coarse sand to a depth of many feet, probably overlying gravel or bed rock. From the time this building was constructed we have experienced trouble with the disposal of sewage and laundry wastes. The laundry sump soon became useless when the grease blocked passage of the liquid through the sand. Various expedients were adopted to care for the laundry wastes but some of the drainage still frequently comes to the surface and creates unsatisfactory conditions.

The original disposal bed appeared to work satisfactorily at first but some three or four years ago the liquid commenced rising to the surface and proceeded down the slope into the lake. The construction of the new disposal bed in freezing weather, late last fall, did not permit of a satisfactory job being performed. The sand was frozen and in large lumps so that when the bed was re-built and connected with the septic tank, the liquid quickly percolated through the coarse sand, made outlets for itself and flowed down the slope into the lake. It still continues to do so and as the effluent runs into the small lake, the source of the water supply, the present conditions are very unsatisfactory.

The soil conditions and the location upon the slope renders it very difficult to construct and maintain an efficient disposal bed for this school. It may be impossible to secure satisfactory results with the disposal bed but I would like to suggest that an attempt be made to secure results by some alterations to the present bed before some other scheme for the disposal of sewage be decided upon.

It will be necessary to uncover the tile at the sides and ends of the present bed and build up the outer borders of the bed itself with heavy earth to prevent erosion from within the bed. It will also be necessary to haul loam to mix with the coarse sand so as to obtain a more satisfactory soil condition. Furthermore, the surface must be made so that a growth of grass or other vegetation can be assured. It will be necessary to fence in the disposal bed in order to prevent livestock from crossing the same and damaging it.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
This work should be done early in July when the school is mostly unoccupied and the sewage system not fully loaded.

It is difficult to say what the cost of this suggested work will be but at least $300.00 should be allotted for the work. I would also suggest that an addition be made to the siphon chamber of the septic tank this summer, unless funds have already been provided for that purpose.

I would again point out that if it is desired to have this work proceeded with, it must be carried out during the period in July and August when the school holidays are on.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) D.B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Sewage disposal, Caselia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

On receipt of your memorandum of March 22nd last, Mr. Gow was requested to make an inspection of the above sewage disposal system as soon as weather conditions were suitable. His report has now been received and a copy is attached. From this report it will be noted that Mr. Gow is not prepared to estimate closely on the funds required for additional work necessary, but considers that for the suggested work at least $300.00 should be provided. It will also be noted that if this work is to be done this season, it should be carried out during the period in July and August when the school holidays are on.

It would appear from information available that there has been trouble for some time with this sewage disposal system. This would appear to be at least partly due to the topography at this point and also to the fact that the soil is of such a sandy nature that considerable seepage through same takes place into the lake which is the source of water supply for the school.

While under the circumstances it appears doubtful as to whether the system installed is the best, still as Mr. Gow only wants to do work which will cost a comparatively small amount this season, it is recommended that such work should be undertaken as a further experiment before any larger work would be planned that would revise the present system.

From Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of March 18th last, it is assumed that he will probably be able to provide the required money for this work. I would, however, be glad to be advised as to what instructions are to be issued in connection with same.

Dear Miss Lang:

No doubt you will recall that during our conference with Mr. Phelan last June, that he raised the question re: the locking of our dormitory doors at night. Mr. Phelan stated on that occasion that the Agent had misread the Department's instructions and that it was the doors leading onto fire escapes that the Department wished unlocked. He further stated that it was not practical to have the dormitory doors unlocked.

The Indian Agent here insists that I unlock the doors and at the same time every other school in his agency have the doors locked. I have visited quite a number of Indian Schools and in every one visited the doors are locked.

It seems to me a deep injustice that a ruling should be made to apply to one school and other schools are left free to do as they wish. I must have the boards' support in this matter, otherwise the agent is going to force me to throw our dormitory doors wide open, with boys sleeping at one end of the corridor and girls at the other end with nothing but the open corridor between.

The members of staff feel that it is an impossible situation and some have even said that they would rather resign than work under those conditions. The principals of Brandon, Birtle, Portage la Prairie, and Sioux Lookout all say it is impossible. I hope you will do everything possible to have this ruling vetoed.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Since writing you regarding a night-watchman for the Birtle school, I understand that in the other schools a watchman is allowed for seven months at a rate of $40.00 per month. At the Cecilia Jeffrey school, which is the largest in the agency, only $30.00 per month is allowed for six months.

In the matter of expense for bringing in the children, we have never received any allowance. At Cecilia Jeffrey our principal has very kindly brought in children going to other schools because they happened to be in the district where he was collecting children. For this he has received nothing, and a claim for bringing in our own children made by Mr. Byers was not allowed.

Our Society has always been very generous in its contribution to Indian work and we feel that we should have the same allowances as other churches. May I suggest that these matters be considered and a fair arrangement made?

September 23, 1936.

Dear Miss Lang:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant regarding the amount allowed for the night watchman at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School I would refer you to my recent letter in connection with the request for a grant for a night watchman at the Birtle School. In providing the necessary equipment for this service it was definitely understood that a grant for a night watchman would only be allowed at those Residential Schools where there was a very serious fire hazard. Two years ago the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School applied to the Department through Indian Agent Edwards, for a grant for a night watchman and while the Cecilia Jeffrey School cannot be recognized as one in which the fire hazard is serious the Principal stated that he had engaged a night watchman to assist him and it was decided to allow an amount of $50.00 a month for 6 months. We have always understood that this payment was satisfactory to the Principal.

Some years ago the Department purchased a boat for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey School. Under these circumstances it was felt that it should not be necessary to make an allowance for the transportation of pupils as they can be carried in the school boat. We have paid small accounts for the transportation of pupils from points which the school boat could not reach.

Yours truly,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Sewage Disposal System, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

Referring to your memorandum of the 24th of June last regarding the above, we are now advised by Mr. Gow that work for this season has been completed. As regards the work done, the following is quoted from Mr. Gow's letter for your information:

"The work carried out on this project consisted mostly of re-building up the disposal bed. As you are aware, this disposal bed was constructed early in the winter of 1937 during very severe frosty weather with the result that the ground was frozen and the job not properly finished. It was found necessary to dig up a considerable number of rows of tile, relay the same, reconstruct with denser material the borders of the disposal bed and add gravel and etc., to portions that had been washed away.

"The work carried out this summer is not expected to eliminate the trouble being experienced with the sewage disposal system at this school. The nature of the soil and the over-loading of the septic tank creates a condition where a disposal bed cannot be made to work satisfactorily. Accordingly, it is anticipated that more trouble will be experienced with this disposal bed and it was for this reason that we did not care to make further expenditures during the present season.

You will recall that an amount not exceeding $500.00 was approved for this work, but according to Mr. Gow's statement of expenditure, only $158.76 was actually expended. The reason limiting the work done this season to this amount being given in the last paragraph quoted above from Mr. Gow's report.

Respectfully submitted,

T.S. Mills

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director, Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa."

"Upon visiting this Institution we were most pleased to find the boys and girls in good health and well nourished."

Dear Sir,

Re Cedilia Jeffrey School.

When at Ponora last week I discussed with Mr. Byers several matters relating to the school and wish to report on them as follows.

The sewage disposal bed is again overflowing and the water is emptying into the lake from which the school obtains all its water. I doubt if this bed can ever be made to be satisfactory on account of the texture of the soil and I think perhaps it would be better, before making any further expenditure on the disposal bed to have Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power Branch investigate the possibilities of obtaining water either from a spring or by means of wells. If we could secure an abundance of water for the school by this means, it would eliminate the use of chlorinator and I do not think there would be any great objection to leaving the disposal bed in its present condition.

I have before brought to the Department's attention the fact that the electric bake oven is not satisfactory and cannot be used. When the oven is operating, it gives off a gas which makes it impossible for anyone to remain in the room as this gas affects the eyes and in a few minutes it is unbearable. I have been at the school when the oven was in use and know the condition is such that no woman could carry on her work. The oven has not been in use for a couple of years. I would recommend that it be discarded and that a wood burning oven be installed.

The school is badly in need of paint, both inside and out and Mr. Byers has had very little assistance in this respect. I would recommend that a quantity of paint be allowed and instructions issued that this is to be put on by the members of the staff, assisted by the pupils. I consider the boys need this training and it should be a part of their education.

I would be glad to know the Departments' decision in connection with these matters. Mr. Christianson was present during our conversation and no doubt could give further information in connection with these matters if such is required.

Sir:

Re: Sewage Disposal System, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 9th with reference to the above mentioned subject. The suggestions as made by Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, have been noted.

Mr. Hamilton suggested that the possibility of securing an adequate water supply from springs or wells in the vicinity be investigated and intimates that water from such sources would obviate the necessity for the present chlorination and would also permit of leaving the disposal bed in its present condition.

Mr. Hamilton's suggestion with respect to securing a new water supply will be studied on the ground shortly when conditions are more favourable. While it is understood a settler in the vicinity of the school has a water supply from a small spring, yet it would appear improbable that an adequate water supply could be secured in the vicinity, from springs. I know of no institutions or industry in the vicinity obtaining its water supply from wells. However, further inquiries will be made locally concerning the possibility of securing a water supply from such a source.

While the elimination of chlorination is always desirable, yet it might be pointed out that the water in use at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School is not chlorinated to the extent that is necessary with the water supply for the Town of Kenora. Furthermore, I do not believe that the Department of Health of the Province of Ontario would approve of the suggestion that the effluent from the disposal bed be permitted to flow freely into Round Lake as at present, since the overflow from this small lake passes into Lake of the Woods - a short distance away.

Under the circumstances, a new water supply, in all probability, would not eliminate the necessity for overcoming the present condition at the sewage disposal bed.

Yours truly,

Sgd. D. B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer.

All estimates for residential schools now come under the Inspector and not the Indian Agent; all requests received from the Principal have been forwarded to Ottawa.

There is no doubt the recommendations of the Jury are correct, but only a small amount was allowed for the school last year, and nothing could be done with the money available also probably a considerable expense will be necessary to put the sewage disposal bed in shape to function satisfactorily.

Several of the local Indians are going to Winnipeg to see the King and Queen on May 24th, and requests have been made to send the Cecilia Jeffrey School Band there at the same time, but the Welcome Committee have no funds for this, as it would cost at the very least $200.00, and if we paid for this we would also have the other school asking why we would not pay for them.

It is planned to rehabilitate the original bed by digging up the tile to clean them out. The area will be re-graded. Further the plan is to extend the bed to the east a length of 60 feet with 60 feet porous tile lines to in number, making a total porous tile extension of 1200 feet. This with the 1500 feet provided in the original field would make a total of 2700 feet of tile will be in place. It is proposed to lift 1500 feet of tile from the lower bed developed in December 1937, and this would leave 1200 feet in place for use with the laundry waste, if desired.

It will be advisable to place coarse gravel under and around the tile lines to the depth of one foot below grade. Further it is advisable to install end underdrains along the downhill side of the disposal field in a gravel-filled trench and connected to the lower disposal field to provide against water-logging of the entire bed due to the failure of the subgrade to effectively carry off the liquid.

In addition it will be advisable to increase the septic tank capacity and particularly to increase the siphon chamber. In the first case to improve the settlement conditions as the school population has considerably increased since the original plant was built, and in the second case to lengthen the periods between dosing flows discharged by the siphons to the disposal field.

The walls of the inspection man-hole of the original septic tank were reported caving in and it was noticed the timber was rotted and sand filtered in. New walls and covers will be necessary. An additional soil depth of one foot has been built up and a road built over the original tank so that it is advisable a reinforced concrete roof be built to replace the wooden top. The present wood top appears to be overloaded, especially when snow or ice and vehicular traffic over it is considered.

It was obvious the tank was not holding back sufficient of the solids, particularly paper, which tended to block up the disposal bed; the siphon chamber was too small, causing too frequent flow into the bed and the land underlying the bed was not able to absorb sufficient water to prevent water-logging and overflow.

Some remedial methods were needed in the septic tank. First an attempt was made to stop some of the paper by building up a wooden partition on the weir between the main section of the tank and the siphon chamber. Two 4" iron pipes with single elbows were inserted in the partition so that the flow to the siphon chamber came from a depth in the main tank about 3 feet from the floor at the back end. The intention was to stop paper and other light solids which must have previously flowed past the baffle and over the weir.

**Present Conditions**

A series of samples were taken from the siphon chamber during the year's school term and they showed little of the light particles were being discharged from the tank. An inspection was made of the tank effluent and bed on June 4th. A carefully taken sample was secured directly from the outlet pipe of the main tank. Little obnoxious odor was noticeable from this murky pailful of water and only a very limited quantity of particles, about the size of a pinhead, were observed when the pail's contents were stirred up.

The disposal bed appeared to be water-logged, particularly noticeable at the centre where the ground was soggy. Most of the rest of the bed was probably clogged up. A flow of water occurred each time the siphon operated, welled up the surface and flowed away over ground to the southeast. Some of this water was scattered over the hillside, but in wet or winter weather could reach the lake, as the hillside would then have little absorptive capacity.

The laundry waste water is carried by a separate line down past the septic tank and now flows overland on the greased slope 500 feet south from the tank. It includes kitchen-sink drainage. A man-hole on the buried section of this line exists near the southwest corner of the original disposal bed and the water flows out of it at an elevation well above the lower disposal field. In the construction of supply tile line to this bed on December, 1957, a "T" entry was left for connection of the laundry waste in event a grease separation tank or contact bed were built so that the effluent could be disposed of in the disposal field.

Topography of the original and second disposal field was checked over and borings made. This, with test pits made at the site of the lower bed dug just before its development showed that the best absorptive area was located in the original disposal bed area and its vicinity.
MEMORANDUM

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School
Sewage Disposal System.

The sewage disposal system of this school consists of a septic tank with siphon chamber and a disposal bed. Owing to overloading and lack of cleaning out of the tank and disposal bed over a period of 5 years, the system ceased to operate properly.

It was found the tank contained a large accumulation of solids which took up space designed for settlement and digestive action so that passage through the tank of daily flows was unduly speeded up. The consequent passage of solids quickened the accumulation in the disposal field, which clogged up, backed up the flow and stopped intermittent operation of the siphons. Finally an outlet was established from the outer end of the disposal bed and more or less continuous flow from the tank resulted. In November, 1937, it was noticed this flow carried particles about the size and shape of tea leaves, enough to soon block any disposal tile field.

In December, 1937, a new disposal bed was built in a field at a distance of 250 feet southeast of the tank. This location was used as an alternative to cleaning and extending the original bed, which was expected to be water-logged owing to necessary continuous use of the disposal system during mid term of the school. The tank was cleaned out under difficulties of this handicap. It was observed the school sewage filled this tank and siphon chamber in 24 hours.

It was evident by the following spring that there was insufficient absorption obtained in the new disposal area; as the bed overflowed and established a discharge path directly downhill into the adjacent lake. In August, 1938, this washout was stopped by building a clay dyke around the downhill side of the bed and re-leveling the bed. An examination showed that tile had not been dispensed, but nearly one fifth of a complete line of tile was found to be filled with black muck, mostly paper, and the underlying sand appeared to have little absorptive capacity. Where the tiles were lifted out there was no sign of discoloration or silting of the adjacent sand, but a flow of tank water along the open trench filled it to about 3 or 4 inches. After slowly seeping away a thick scum was left on the sand.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Sewage Disposal, Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School.

I have your memorandum of the 24th instant with regard to the above and carrying a copy of a memorandum that you had received from the Acting Director of the Indian Affairs Branch advising that the amount of $400.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school, and requesting a report on conditions of the sewage disposal system.

I may say that we have been in correspondence with Mr. Gow for some months in connection with this matter, and have received a report under cover of a letter from Mr. Gow dated the 1st instant. I am attaching hereto the report accompanying Mr. Gow's letter and prepared by Mr. Rose or Mr. Gow's office. Copy of a blueprint to accompany Mr. Rose's report is also attached.

In his covering letter Mr. Gow states that they have been very busy on work connected with his own Bureau, and so have not been able to prepare detail drawings of the extensions and alterations proposed. However, the preparation of these plans is now under way, and they will be completed as rapidly as Mr. Gow's staff activities will permit.

Mr. Gow states that if any work is to be carried out along the lines suggested in Mr. Rose's report, it is imperative that such work should be done during the holiday season and as soon after July 1st as possible. It will be noted that in this connection, Mr. Rose has estimated the cost of the proposed work at $3,102.00.

From Mr. Rose's history of this sewage disposal system as well as statements of present condition and recommendation with regard to what he thinks should be done, it does not appear to us that the $400.00 available for work this year will be of much use. However, as Mr. Rose is now thoroughly familiar with the whole situation, if the Indian Affairs Branch do not wish to make an expenditure in excess of $400.00 this season, our recommendation would be that the expenditure of this amount be left to the discretion of Mr. Gow as to what work could be undertaken to the best advantage with this limited amount.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,

T.S. Smith

The officials of this Department accept full responsibility for the work undertaken and accomplished and the money necessary for all such projects is transferred from this Branch to the Surveys & Engineering Service from time to time. Dear Sir,

I have just received a letter from Mr. Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora, from which I quote the following -

"Mr. Rose will soon complete his work at the sewage disposal bed, and the tank should be cleaned out. Mr. Byers asks that the Department pay for this. It is a question whether we should do it or the school. Instructions were given Mr. Byers that the tank should be cleaned out at least twice a year but this has not been done and the reason given is that Mr. Davidson, the engineer said it was not necessary. I asked Mr. Byers if the Department's instructions or the School engineer's should be carried out and he had nothing to say. Please let me have instructions as to this."

It is my opinion that the cleaning out of septic tanks should be included in the operating of an Indian Residential School and the expense, if any, borne by the school authorities. On information obtained from Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water and Power Branch, I advised Mr. Byers last spring, in the presence of the Indian Agent, that he should see that the tanks were cleaned out regularly. Apparently this work has not been done.

I would be pleased if the Department would instruct Mr. Byers in this connection, sending a copy of their letter to this office.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School phoned me up about 7 p.m. last night and informed me a bad break had occurred in the main water pipe line from the pump house to the school, and that it must be repaired immediately and that the cost for temporary repair of the line would not cost at the most more than $100.00. He also informed me that the Engineer Mr Rose and the men who were doing the work at the last repair noticed that the pipes were badly pitted.

Mr Eyers informs me Mr Rose said he would make a report as to the state of the pipes.

The distance from the school to the pump house is about 600 feet, and Mr Eyers estimates it would cost in the neighborhood of $200 to do the digging and put in new pipe, but I anticipate it would cost more, particularly as the ground is frozen although it is only sandy soil.

The Principal suggests we should put in a new line and leave the present one as it is.

They are getting some water at the school through the present pipe line but there is considerable leakage and it necessitates much pumping, and of course might fail at any time.

Some saving might be made if no foreman was hired and the work paid for on a day basis, the Principal says he could supervise the work, and I would suggest some of the pupils might do some of the digging, although I am afraid Mr Eyers might not like me suggesting this to him.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions.

Yours very truly,

The following letter has just been received from Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kanora:

"The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School phoned me up about 7 p.m. last night and informed me a bad break had occurred in the main water pipe line from the pump house to the school, and that it must be repaired immediately and that the cost for temporary repair of the line would not cost at the most more than $100.00. He also informed me that the Engineer Mr. Ross and the men who were doing the work at the last repair noticed that the pipes were badly pitted.

Director."

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School with reference to allowing the Public Grocery to use the basement of the old barn at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

From time to time requests reach the Department from outsiders to use buildings situated on residential school property and which are not at the time required for residential school purposes. It has not been our policy to favourably consider such requests as due to present conditions it is felt that it is preferable to reserve buildings located on residential school property for the purpose of the school and thus avoid many complications that might arise if outsiders had free access to Indian residential school property. Consequently you should inform Mr. Byers that the Department is not prepared to give favourable consideration to the request of the Public Grocery.

Dear Sir,

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario.

On April 8th and 9th, I visited the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School near Kenora, to examine the sewage disposal system and make inquiries regarding the water supply pipe line.

The water supply pipe line, 750' in length, consists of 4" wrought iron pipe, laid in the late winter of 1929. At present the line is working satisfactorily, but I am informed that on four or five occasions during the past three years, leaks have occurred and repairs were necessary. One repair job was necessary in the fall of 1939 and the latest in March of this year. In all instances it was found that the pipe had pitted badly and holes had formed through the pipe. As the minimum depth of the line is about 8 feet, the repair work is fairly expensive. It is reasonable to assume that the pitting is occurring throughout the entire line as the breaks have occurred at various locations and that the leakages will occur more frequently unless action is taken to replace the line.

It is recommended that the line be replaced with 4" transite pipe. This line extends only from the pump house to the pressure tank and is entirely separate from the suction line which extends from the pump house about 350 feet into Round Lake. It is not intended to replace this suction line at this time, as there is no evidence of any leakage in it.

In 1929 the cost of this 750' water line was $1,613.00 and this was for labour and material and included no profit for the contractor. The costs for pipe and labour are now slightly lower and the estimated costs of the replacement line are as follows:

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| 750' - 4" transite pipe, F.O.B. site | $600.00 |
| Labour                | $750.00 |
| **Total**             | $1,350.00 |

The pump house is in urgent need of painting and some repairs to roof are required. A sum of $50.00 should be provided for this purpose. I would suggest, therefore, that $1,500.00 be provided to cover replacement of force water main, repair pump house and to meet engineering expenses. The above estimate is based upon the assumption that the work will be done by day labour under the direction of this office.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
I would also urge that $250.00 be provided for the sewage disposal system. We desire to fence off the disposal bed, to protect the bed from natural drainage, to cover the bed with loam and plant grass seed. At present the disposal bed is being used as a playground unless fenced off, protected and provided with surface growth. It will most assuredly deteriorate rapidly and become a failure within eighteen months. Last year, $1,100.00 was provided to repair the disposal bed and septic tank. The work was carried out in the late autumn - the total expenditures being $1,704.82. At that time we gave consideration to fencing and surfacing the bed, but decided it could best be done this spring or early summer. I cannot too strongly recommend that money be made available by June 1st for finishing up this disposal bed.

Yours truly,

Sgd. D.B. Gov.
District Chief Engineer.

Re: Buildings & Equipment.

Dear Sir:

Having completed an inspection of the building and fixtures, I am in a position to report that certain departments are in such bad need of repairs as to endanger the normal life of those parts. After consultation with Capt. Edwards and Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg, it was decided that I should address this to your Department with a respectful request that some provision might be made to supply the materials. We should endeavour to do at least the greater part of the labour.

The entire building is in need of paint. In places the wood has or is rotting from exposure to weather. A professional painter kindly gave us his opinion on each room throughout the building. (This was entirely free of any obligation.)

We could undertake to do the entire inside, and the outside up to the 1st story windows. The eaves and windows of 2nd. storey and attic would require special scantlings, swings, slings etc., and would be too dangerous for boys. This work alone would cost over $200.00, including all materials. The eaves troughs are off entirely in three places.

Mr. Miller, Manager of the Linoleum Department of the Hudson's Bay Co., Winnipeg, while visiting us on holiday, went over our rooms at our request, measuring up the floors for much needed linoleum. He has taken the measurements back to Winnipeg and will work out an estimate on a special reduced rate.

We find that linoleum is essential for the following: Hospital 2 Wards 15' x 13', 1 Hall 17' x 6'.
Hospital - Cont'd.

1 Dispensary 8' 6" x 6'
1 Sunroom 14' x 6'
1 Bathroom 9' x 6'
2 Staff Bathrooms 13' 6" x 6'
1 Staff Dining Room 16' x 13' 6"
(Concrete floor)
1 Residence Kitchen 16' x 13'

The floors need "Lionoil" or some such preservative. We have discovered a 45 gal. drum full of a floor oil, for which a local firm will exchange us Lionoil. This drum has been here, unused, for several years and is of a low grade.

A set of six steps on the Boys' side is almost on the point of collapse. They will not satisfactorily stand repair, but need to be replaced.

The boys have no lockers of any kind in their Playroom, only a common room 18' x 3' lined with rows of Hooks which are at a dangerous height. We can install individual lockers for 75 boys at a cost of under $11.00.

We are in immediate need of 70 mattresses, single hospital type bed. These are essential to replace mattresses worn entirely through the middle from end to end.

We also need for this Fall, bed sheets throughout. We require at least 215 sheets. This means 520 yds. (with app. 2½ yds. to 1 sheet), of unbleached cotton sheeting 5¼ wide in Bolts.

We can find no copies of any requisitions for school supplies etc., for September, and Capt. Edwards has none on his files. Could you please let us know as soon as possible if any have been sent in to your office. If not, we shall fill out your requisition forms immediately.

We do hope that some representative from your office will be able to visit us early this Fall.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Excerpt from Mr. P. Phelan's report to Mr. Hoey, dated Sept. 5, 1940.

5. Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School

Accompanied by Indian Agent Edwards, I visited this school on August 31. The new Principal - Mr. Douglas S. Pitts - met us at the school and accompanied us on inspection of the main building and the outbuildings.

Although Mr. Pitts has only been at the school for the last month, he has effected many necessary improvements. However, it is quite evident that the former principal of this school did not make any determined effort to keep the building in a proper condition. Actually, the Cecilia Jeffrey school is a very substantial building but it certainly has not been properly looked after. For instance, one or two of the boards in the platform at the entrance to the school had broken, and instead of replacing them a piece of tin was nailed over them. This, of course, has rusted and certainly does not present a very good appearance to anyone entering the school for the first time.

I am placing on the Cecilia Jeffrey file a memorandum regarding the expenditures that I authorized, in conformity with your letter to Indian Agent Edwards of August 29th.

The Survey and Engineering Branch have completed the repairs to the sewage system and it is hoped that this will not cause us any further trouble. I impressed on the Indian Agent, Mr. Edwards, and also the Principal the necessity of cleaning out the system at regular intervals each year.

The barns have been very thoroughly cleaned and I authorized the purchase of new lumber to replace the old platform in the cow stable.

Mr. Pitts seems very much interested and is anxious to do as much work as possible without expense to the Department. As you are aware, he has had some years' experience in an Indian residential school and is more or less familiar with conditions. I feel that the Presbyterian Church has made no mistake in engaging him and Indian Agent Edwards is anxious to co-operate with him. I believe that we can expect good results from this school in the future.
Ottawa, September 5, 1940.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Re: CECILIA JEFFREY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on August 30 and, accompanied by Indian Agent Edwards, inspected the main building and all the outbuildings. I had a copy of the Principal's letter dated August 9th and also a copy of Mr. Hoey's letter to Indian Agent Edwards dated August 22nd.

The following expenditures were authorized:

1. Set of six steps for boys' wing.
2. Lumber for lockers in the boys' and girls' play-rooms. The labour for this purpose is being supplied by the school management.
3. Linoleum for infirmary section of the school.
4. Paint to the value of $100. This will be used in the interior of the building. The outside painting will have to receive consideration next year.

In the Principal's letter of August 9 he requested linoleum for several rooms in the building. There is no doubt this is required but it will probably involve a high expenditure. The Principal had not obtained any estimate of the cost of this linoleum and I therefore requested him to obtain estimates and supply these to Indian Agent Edwards, who will forward them to us for our consideration. The Principal also requested 70 mattresses. These are certainly necessary and Indian Agent Edwards will forward information regarding their size.

I intimated to the Principal that it was doubtful if we could even consider supplying the sheets that he requested.

Philip Miller

Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

I sent you a night telegram on the 18th instant, but have received no reply up to time of writing.

The water intake to the school would not function and the Principal had to get a diver, to get at the source of the trouble, which was found to be that owing to the low water in the lake the perforated cap on the intake got plugged up with mud, and nothing would pass through it.

However this has now been cleaned out, and I shall be glad to know if the account is approved, the school is a long way from the lake and the children and staff were kept busy hauling water to the building in pails.

The Principal also informs me he has had to get boiler number 731 electrically welded, as it started to leak all round the seams, one leak being 16 inches long. This boiler appeared alright when the boiler Inspector inspected it last month.

I am asking the Inspector if he is in this vicinity soon if he will inspect it again, as the Principal is afraid it may not stand up, and may have to be replaced.

KENORA, ONT.—September 16th 1940

Captain F. Edwards, Esq.,

Dear Captain Edwards:

At the request of the new Superintendent of the Cecilia Jeffery School I made an inspection of the school and premises on Friday last and as requested by yourself I am submitting a report on same to you.

Two hose reels on the top floor are empty they require each one fifty foot section of one and a half inch linen hose the same as is on the other reels in other parts of the building.

New lock arrangements for the dormitories are contemplated and I would suggest that the arrangements made will enable the pupils to make their exit promptly in case of fire and the old system of keeping the doors locked be done away with.

The door of the furnace room leading into the main building should be regular fire door as it leads into a long narrow passage way which would allow a fire to make a fierce headway whereas a good fire door would prevent this.

There should be sufficient rubber lined firehose kept on the hose reel in the hose shed to enable the employees to be able to combat a fire in any of the outside buildings or the yard; the hose should be kept connected to the hose standard at all times and all this hose should not be used for any other purpose than for fire or for an occasional test.

All the chemical extinguishers should be carefully examined each year.

Respectfully submitted by

Chief Fire Dept.
The Secretary,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;

Enclosed please find letter received from the local Fire Chief re the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. We get the Chief to visit the school annually, and will be again visiting them during fire prevention week, when we have test drills and regular inspections.

In November 1939, the fire Chief recommended we supply two fifty ft lengths of linen hose for inside the school and 500 ft rubber lined for outside. Departmental letter #129-6-5 of December 9th 1939 informed me that the Purchasing Agent was forwarding 500 feet of rubber lined hose to the school, but no mention is made of the linen hose for inside the building.

The Chief now recommends fire doors to the furnace room; this would I agree be a great protection, in case of fire from the boiler room, but the Chief has not recommended this before and in discussing the matter with him and the Principal, I was informed that the insurance rates would be much reduced, if this door was installed. We do not carry insurance but I am told the Church does on their property.

There should be enough hose to reach to the outside buildings with what was supplied last year, I will go into this with the Principal when I next see him.

He has been very much handicapped in starting work at the School as he has not had much co-operation from the late Principal Mr. Byers who is still living in the District.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Principal now informs he can find no trace of the 500 ft of hose, presumed to have been supplied by the purchasing agent in 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Metal Roof over Furnace Room

This roof has been punctured in innumerable places by persons trying to remove ice and snow which have collected during the winter months.

The roof leaks so badly and has done so, for so long, that the boarding underneath has rotted.

Mr. Phelan may remember, on his recent visit here, that I pointed it out to him, and at that time said that we were going to raise the metal roof and place a layer of cheap roofing paper between the boards and the metal roof. However after raising the roof and inspecting beneath, we find the woodwork too far gone. I asked a builder's advice re roofing paper, and he said that he would recommend removing the metal and replacing with a good grade of roofing. He pointed out, that the cuts in the metal would only pierce the roofing paper, and make it useless also.

If you consider this latter course wise, would you authorize the expenditure in time to complete the work before winter sets in? It would require 3; to 4 rolls of roofing or approximately 350 sq. ft. It will also require replacing several boards, about 50 ft. of 6" x 1".

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
