Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School re metal roof over furnace room.

I would suggest we approve the Principal's request as the amount will be very little, and it will prevent further deterioration at least temporarily.

The total cost should not be much more than $15.00 or $20.00 for the necessary roofing and lumber.

I am well aware the Department has notified us that there are no further funds available for this school, but in view of the fact that if this work is done now it will prevent further rotting of the lumber of the roof.

I therefore recommend the expenditure.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards

Dear Mr. Phelan:

At the request of the Board I visited the schools at Kenora and Birtle early in December.

Birtle: There seemed to be good atmosphere here. There has been several changes on the staff. The new teacher, Mr. Candy, is an exceptional young man. His class work I found very satisfactory. He is also taking a keen interest in physical training of boys and girls.

We are considering some gymnasium equipment and would like your opinion as to the use of parallel bars, travelling rings, etc., We could get parallel bars from Harold A. Wilson Co., for about $125.00 and upwards and would like to know whether you consider this a good investment for both schools. Birtle needs equipment for woodwork and I have an estimate for this which we are willing to supply if you think the money would be well spent. The estimate is for about $30.00 plus $25.00 for material.

They also want a movie projector and a movie camera at Birtle. I understand that the 16mm projector can be secured for about $55.00 but the 16mm camera is expensive to buy and also to operate.

Kenora: Mr. and Mrs. Pitts are doing good work. The building has been cleaned up and a good deal of painting done which improves the appearance of the inside. We are giving them a new staff car to replace the old Packard 1926. They are asking for some chairs for the chapel - 60 - an electric washing machine for staff laundry. We are able to supply these requests because we have watched the spending of our grant so carefully.
Mr. Pitts asked that a men teacher be appointed in Miss Wilson's place and Mr. Martin Rusaw has been appointed. His inspectors' reports were very good and he is especially qualified for manual training.

I saw both Mr. Smith and Captain Edwards and they seemed satisfied with conditions in the schools.

The stove at Cecilia Jeffrey School, Kenora, is in very bad condition. The lids are so worn that they fall into the fire, which is very upsetting to the cook. One oven is useless because so much heat is wasted owing to the condition of the top and it is difficult to put on meals for 150 people with such poor equipment. Would it be possible to get a new stove from the Indian Department?

The new furnishings in the residence are very nice and Mr. and Mrs. Pitts are quite comfortable.

I would be glad to have a reply as soon as possible about the stove and your judgment on the gymnasium equipment.

Sincerely yours,

J. Florence Lang
Indians Secretary.
Dear Miss Lang:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant with reference to your recent visit to the Birtle and Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential Schools.

I am very pleased to know that you found everything satisfactory at Birtle and that the new teacher gives promise of being exceptionally capable.

Careful consideration has been given to your suggestion of supplying gymnasium equipment. I really doubt the advisability of doing this and would suggest that its purchase be deferred. I note that Mr. Candy is interested in the physical training of the boys and the girls and I believe that without any expenditure he could follow the syllabus of physical training issued by the Strathcona Trust. If he does this there is no doubt that beneficial results will be obtained. Besides, he could encourage more outside games. After all outside play is preferable to inside play, no matter how good your inside equipment may be. When a few months of physical training as suggested above has been given I would recommend formation of a Boy Scout group and Girl Guide group for the girls. I feel very definitely that such activities would be better for the present and would likely have more lasting value.

Before you incur the expenditure that you mention for woodwork equipment I should appreciate

I have noted your remarks about the stove at the Cecilia Jeffrey School and I am writing to the Agent today requesting definite information regarding the type of stove that would be necessary. If at all possible this will be secured at an early date.

Re: Forced Draft Blower.

Dear Captain Edwards:

We use a tremendous amount of fuel to heat the School Building during the winter months. After trying both coal and wood, and on the advice of several experts, we have found that coal is cheaper. However, we are starting our third car of coal (about 130 tons in all) and find that the fuel bill is a huge part of our expenses.

Most large buildings now use an automatic stoker or a blower. They find that the heat is more easily controlled, that there is less waste, and that a cheaper coal may be used.

We do not wish a stoker, because the art of building and attending a furnace fire is one branch of training for our boys. But, I do think that a forced draft under the grates will give us more actual heat per unit of coal used. At present, the heat very seldom reaches the Residence. When we are able to force the draft, it does so easily.

The Fairbanks-Morse Company Ltd., of Winnipeg has quoted us a price on a small blower, taken from an Apartment Block in Winnipeg. It was replaced by an Automatic Stoker. The price of the blower, equipped with a 1/4 H.P. Motor would be $35.00. A pressure switch to control the fan would cost an additional $11.00. These prices are f.o.b. Winnipeg, all taxes paid.

We could place the blower between the two furnaces, with a butterfly damper on each line to control the flow of air. We could then use one boiler instead of two, except in cases of emergency.

This offer (price) is only for a limited time. If the Department would consider this purchase, it would save us considerably on costs, and would also save on the possibility of repairs to the second furnace which is in rather poor condition.
I hope that you will bring this to the attention of the Department as speedily as possible, and that they will deem it wise to grant this piece of very valuable House Equipment.

Yours Sincerely,

Dear Sir:

The Principia of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School has just rung me up by phone informing me that he wishes to make a trade with a local man for a horse, which he values at $120.00, for the old building that was on the school property when we took it over.

This building is useless for a residence or for any other purposes, except the old material in it, which would only be worth a few dollars to the school.

The local man has offered Mr Pitts to remove the old building, which is an eyesore, and allow him $50 for it. In turn, Mr Pitts will give $50 from school funds and personal funds for the school use, i.e., feed the extra horse.

I would suggest that this offer be accepted, and thank Mr Pitts for his offer.

This letter is being written before receipt of a letter from the Principal, which will be enclosed if received in time for this mail, so it is imperative that a reply be received at once, if the deal is to be concluded.

A reply by air mail will be appreciated,

Frank Edwards

Dear Sir:

(1) Re: Roof over, and repairs to steps.

This is to confirm our conversation of a few days ago.

RE: MOTOR for Return Pump for Furnaces.

Dear Sir:

For some time the motor which is part of the Return Pump unit for our furnaces has been sparking. We had an electrician check it. He said that there was nothing out of the ordinary except that it probably needed cleaning. Soon afterwards, it stopped and we had it fixed, thinking that it was only something that would come under "operational expenses".

As it was summer, we did not have it installed until the last week of August. The wiring, including the armature, burned out. We found then that the bearings were binding.

The electricians and motor experts in Winnipeg said that the motor was wearing out from heavy use.

The motor has to be entirely re-wound, (including armature,) and the bearings must be replaced.

Since the children are now back and we must use the furnace for washing and for laundry, and also for heating the buildings on account of the unseasonable weather, it is absolutely essential that we have the return pump in operation immediately.

Because of its urgency, I have thought it advisable to ask the Electrician to proceed with the necessary work, keeping the price as low as possible. The total expenses will be approximately $75.00

I submit this above information, along with a letter from the electrician, hoping that the Department will agree to the urgency and will see fit to authorize the payment of this account.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Our Hot water tank has sprung a leak. It is one of about 600 gals. with a steam coil inside, through which steam from the boilers heats the water for the school.

Inspector Kelly evidently warned our engineer a few years ago that the boiler might go soon through corrosion.

We sought professional advice and were told of a certain flanged plug, which, it was stated would stop the leak. This may do a temporary job. We will try it to-night.

However we are informing you of this incident because it may mean that the entire inside of the tank is corroded and weak. If it should go, 60 lbs. of hot water might be serious.

Also, our Steam dryer has developed a leak. We think that this may be in one of the tubes at the back which carry the steam (about 90lbs). However we have been unable to get a steam fitter to check this. One will do so to-morrow. If the trouble is serious, I will let you know.

Re: Boiler & Furnace.

Dear Sir:

After considerable delay, I have been able to get an expert boiler maker of The C.P.R. Roundhouse shops to come and look at our boilers.

Mr. A. Favreau, Master Boiler Maker, retired, believes that the boiler is very old and not in sound shape for repair. It could be done, but might take a lot more time than estimated because if some tubes were to be taken out others might be disturbed. His opinion is that, if we let him roll all the tubes, it will help to prolong the life of the boilers, and certainly will not do any harm. His estimate for this is "Less than $45.00, for both boilers." His estimate for the replacing of seven tubes is "at least $150.00, with no guarantee."

The Superintendent of The Roundhouse recommended Mr. Favreau. He has himself inspected the job, with one of his foremen. They say that none of the men still active will do the job, because they do not know how long they may have to be.

If any big job had been undertaken, it should have been done in mild weather. Now we need both boilers. The boilers are such that, even though they may leak, when a hot fire is run on, they "take up" or expand so as to close the leak.

My suggestion to the Department, upon the advice of several experts is:- That we have Mr. Favreau Roll the tubes.
That we have any small Electric welding done.
That if anything serious be needed next year, the Department will realize that it is an accumulation of trouble through the years.
and that we carry on with both boilers for the cold weather.

Yours sincerely,

Principal.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

The welding would cost in the neighbourhood of $5.00 or $10.00 and should any other charges be made the school authorities will take care of this.

RE Plaster, Boys' Washroom.

Dear Capt. Edwards:

Slightly more than a year ago, I found huge chunks of plaster off the wall of the Boys' Washroom. We had the wall plastered (patched). Once again the plaster is off in many places. I am told that the wall was completely replastered about four years ago. It had often been patched before that.

We have discussed this matter with Mr. Lindstrom of Lindstrom & Wilson Ltd. He recommends filling up the holes left from fallen plaster and then covering the wall with a preparation known as "hard wallboard." This substance is very strong and water resistant.

I should like to request that the Department allow us to do this work, and that the Department will pay for this "hard-board." The cost will be:
125 sq. ft. hard-board @ 10¢ $12.50
less any discount.

Our men will do all work, including patching the wall plaster, and painting afterwards.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Roberts:

In accordance with our telephone conversation of a few days ago, I am hereby forwarding to you a request for certain essential repairs and equipment.

The wash-tub in our Steam Laundry Plant has been decaying for some time. The woodwork at both ends and at the bottom has completely gone. We have been repairing it with wedges, cement, tar, etc., but this is no longer practical. We should like to request at least a new outer part for the tub or if this is not practical, a used tub of about our size was advertised for $400.00 in the last copy of the Canadian Laundryman.

Our machine was manufactured by the Canadian Laundry Machinery Company, of Toronto, and is called a Globe Washer. Its serial number is 12577.

We estimate that $400.00 would cover any cost for the Washing Machine.

Our old barn which was the original barn on the property when bought from Long, is still in good shape, except for the foundation on one side. This foundation has cracked along the full length, and is buckling inward. A local contractor has assured us that it ought to be fixed immediately to save the barn, and that it can be fixed by shoring up inside with timbers and building a supporting cement wall against the inward lean. We have the timber, and our men can do the work. We should like to request the amount of $100.00 to cover the cost of approximately 100 bags of cement.

Paint. All buildings are in need of paint.
June 26th, 1942.

Mr. Roberts, Cont'd:

Some are in danger of needing replacement soon, if not protected from the deterioration of weather. We should like to request the purchase of Outside Grey or Red paint up to $100.00 in value. This is an absolute minimum requirement for this year.

In summarising, we hereby make request for:

1. Washing Machine Tub for Laundry. Approx. $400.00
2. Cement for Old Barn $120.00
3. Paint for Outside Buildings $100.00

$600.00

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Principal

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I was sorry to miss the conference in Ottawa but was not able to go. As soon as the report is ready, we shall be glad to have a copy and shall try to carry out any suggestions made.

Mr. Roy Webb, Principal of the Birtle School, had a very serious accident on January 10th. He is in the Winnipeg General Hospital but is making satisfactory progress and I think will be able to return to the School shortly. We did consider sending in an Acting Principal but as Mrs. Webb returned a week ago, and there are four men on the staff, we decided they could manage until Mr. Webb returned.

There are several matters which I would like to talk over with you and, if necessary, I could go to Ottawa later on.

We have been under great expense for railway fares for children from Mistawasis. Mr. Lockhart would go for them and take them home in the school truck but it is out of commission - tires, etc. and I would like to know if you could help us to get an order for tires. The tires of the school car are also in bad shape. We can pay for them, if we can get them.

Mr. Phelan promised us new mattresses for the Cecilia Jeffrey School some time ago. We have not yet received them and the ones in use would certainly not pass the health inspector.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Indians Secretary.

P.S. We have had several reports on the condition of some Indians in the neighborhood of Rocky Mountain House, Alberta, where we have a Church and also a hospital. These are not Treaty Indians but there are a great many children who are growing up without any schooling. Our Church people are very much concerned and are considering some work among these Indians. Would the Department consider helping in any way or is this the responsibility of the Alberta Government?

We are buying a loom for the Mistawasis Reserve out of our own supply money and hope for some good results in craft work there.
Ottawa,
January 29, 1945.

Dear Miss Lang:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, I am sorry that you were unable to attend the recent conference in Ottawa. However, I expect to be at the office steadily during the next few months and will be glad to see you at any time you visit this city.

I note your remarks regarding Mr. Webb, Principal of the Birtle School, and presume from your letter that Mr. Webb will be able to return to duties within a reasonable time.

I understand that reclaimed tires will be on sale almost immediately to those people falling in certain categories. These are four-ply tires and, while not as good as the same tires formerly sold and at the same time slightly more expensive, they will at least serve the purpose for the time being. I feel certain that Indian residential schools come within the category of those entitled to purchase these tires. Application should be made to the Tire National Officer of the Rubber Controller's Office which is a branch of the Department of Industries & Supply. They have representatives in various parts of the Dominion. I feel certain that there is one in Winnipeg and quite possibly closer to Birtle. The Principal of the Birtle School should make application to him for the number of tires he requires and, as stated above, I feel certain that he will be permitted to purchase them.

Replying to Departmental Letter of January 21st - file 129-3-5 - I have to advise the matter of mattresses at the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School has been investigated and it will be absolutely necessary to replace 50 of the old ones. 10 more are in such bad condition they will not last more than a year. Consequently, if possible, I would recommend that 60 new mattresses be obtained for this school.

I do not know whether it is due to age or poor quality of the present mattresses but the filling seems to be without any fibre or length. It is more a case where filled with saw dust or shortly chopped straw. The covering is 1 1/4" on two thicknesses of mattress ticking - with the filling piled up on both sides of him.

I examined these mattresses on January 5th and suggested they experiment by making the filling level and then sewing through from cover to cover in the manner known as 'quilting' but this did not prove satisfactory. The child's weight spreads the threads and the filling works out to the edges just the same.

It is recommended that the best grade possible be purchased. From past experience I am of the opinion there is no economy in purchasing a cheap trade of this type.

The size required is 6' 0" x 4' 0".

C. Roberts,

RE: REFRIGERATION REPAIRS.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith copies of an invoice handed to me by Mr. Art Cheyne.

The large "Walk-in" Kelvinator broke down last winter. It developed a strong leak in the gas line. We called in Mr. Cheyne, expecting only a small job, such as we have taken care of in the past, and paid out of our grand, under "Buildings & Repairs."

I asked Mr. Cheyne for an estimate. He would only give this after he had seen pictures of the faulty part. His estimate was for $44.00. I told him that was out of the question and sent the part into the Kelvinator Company, Winnipeg. They had the job welded, and charged us $42.50.

The part was returned but after assembling was found to be still faulty. Kelvinator of Winnipeg re-welded, without charge.

Mr. Cheyne reassembled the condenser for us. After considerable dissatisfaction we called him in again. This time he repaired and adjusted the line strainer.

After considerable urging, he handed in his Bill in the present form. The amount was higher than originally expected, but probably not in excess for the skilled type of work and the number of trips involved.

However, it was sufficiently high that I would request the Department's earnest consideration in reimbursing the school for this payment. Our cheque was A-259 of June 7th, 1943, for $42.50.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Pumps - Electrical Control

Dear Sir:

With further regard to the trouble and extra labour entailed in operating pumps manually, we found it necessary to arrange with Williams Hardware Co. to proceed with the work, on our responsibility.

The new Control System is known as "A Magnetic Line". It is a very simple, neat, and satisfactory arrangement. It is merely hooked on to our old automatic control, and to the individual pumps. If lightning or some other overload strikes the line, it merely cuts off at the magnetic switch. This replaces the former complicated Compensator box with relays etc., To reset the new system it is only necessary to press a button. The old system required an electrician from town, and these visits were becoming more and more frequent.

We sincerely hope that Ottawa will look favourably on this move because of its necessity.

RE: FURNACE GRATES

Dear Mr. Hoey,

In reply to your wire to Mr. Patterson, the boiler is a Spencer Surface Feed 36 x 24. The grates are marked 9.F.G.6 B. and are 23 inches long with 26 sections to each grate. They are shipped from Penetanguishene, Ont., via Midland.

However these grates were shipped to us and arrived yesterday. Therefore I submit the following information:

In 1941, we had need of a few grates to replace some broken and purchased 5 grates, each 40 lbs. J 1/4 per lb. Total cost about $6.40 per grate.

Because of the type of coal available (clinker forming etc.) we have used our reserve grates, getting them welded until no longer possible to repair them.

In Sept. of this year we decided to purchase 5 more grates and placed the order with William Haws Co. of Kenora, who in turn deal with Marshall-Tello of Winnipeg. After a delay of over a month 5 grates arrived and were too long. I wrote direct to Marshall-Tello and received the following: "In reply to your letter of Oct. 27th, we have been looking into the matter of these grates and find that the correct ones were shipped to you. All our grates are at least 4" difference in length and as the pattern cannot vary at the factory we are under the impression that the grate supports in your boiler must have warped, as all the ones we have in stock do not vary 1/16" in length." Signed F.W. Piper Manager Heating Dept.

In the meantime, and because of this, we were getting anxious. The local welder said nothing more could be done with the old grates and frustrated having the Vulcan Iron Works of Winnipeg cast us new ones, as the foundry of Kenora had recently done. If this were to be done, we felt it wise to get a complete set of ten and two spares for the other boilers, total 12 grates.

On Nov. 15th, I visited Mr. Pipher and explained that these were not the correct ones and that we had purchased some before. (He intimated then that possibly they were from the American plant and that Marshall-Tello Co. owned the Canadian Spencer)

Continued.
Up until this time, we had intended treating this Account as an ordinary School Account (as in 1941.) However from the grates received we could see that the prices had advanced to almost $12.00 per grate and since we would now need at least a set of 10 grates, the cost would be quite high for our supplementary expenses. Therefore on Nov. 23rd, we requested Estimate from Williams Edwe with a view to requesting the payment of this expense by the Department.

Mr. Piper still maintained that his letter of Oct. 29th, was correct, but on my insistence was going to enquire of their factory. He also knew of the urgency of receiving the grates. Therefore, without any further word to me—me to whether the right size could be procured,—he had the twelve grates shipped direct from the Factory. That puts me "on the spot."

Our Engineer has found that these are the correct grates and has already installed 7, in order that we may use this Boiler. He says that there are at least two needed in the other boiler.

I regret this long letter, but hope it clears up the matter.

We have now received 12 grates (correct size) from the Spencer Fdy Co., Ltd., of Penetanguishene, Ontario.

We feel sure that the Department will understand the unusual circumstances which led up to this unusual procedure.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

For several months we have been having trouble with
the 5000 Gal. Typhoon Pumps (Fairbanks-Morse, Canada, Ltd.)

In November we had them overhauled by Machinists at
Stone's Boat Co., Kenora.

Since then, they ran for three months and then trouble
developed! Three check valves had become encrusted with a metallic
residue (like iron rust) from the water and had seized partly open.
One had become worn too badly to have reamed, and we found it necessary
to replace it with a new swing valve. Another cheque which was not
holding, we ground down ourselves until it now works. (On advice of J.
Brown, Plumber.)

On Thurs., March 9th, Number two pump stopped pumping
although apparently operating. We checked it and found one plunger
with threads stripped on both plunger nut and rod sleeve.

I took both pistons in to Stone's Machine shop and was
advised that both were badly worn. With calipers they found that the
rod was worn down 20/1000 of an inch in the centre. This means that
packing & bearing will not hold. They advised getting complete new
Assembly. I ordered these by telephone immediately, because of so
many experiences in the past month of being without water.

As we have already borne considerable of the cost, I hereby
make request that the Department will accept this amount. It will
amount to about $50.00. (Have been unable to get price exactly as yet.)

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Mr. Patterson:

Following our conversation of this morning, I enclose a letter received from Mr. H. Thorne of the Fire-Fighter Sales & Service. I would also refer you to our conversations with the Kenora Fire Chief on this matter.

We had occasion to use three of our School Extinguishers at a recent date. We could see that one of our neighbours was fleeing from fire. We were unable to tell whether it was the house or barn. (Only thirty-five yards away.) With near our men and some six boys we hurried to the scene of the fire, taking three Quick Extinguishers. As the Kenora Fire Brigade were on the scene, we did not use these but left them in the car. Unexpectedly, the well ran dry when the fire was under control. The nearest source was the lake, 300 yards away. While the Firemen were laying line to this the fire gained headway, fanned by wind. It was here that I decided to use our extinguishers, and to considerable advantage, until the water came on again. (One of the three did not function properly having become blocked. This one had been at the fire-hall recently to be checked.)

We feel the such neighbourly action is fully justified, as we have often received neighbourly help from others, and would receive such help again, should the school face such an emergency.

As you have had considerable experience with these extinguishers, we should like to leave any recommendations to the Department with you, and possibly we can arrange to work in conjunction with St. Mary's School. However, we have had to order refills for our old extinguishers, to avoid being caught without any protection.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sirs:

Re Fire Extinguishers

Regarding your 3 fire extinguishers which I checked at the Fire Hall, I regret that it will not be possible to procure the original type Karboloy recharge with metal acid bottle. These Thermoxo extinguishers were developed about 1927 and used a chlorosulphonic acid to provide the necessary reaction to expel the Karboloy inside stream Type Charge. The acid was placed in a sealed metal container but very often corrosion from the container in acid bottle holder making it difficult to inspect the unit or ascertain its further usefulness.

An improvement was made several years ago by using a CO2 Cartridge for the expelling agent and provision was made to convert the older machines when recharges were needed. The loaded steel charge Karboloy does not deteriorate and the CO2 Cartridge should be inspected and weighed yearly. Unless it shows 10% or more loss in weight the cartridge is still efficient. In many cases this cartridge lasts several years or more making it more reliable and economical.

In making the above conversion some new parts are required for the cap, also a new type cartridge holder & cartridge. With the suggested change your extinguishers should give many years of service. Incidentally they are considered the most effective turn-over extinguisher on the market, being credited by the underwriters for A and B type fires. The complete conversion recharge sells at $11.50 F.O.B. Hamilton, Ont., and consists of Karboloy, parts for ext. Cap, Cartridge Holder and Cartridge. Allowances of $2.50 are made on returned cartridges for future refills.

Trusting I have explained the matter to your satisfaction and thanking you for your refill and conversion order on which I have requested rush shipment; I remain,

Yours very truly,
Fyr-Fyter Sales & Service
Distributor
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept't of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Re Fire Protection, I.R.Schools.

During my last inspection of the Indian Residential Schools on April 26th and 27th, the fire equipment was inspected and it was noted that the 2½ gallon Fire Extinguishers were of the old type and several had been used and not refilled owing to the difficulty in procuring refills for this particular type.

The schools have at present the following number and type of extinguishers:

- St. Mary's I.R.School:
  - 2 Thermene Soda & Acid Old Type 2½ Gal. - Filled & in use.
  - 2 Ditto - Empty to be filled.

- Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School:
  - 1 Guardene - New Type - Filled & in use.
  - 3 Ditto - Empty to be filled.

It will be noted there are two Thermene Extinguishers empty. These cannot be refilled with original type of refills and can only be made serviceable by being converted to take later type of refills or recharge. This costs approximately $11.50 each, whereas a new Extinguisher of the Pyrene or Guardene type would cost around $25.75 and can be refilled for .75 cents.

There are no extinguishers in the barn or Staff House, which should have some protection, especially in the summer.

Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School:
- 7 Thermene Soda & Acid Old Type 2½ Gal. - Filled & in use.
- 3 Ditto - Empty to be filled.

Three more extinguishers are required. One in the basement hallway and two in the top floor corridor.

It appears to me that these Old Type Thermene Extinguishers could be replaced, at considerable less cost, when found necessary to have present ones converted and recharged. In doing so both schools would have similar and standardized equipment.

I would therefore recommend that authority be granted to purchase the following when it is found necessary, after being used, instead of converting and recharging these old type Thermene Fire Extinguishers:

For St. Mary's I.R.School:
- 4 Pyrene Acid & Soda 2½ Gal. fire extinguishers.
- 2 Ditto - One for barn and one for Staff House.

For Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School:
- 7 Pyrene Acid & Soda 2½ Gal. fire extinguishers.
- 3 Ditto - One for basement hallway.
- 2 Ditto - Two for top floor corridor.

Correspondence leading up to this inspection is herewith attached. I might also add that the Kenora Fire Chief strongly advises this change. The foregoing is submitted for your information and consideration.

Norman Selwyn
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

RE: BOILER.

For several years we have mentioned the condition of the Heating System in use in our school, with a view to keeping the Department informed of the necessity of replacing the system soon. (Mentioned in Annual Estimates). The point has now been reached when we feel it necessary to make the request for a new boiler.

The present equipment consists of two Spencer surface feed boilers, purchased, we believe, when the school was built. This would make them 15 years old. Furthermore, experts whom we have asked to look them over have given their opinion that the boilers are of too small capacity. (We are told that each was intended to care for approximately 3,000 feet Radiation, making a total maximum of 6,000 feet Radiation.) From the enclosed diagram you will see that our building is rated between 7,000 and 8,000 feet. This difference is probably accounted for by the fact that formerly there was a jacket heater to take care of the Domestic Hot Water tank which is rated approximately 1,500 feet of Radiation.

All advice we have been able to get, points to the use of one boiler to take care of the whole system. We propose to retain the better of the two old boilers as a standby and for change over in mild weather.

We would like to point out that we are using about three cars of coal and about 120 cords of wood on the average each year. (During the winter 1942-43, we purchased five cars of coal). Even with such consumption, it is always difficult to properly heat all of the building. The reason for this appears to be present inefficiency of the worn out boiler, and deterioration of insulation on the boiler.

I submit the following report on the Cecilia Jeffery School, inspected April 26th, 1945.

The building was clean and the dormitories tidy and well aired. There are no drinking fountains in the dormitories and I would recommend that these be installed.

The steps from the basement to the first floor on both sides of the building should be renewed. They are about worn through and unsafe.

The galvanized urinals are in bad condition and should be replaced with a two-stall vitreous china urinal. They will cost about $150.00 plus the labor for installing. These are badly needed and when installed will make it easier to keep the room fresh and clean and eliminate largely the existing offensive odor.

The chlorinator appears to be working well and with careful supervision should render efficient service.

I understand a new furnace has been ordered and it is expected to arrive any time.

The roof leaks in a couple of places and should be repaired. It is a tin roof and the tin may be cracked or it may be leaking around the mail heads and troughing will be required to do the work. The gutter troughing is also badly in need of repairing. On the north side in the winter ice accumulates on the roof and when it melts and loosens from the tin it crashes to the ground and carries large pieces of the eaves troughing with it. If it is possible to do anything to prevent the accumulation of ice on the north of the roof, it should be done, because it is destructive and dangerous to anyone passing below.

Folding chairs are used in the chapel and there appears
quite a shortage. Mr. Pitts states he has had a number repaired but some were past repairing and had to be discarded. I would recommend they be supplied with forty new chairs.

Dear Sir,

With reference to our discussion of the icing conditions at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, our suggestion to relieve would be to insulate the main part of the building as well as the dormitories with a three inch layer of Vermiculite Insulation.

This could be done quite easily except for the steep parts off the wall plates which are inaccessible. These we propose to neglect.

While it would be desirable to do these as well, we do not anticipate much trouble from these because of their steep angle which means that the heat pressure against these points would not be nearly as great as in the case of the horizontal ceiling. Opening up these points to allow insulation would be a costly undertaking because of the limited working space. Also some of the structural members would have to be cut which would seem undesirable.

The above proposal may not entirely cure the icing but it would undoubtedly relieve it to a great extent, because obviously if the heat is not allowed to reach the roof boards from below, the only heat which would melt the ice would be that from the sun outside.

Also, aside from reducing the icing, most of the heat would be kept below the ceiling, and thus a considerable annual saving of fuel should be effected.

Our estimated cost of this as outlined above would be Six Hundred and Sixty-Five Dollars, ($665.00).

Hoping the above proposal will be considered, and to have the pleasure of serving you in this matter, we remain,

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: Danger of Ice on Roof.

The following is for your information and for the information of the Department through you.

Several times we have pointed out this danger to yourself and any other visiting officials. We hope that some action may be taken before some serious injury is caused. The danger is passed for this year, but it seems that plans should be made to prevent a repetition this next year.

This morning, at approximately 11:15 p.m., a slide of accumulated ice was released from the roof of the school without any warning. One of our men was working at a distance of 16 feet out from the side of the building. A large chunk of ice, approx. 5 ft. x 4 ft. x 6 inches, just grazed his leg, knocking him over, but not injuring him. (The school children had just crossed this spot, returning from recess.) The chunk of ice would weigh approx. 250 - 300 lbs.

This also concerns the new eves-troughing so urgently required. The above mentioned chunk of ice tore off a piece of the eves-trough, 21 feet long.

CAUSE: The condition is probably caused by the snow melting on the metal (galvanized iron-sino) roof. It appears that the snow melts from either waste internal heat or sun's heat. When the water reaches the outer and lower two feet of roof (unheated) it freezes and "builds up". Then, in the spring or during a thaw, this unheated roof becomes warm enough to melt and release this load.

REMEDY: The experts differ. It is a difficult problem. Lindstrom & Nilson Ltd., Contractors, believe that insulation will help. Hence our requisition last year for Insulation, Value $500.00. A very strong Eves-trough, with some form of Grid to retain ice on the roof until it melts has been used on some buildings. (Another idea, which is impractical, is to put steam heating pipes under Eves.)

Yours sincerely,

During the progress of work associated with the installation of new heating equipment at the school, the Principal without reference to any Departmental officer, made personal arrangements with subcontractors of the Vulcan Iron Works Ltd., engaged on the project to have extra work carried out, which was not covered by the contract. Our Winnipeg officer who has been in charge of the work has been instructed to investigate these items and report on them to this office.

DEAR SIR:

RE: "OLD BARN" - Large Original Barn,
South Side of Round Lake.

The above named barn was on the property when purchased for the new Cecilia Jeffrey School. It measures approximately 110 ft. long, 40 ft. wide, and the loft is about 30 ft. from floor to ceiling. On the north side of Barn, there are two runways into the loft, each built up of solid earth. At these runways, (and more especially between the two) there is a downward slope to barn foundation.

This foundation, north side has developed a long crack, extending about five feet up from floor, for the full length of main stable (horizontally), about 60 feet.

The whole building is beginning to shift away from this broken wall.

The foundation is of concrete, about 12" thick, but is not solid nor reinforced. A rather too generous mixture of stone was added within the concrete forms.

In 1942, we asked for, and received from the Department 100 Bags of Cement to correct the above noted condition. At that time we had an Engineer a man who claimed to be fairly expert at cement work and felt that with the cement, he could correct the condition. He left our employ soon afterwards. Then labour shortages became worse. The foundation break grew larger. We were unable to secure anyone to undertake the work. In the meantime, the company selling the cement was anxious for us to remove it from their warehouse. As cement will not keep indefinitely and we had several small jobs to do around the building, We used the cement hoping to purchase enough to replace that used, when we could start on the job.

The cement used was to put a concrete floor in the Piggery, in one half of the implement shed, in our blacksmith shop, and other odd improvements about the building.
I regret very much that due to the circumstances here mentioned, the concrete was not used for purpose it was given. However, I feel that it was impossible to carry out the first plan, and also feel that cement has been used in such a manner as to improve the property. None was wasted. We still have about 15 bags, all of which we could still use to improve the School.

We now draw to your attention the need for speedy action to prevent the collapse of the foundation Wall.

I called in Mr. Geo. Kimberley, local Concrete Contractor for expert advice. His opinion is that the condition is getting worse every year and this year is at a critical stage. He advised that it should be "shored up" with timber to help take some of the strain off the other walls. He pointed out that the cement work was done by small amounts pouring a small amount at a time and using smooth rock for "fill" and also reinforcing (and even large windows etc.) without having used reinforcing. His estimate of the cost of repairing the wall would consist of:

- Excavating earth from outside of Wall,
- Shoring up floor to take strain,
- Removing old wall entirely,
- Building new wall.

Estimated cost for above, between $200.00 and $200.00. However, his costs appear high, (as he had offered to excavate earth and assist with labour). He is not very anxious to do the job, because of other work.

I hereby make the request that this matter receive consideration as soon as possible. We would recommend that Mr. Gow of the Engineering Branch in Winnipeg, be consulted and asked to make a survey. (We have already mentioned this matter to Mr. Gow, Inspector Hamilton, and Mr. N.Paterson.) We feel that this is too large a job for us to tackle under present conditions, but would be willing to assist with labour.

The barn is valuable to the school as a storage for hay, shelter for cattle, and temporary quarters for teams. The rest of the building is in fairly good condition. The shingles were replaced a few years ago. (However the floor needs re-planking.)

Yours very truly,

Mr. Norman Patterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont., has just forwarded to us a communication he has received from Mr. R. G. Pitts, Principal of the above-mentioned Residential School. There is a barn on the school property, measuring approximately 110 ft. by 40 ft., by 30 ft.

The foundation on the north side of the building has developed a long crack extending about 5 ft. from the floor for the full length of the stable, about 60 ft.

Mr. George Kimberley, a local contractor, states that the following repairs are necessary:

The floor in the children's dining room is made from a bulk asphalt mixture. It is continually being scrubbed and yet never appears clean. New steps are being installed from the first floor to the basement on both the boys and girls side of the building. These stairs could also be covered with linoleum. These stairs are constantly in use and difficult to keep clean. The covering will lighten the work and increase the life of the stair treads. Memorandum:

Re: Barn at Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School,
Kenora, Ontario

On receipt of a report from Mr. Gow in connection with his recent inspection of the above, in accordance with the request in Mr. Howey's memorandum to you of February 4th last.

Mr. Gow's report may be briefly summarized as follows:

The barn in question was standing on the property when it was purchased as the site of the Indian School eighteen years ago. It was an old structure which had evidently deteriorated considerably since that time. It shelters no live stock but is used for the storing of hay grown on adjacent rented farms and has no buildings.

The barn appears to have been set in a side hill cut, and the concrete lower walls, not having been designed as retaining walls, and having no reinforcement, have been unable to withstand earth pressures and are badly fractured. Movements caused by these fractures have tilted the superstructure to the extent that it might collapse during a bad storm.

To put the building in a safe and useful condition would involve extensive operations including the removal of the earthen banks, jacking up the superstructure, removing the fill behind most of the separate walls, lowering the superstructure into position with the attendant bracing and straightening that would be required. Mr. Gow estimates these operations would cost at least $2000.

Since the building is only used for hay storage, Mr. Gow suggests the alternative of removing the earthen banks on three sides of the building to the level of the former stable floor, demolishing the lower concrete walls, and raising the superstructure to the former stable floor level. Attention on this alternative would be bracing and straightening operations. The cost of this alternative is estimated by Mr. Gow to be approximately $1500.

Mr. Gow states that in his opinion expenditures ranging from $1500 to $2000 are not justified, and recommends that the old building should be demolished, salvaging any material that appears to have any value. We concur in this recommendation.

It appears however that the school principal maintains some provision must be made for the storage of hay. Mr. Gow advises that in the event that Indian Affairs should decide to use the alternative of lowering the superstructure to the former stable level, he will contact Kenora firms and obtain confirmation of his estimate. He will also obtain prices for complete demolition. These prices are to be forwarded here for consideration when received.

It is our opinion that the building has outlived its usefulness, and does not merit any expenditure. If hay storage in a building is required, a new hay barn should be provided.

(Sgd.) T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

J. M. Hardie, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

Re: Sewage Disposal, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario.

The following report has been received from Mr. Gow in connection with the above matter under date of May 6th:

"Recently I examined the site of the sewage disposal bed at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario. There has been overflow from the disposal bed for two or three years past and at the present time it is probable that none of the effluent from the septic tank is being absorbed through the tile distribution system. Some few months ago the Principal had a number of tile removed from a section of the bed where the liquid was being freely discharged to the surface and a sump 6 feet deep was dug at this point and partially filled with stone. For while this sump took care of the overflow from the bed but now there is considerable overflow from the sump. An examination of the tile removed shows them to be completely filled with solid matter and an examination of the solid matter shows it to be solids from the septic tank.

"The Principal of the School advises that the septic tank has been cleaned out only once or twice since he arrived there six years ago. In this connection he explains that it has been impossible to get men to do such work. They threaten to quit his employ rather than do such work and it has not been possible to get men from an outside source to do such work either. Such being the case it is not surprising that the distribution tile in the bed is not now functioning.

"Upon looking through our file, it is noted that there has been considerable correspondence with your office in connection with the sewage disposal system at this school and also that a considerable amount of money has been expended in connection with the same. The site of the disposal bed is now fenced off; it is not immediately by the tile and there has been sufficient attention paid to the bed to permit of a very good growth of grass; there has been no neglect in this respect. The bed was relaid in 1935 and at the present time is wholly ineffective. I do not see any alternative to the relaying of the tile during the coming vacation period and the matter is now being brought to your attention."

The matter of sewage disposal for this school came up in 1937 and again in 1939 when an extension to the old 1926 installation was made. The proposed work received serious consideration in 1939 before the extension was carried out.

We have asked Mr. Gow for an estimate of cost of his present proposals. Sprinkler treatment of the tank effluent was considered in 1939 but not adopted.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,

Re: Sewage Disposal - Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario

Further to our memorandum of May 18th and with reference to the verbal request of Mr. Prouder we are now in receipt of a further report from Mr. Gow respecting the above matter. This report, dated July 23rd reads as follows:

"We have for attention your letter of July 6th in connection with the above mentioned subject and asking for an estimate of the cost of reconstruction of the disposal bed.

"Our letter of May 6th outlined the situation with respect to the condition of the tile bed and the septic tank. We appreciate the position of the Principal of the school with respect to the cleaning out of the septic tank, but unless a septic tank is cleaned of solid matter at least twice yearly, a disposal bed will rapidly become ineffective.

"The leakage from the disposal bed is disagreeable and offensive, but it disappears in the land before reaching Round Lake, the source of the water supply, and thus does not contaminate the water supply or cause annoyance or damage to other than the school property and management. We realize that it would be difficult to get labor to dig up, clean and replace the tile and unless some definite action is taken to clean the septic tank frequently replacement of the bed will only be a very temporary improvement. We suggest that conditions be allowed to rest for another year in the hope that the labor situation will improve."

We are in agreement with Mr. Gow that the work of cleaning the tile would only result in a very temporary improvement in the situation if the cleaning of solids out of the septic tank continues to be neglected.

As there appears to be a shortage of labour we must concur in Mr. Gow's recommendation to postpone action for another year in regard to the replacement or cleaning of the tile and disposal bed but suggest that Indian Affairs arrange for the cleaning of the septic tank as soon as possible. After the solids have been removed from the tank flushing of the disposal system with clean water might put it into shape for satisfactory operation until next year.

After considerable trouble in locating anyone who would tackle this job of cleaning septic tank, I located Chan. Ratchford, Kenora. (Kenora's sewage men would not touch it.) His letter covering this subject is attached (copy).

Six years ago, while we were cleaning this septic tank, the health inspector from Toronto, (checking Chlorine system in drinking water,) watched our men working. He said that we were doing the wrong thing—that we should not touch the septic tank as this would disturb the bacterial action.

To prevent any "foreign matter" from entering the tank (that is other than sewage, and which would not deteriorate with normal bacterial action,) we have a screen before entrance to tank. We clean this once each week while school is in session.

As noted in your letter, it is practically impossible to get men to do this work. When asked our own men to do it, even with a considerable bonus, they told me they would quit first.

Dr. Ferguson, Health Officer and our own doctor, and I have often examined the disposal bed. It has always been our opinion that the tiles were bound to fill up with silt in a bed of such fine sand. There should have been coarse gravel, for example, around tiles.

I feel that some further investigation of this matter should be made, possibly by some independent sanitary engineer. The Septic tank appears to be operating O.K., it is the disposal field which is at fault.

Att'd Copy, N. Ratchford.

Yours sincerely,

Aug. 16th, 1946

Mr. D.S. Pitts
Cecilia Jeffrey School
KENORA, Ontario,

Dear Sir:

I have examined the sewage disposal plant at your school.

Regarding your proposal to pump out and clean the septic tank, this can be done. The cost, including a power pump and tank work, would be around $150.00. However, this proposed cleaning of the tank would not get any place, as your trouble is not in the tank but in the disposal field. This field, as you can see by the cemetiles that have been taken up, are full, not of sludge or anything that has gone through the septic tank, but of fine sand of which the field where the tile bed lies is made up. The above conditions will not allow the siphons in the tanks to operate. Then of course you have no septic tank, or no sewage disposal plant. What you would have to do is introduce some wider drainage in your present location. This will give seepage tile, bring in some good clean gravel and make a new disposal field. If this work is done as it should be, you will have no more sewage troubles. If you try to get by with tank cleaning, flushing or other repairs, I would say you are just looking for trouble. To do this job as it should be done would cost around $2,500.00. As the summer season is now well on its way, you should have to make a start very soon to have the work done before freeze-up.

Yours Truly,

SIGNED

Chas. Ratchford

MEMORANDUM:

October 5th, 1946.

Re: Sewage Disposal, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

Referring to your notation on a copy of a memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs dated August 29th, we are now in receipt of the following from Mr. Gov, under date of September 27th:

"We have for attention your letter of September 6th with enclosures relating to the above mentioned subject. We have noted the report by Mr. Pitts, Principal of the School, and also the letter of Mr. Charles Batchford outlining his viewpoint.

Under date of February 13, 1938, a member of your staff furnished you with a summary of the history of the sewage disposal system at this school up to that date. Upon being supplied with a copy of this summary, we wrote you under date of March 16, 1938 with respect to the matter. Since that time considerable money has been spent on the project and the correspondence file will reveal that the operation of the system has not been very successful. The file shows that late in 1938 this building had the septic tank thoroughly cleaned and enlarged, while the disposal bed was dug up, leveled off, the tile laid and the bed considerably enlarged. Some 30 tons of gravel were used in providing under-drainage for the tile and all tile joints were covered with tar paper. The rebuilding of the disposal bed was carefully undertaken and carried out in a very efficient manner. In the following year the whole area was fenced off and the top surface intermixed with black soil hauled to the site so as to provide a better mixture for the growth of grass. However, Mr. Pitts writes under date of August 16, 1946 that six years previously, or in 1940 when cleaning the septic tank, a Health Inspector advised against such cleaning and it is our understanding that this septic tank has not been cleaned out since that date. The position of the Principal of the School can quite readily be appreciated as Mr. Pitts has earnestly endeavored to have the tank cleaned out periodically but he was never supplied with any sludge pump or tank that would have rendered the work less objectionable. However, no disposal bed will indefinitely absorb solid matter without being completely plugged. The writer and other engineers from this office have made several examinations of plugged tiles removed from the disposal bed during the past year and they contained mostly solids passed on from the septic tank. I think it can be confidently stated that the rehabilitation of the sewage disposal system was efficiently carried out late in 1938 and early in 1940 and it is unfortunate that the war prevented proper attention being given to measures considered necessary to ensure proper operation of the sewage disposal system.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario."
The situation at the school now is that both septic tank and disposal bed are plugged and as Mr. Batchford pointed out, cleaning of the tank will not overcome the difficulty. The disposal bed must be relaid. Last week, I had our Resident Engineer, Mr. Galloway at Keewatin, visit the school, with reference to reported further difficulty being experienced in connection with the sewage disposal system. The following is quoted from Mr. Galloway's report:

"The sewage backed up from the disposal bed into the siphon manhole boxes, the manhole boxes of the septic tank, screen boxes and back into the drain hole of the basement under that part of the building in which the Principal resides. About 80 feet or so from the siphon boxes, Mr. Pitts dug a ditch in the disposal bed down to the tile, then broke the tile allowing the sewage in the ditch to release itself back to normal conditions. The ditch is now full of sewage water and running over like a spring on top of the disposal bed from where the tile was broken. Mr. Pitts is of the opinion that the tile system in the disposal bed is plugged with fine sand of which the bed is made up and is afraid that it will freeze up during the cold weather this winter."

With reference to the letter of Mr. Charles Batchford, I might say that I do not believe he professes to be an authority on the construction of disposal beds and insofar as our records show, he was never engaged on any work under our direction and so is not familiar with the method of construction used in the existing disposal bed. The above statement is not to be construed as any criticism of Mr. Batchford who I believe is quite an efficient and successful plumbing and heating contractor.

As for the statement of the Principal of the School, Mr. Pitts, I might say that he was not Principal at this Institution when the existing disposal bed was constructed and accordingly is not necessarily fully informed as to its construction. He became Principal in 1940 and co-operated whole-heartedly with our Bureau in the fencing and seeding to grass of the area used in construction of the disposal bed. In connection with his suggestion that the matter of sewage disposal at the school should be investigated by some independent Sanitary Engineer, I can only say that we would welcome any such move.

It would appear that Mr. Gow is correct in his statement that the disposal bed must be relaid and while we hoped by cleaning the tank and flushing the tile to postpone this work till next year, it would now seem necessary to relay the disposal bed at once, if the necessary material and labour can be obtained.

It should be remembered that a new disposal field alone will not necessarily solve the difficulties, as if the septic tank is allowed to fill up with sludge, thus leaving no room in the tank for septic action, the unsatisfactory condition of the disposal field is apt to occur once again.

Chief Engineer,
November 6th, 1946.

To: SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM, OCEILLA JEFFREY
INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - RENORLA, ONTARIO.

Further to our memorandum of October 6th, we are now in receipt of additional information regarding the above from Mr. Cox, under date of October 25th, as follows:

"This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of Oct. 25th with reference to the above mentioned subject and asking for certain data with respect to the needs of the school as regards water supply and also our suggestions as to the replacement of the present sewage disposal system.

Since the receipt of your communication, we have had a visit from Dr. Pitts, the Principal of the school, and he exhibited the recent trouble experienced with the sewage backing up from the bed into the septic tank and then into the basement of the school. This backing up was released by breaking of the main distribution line of the diamond bed so that new the effluent from the tank would flow freely over the ground and disappear before reaching Round Lake, the source of the water supply. Dr. Pitts fears that with cold weather the ground will freeze and cause considerable flooding of the area in the vicinity of the diamond bed. However, he is of the opinion that even without the present winter with the present system provided, the anticipated freezing does not occur. The writer seconded the impression of Dr. Pitts that I visited the institution before freeze-up, however the situation and underscored to have some protection provided in the nature of straw or hay covering in order to prevent freezing.

"It is our intention to supply you with full details and drawings of the present septic tank as constructed, the separate lavatory drain and details of the existing disposal bed. We will at the same time outline the proposals for the reconstruction of the bed, presumably upon its present location, and will endeavor to give an estimate of cost within which the work could be carried out.

"Upon the occasion of his visit to the school, Mr. Pitts said that the daily use of water at the Institution should average 30,000 gal. per day. This estimate is based upon the operation of the pumps supplying the water, and in my opinion, such a use of water appears to be unusual in connection with an Indian School and can be partially explained by the obsolete system of toilets installed in the school. In any event, such a quantity of water is a heavy load on any sewage disposal system and must either be provided for or the use of water curtailed.

It will thus be seen that the Principal of the school and Mr. Cox are trying to provide protection for the system so that renewal can be deferred until next year. It is most probably too late now to be in renewal operation during the present year and so we must hope that Dr. Cox will be able to utilize a procedure during his projected visit to the school for a short period.

We have requested Mr. Cox to investigate conditions so that full information should be available when renewal of the disposal system is finally undertaken.

J. H. Wardle, Engr., Director,

Dear Col. Henry:

RE: DRAFT—Purchase of War Assets Corp. Truck.

Since receipt of your prompt wire offering us a 50% Grant in aid of purchase of Truck, and letter covering the same, several developments took place.

(1) War Assets wired us to cancel their offer for Chevy Truck as quoted to you in my letter, since it had already been sold. They offered instead a heavier, less suitable truck (Dodge, dual wheels.)

(2) By the time we forwarded your offer to our W.A.C., and then altered the whole picture with the new offer from W.A.C., we found that our own W.I.S. are very short of funds. They tell us that we are already over our limit for Equipment etc. Therefore there is no likelihood of their giving us anything from the Grant.

(3) Therefore, regretfully, we shall have to drop this project for the present. I am particularly sorry after all your recent efforts in our behalf with W.A.C.

(If there had been any way that I could have personally bought the 1943 Jeep for $340, you can be sure that I would have done so.)

You may remember, during my visit to the Department at Ottawa during the month of July last year, the above matter was among the various things discussed.

The floor in the cullery needs resurfacing. It is broken in several places and difficult to keep clean. The cullery sink and drain boards are badly rotted and should be replaced with a new unit. I trust the above recommendations will receive favourable consideration.

The high pressure boiler is located in the laundry and I understand is looked after by the laundry Matron. Thus, I would consider the engineers work. The engineer holds no papers for operating a steam boiler so he is merely a fireman for the low pressure boiler. The machinery and boilers are all government property and I believe it would be good business to assist in paying the salaries to all schools who will employ qualified engineers. The men should at least hold 3rd class papers.
The girls playroom is in the basement. The floor is cement, covered with black Mulsomastic finish which is difficult to keep clean and which, with all the scrubbing, appears dirty. I would require 1300 sq. ft. of Double "A" Battleship Linoleum to cover this floor and I know of no better covering to relieve a lot of hard labor. The Double "A" quality Brown Battleship Linoleum comes in rolls 6 feet wide and 30 yards long. It will require 25 rolls to cover the playroom and the hall leading to the room. I recommend that it be supplied.

Mr. Pitts is well pleased with the new low pressure boiler and reports no difficulty experienced in heating the building in spite of the extreme cold weather.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

I have had Mr. T. Crowley go over the suggested work of putting Hard Board around Children's Dining Room. (The contractors, Lindstrom & Wilson are too busy.) M. Olson of Refrigeration & Repair was called to replace a leak in one of the pipes containing gas on the refrigerator yesterday morning. He is to forward an estimate in triplicate on the cost of this immediately. (I would refer you to our letter to you of Aug. 3rd, 1946). This was also included in our Estimates for 1947-48.

REFRIGERATOR.

I would like to see this floor covered with a good grade Battleship Linoleum. The floor would have to be leveled first, and then waterproof linoleum could be used. This method has proved satisfactory in the cement which we used under linoleum at doors of scullery. We would like to recommend this linoleum. Replacing the old mulsomastic would only result in the same condition.

No mention was made by Mr. Hamilton of the condition of the Dishwashing Unit in the Scullery, although he noted that it was worn out. The Dietician who visited reported that this Unit needed to be replaced. Also recommended was a Potato Peeler.

HIGH PRESSURE BOILER IN LAUNDRY.

We have drawn this to the attention of every visiting official. The Boiler Inspector notes it on each Inspection. The engineer does attend to the cleaning and maintenance of boiler, but sundry Matron fires it herself.
Mr. J. Paterson,

Re letter from Col. Henry.

The Boiler is situated in the Laundry instead of in the Furnace Room. When the New Heating Boiler was installed two years ago, we consulted the Engineer on the possibility of putting the High Pressure Boiler in the Furnace Room—and also hooking it onto the Hot water tank. He considered it a good idea but after careful measurements found that the drop would not be sufficient for the Steam.

The Laundry Matron prefers it this way now—

1. She understands the Boiler,
2. She is not dependent on another member of Staff when she needs steam,
3. The heat from H.P. Boiler makes the drying of clothes possible in the Winter time. (When clothes hung on lines in Laundry.)

The Matter could be easily arranged so that the H.P. Boiler could be in part of the "Tank Room" which joins the Boiler Room, by taking out Wall of Tank Room and extending it about 7' to West, and covering in the added portion. In this new small building of about 7'x10' could be moved the H.P.BOILER (Move Boiler north about 6'). The foundation wall could be left in place as a protection should the H.P. Boiler ever explode.

RE: DISPOSAL BED

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Several times lately I have mentioned in conversation the serious condition of the water from the sewage disposal bed flowing on top of the surface.

This creates a serious condition which may lead to an epidemic of Typhoid or Dysentery.

Through considerable correspondence in the past, the matter was drawn to the attention of the Department. The fact is that the tiles (weeping tiles) have become filled with the fine sand silt and refuse from the septic tank and these tiles no longer will carry water.

From expert advice which we have obtained, it is obvious that HEAVY GRAVEL is needed in addition to the sandy ground. This job should be undertaken this summer while the children are away for holiday.

We request that you will forward this letter to the department with the urgent request that they will give it the consideration due such an emergency. (I would suggest that possibly the Provincial department of Highways might assist in the filling of gravel, trucks, men, and bulldozer, if asked to do so.)

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

Mr. D. B. Gow

Rev.- Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario - Septic Tank and Sewage Disposal Bed.

In connection with the rehabilitation of the sewage disposal system at the above mentioned school, I took over supervision from Mr. J. T. Ross on the afternoon of Friday, August 15, 1947. At that time the cleaning of the septic tank had been completed. The top sand soil had been removed from the disposal bed and work had progressed to the extent of relaying 3 - 80' lengths of tile in the bed.

Work was continued in digging up the existing lines of 6" tile and examining the condition of the bed. It was found that the main heater 6" clay pipe line was in good condition. However, at places certain amounts of mud was found but not sufficient to block the flow. As regards the 6" tile lines, for a varying distance averaging 20 feet in length from the 6" distributor pipe, each tile was found to be more or less filled with soft slimy mud from the septic tank and for the balance of the line this matter was practically solid and fairly dry, completely blocking the remaining 60 feet of the 6" tile lines.

Near the centre of the disposal bed, a few 6" tiles were found broken. They may have been in this condition for some time, showing the infiltration of sand thus blocking four of the tile lines for varying lengths. About 500 - 6" tile were found crushed or broken in different parts of the bed. These were probably destroyed in removing the top sand soil as they appeared to have been filled with the solid mud previously thrown on the lines of tile. Tile lines were removed and about 50 of slinders placed in the bottom of the trenches. All tiles were cleaned, replaced in trenches with ramper over all joints, slinders placed around and above tiles to a thickness of about 8" and some sand thrown on top. Top sand soil was then pushed to the edge of the disposal bed by bulldozer and afterwards, by means of teams and scraper, was distributed over the bed. The disposal bed was then levelled to an elevation of 64.0 (project datum) or the equivalent of 20 feet of sand or seven feet of tiles. The wooden manhole of septic tank had rotted in places and were repaired, one over the siphon chamber being completely rebuilt, and all were left in good condition.

A limited amount of work was done on the laundry waste. The manhole near the S.W. corner of disposal bed was repaired to stop the infiltration of sand.

Work was temporarily shut down on August 29, having completed the rehabilitation of the sewage disposal bed and the repair of all manholes of the septic tank.

(Sgd) W. H. Wallace
