Memorandum:

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario - Sewage Disposal Plant Rehabilitation, August, 1967.

Solids in the septic tank main settling chamber were found to be almost a solid mass with over 4-foot depth of sludge floating and a semi-liquid below this running to solids at the bottom. The secondary settling chamber had only a frothy scum on top and a semi-liquid below; a black mass at the bottom and these merged so that no definite depths were determinable. In the siphon chamber there was a black, frothy material on top of the liquid. The chamber never discharged below the bell edge of the siphon so that none of this frothy material would stay indefinitely but the pumping job was done removed most of it at the time of cleaning operations. The siphon chamber flushed less than twice daily with the small holiday population in the school and flushing is much more frequent during the regular school term, mainly due to the flow of the battery toilets.

The disposal field had the outer half of the grid plugged solid with sludge which was practically dry and the inner sections of the field and the distributor line were full of a slimy black, semi-liquid which would not sink even in the coarsest gravel although the gravel surrounding the tile was blackened. This gravel layer, as soon as the bottom, absorbed fully a gallon of water per minute per foot of length when the siphon flushed once after the tank had been cleaned and the outflow was clarified. Therefore, with annual cleaning out of tank solids accumulation, the disposal field system may be expected to function properly again for ten years or more, especially if the excessive flow caused by the use of the automatic flush is cut down by the installation of individual toilets with single flush tanks, manually operated. The distributor riser at the outer end of the distributor line was filled with stones and topped over so that it was not operative. The outer two feet length of the distributor was filled almost solid. In effect the disposal field was in such a state as to be totally inoperative and for some time the siphon chamber effluent had been discharged from a hole breached in the centre of the distributor line and runoff had gone off into the field on the hillside furthest away from the buildings.

It was found that the sludge in the secondary settling tank could be pumped out with little difficulty by the sludge pump used. Finally, some stirring and raking to the suction pipe was done but as it was advisable to leave some sludge for seed under normal periods between cleaning operations, normally little raking is needed. Sewage flow from the building was temporarily turned into this tank to avoid raw sewage flow into the main tank, which was not needed. After an hour or so the semi-fluid sludge had moved and it was necessary to start sieving up the sludge. Then it had to be broken up further with a steel hoe from the furnace room and by adding water from a 3 inch hose it was possible to pump the mixture of black liquid and lumpy brown material. A special non-clogging gasoline motored sludge pump was operated on a stand to pump into a chute to be delivered into special-baffled sludge tanks carried by dump trucks. Owing to
the high lift and suction less due to the least air leak at joints or partly open valves affected by sticks, fruit, tennis balls and heavy sleighs, the pump would frequently stop and require clearing. One diaphragm was torn away from fastening down bolts. Due to these delays and the heavy long-time accumulation of sludge with consequent excessive water dilution needed, the pumping took twenty hours. To finish the removal of thick sludge from the primary settling tank it was necessary to employ two men to go down into this tank the last day. These men raked the last of the solids toward the pump suction-line and located at the lower level under the main manhole. Some debris like pieces of glass, pottery and waterlogged sticks, which were liable to plug the pump, were shovelled into a pail and lifted out. The tanks, including the siphon chamber, were all pumped out as empty as there are no special sumps. Complete removal of material is not advisable, in any event, as it was advisable to leave some old material to act as seed for continued bacterial action in the settling tanks.

The tops of the manholes had rotted to some extent and the original manhole built in 1928 over the siphon chamber was so rotten as to allow sand to sift down so it had to be rebuilt. It was found the timber cover of the tank was in good order as it had been covered.

One long root, about 1" in diameter, had grown down into the main settling tank. It was presumed to be eartgiana from a hedge about 25 feet away. There did not seem to be any extensive root system developed, however. A few tiles in the disposal field had a fine rooting net developed in them presumably from alfalfa which got into the surface field to a limited extent. Not more than a dozen feet of tile seemed to be affected. A few defective tiles had collapsed and had sand in them but there was no sign of any general sifting in of sand. As a bulldozer was used to uncover the upper part of the bed, the number of collapsed tile is problematical as most of the breakage happened when this machine was used to pile up spoil along the edge. However, it may be said as long as the system has damp soil around the pipes, the joints which are originally covered with sand paper, will let in practically no sand or other fine material.

(Sgd.) J. T. Rose

J. T. Rose.
Memorandum:

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re: Current Rehabilitation and Proposed Future Maintenance at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario.

This season's work of cleaning out tank and rebuilding disposal field is a recurrent expense item which it is considered could be much reduced by reasonably frequent cleaning out of the septic tanks. It is proposed that the tanks be cleaned out at least once a year at a cost of about $100.00 and the frequency the disposal field is rebuilt should be much reduced as settlement area in the tanks would not be unduly restricted by sludge accumulation.

Due to the accumulation of several years' run, current pumping of the sludge involved much more difficult work than a single year's operation would involve. Four feet of floating material, possibly largely paper, had to be sliced and mashed into a pumpable mass with a considerable addition of water from a fire hose. In spite of several times the tank capacity was actually pumped, this dilution would be largely unnecessary for a single year's accumulation. This year because school teams were not available, trucks were employed and the work was much expedited as a tank or truck could be filled, loaded, dumped on any field a mile away and truck would be back for refill in seventeen minutes which would not be possible with teams. Other years, the school teams could be used at a time chosen when urgent work would be at a minimum and they could handle the pumping with more time allowed for cleaning the pump in between fillings. Owing to the obnoxious conditions of the work, the school authorities would be obliged to pay their staff and any extra help, current rates of labor in addition to their regular wages, while specially employed on this work. To work with teams, two special tank boxes would necessarily be supplied as the only sludge box with baffles available from the Town of Kenora is made for a dump truck. To have two of these boxes made would cost about $50.00 each and they could be utilized by the St. Mary's Indian School also, by arrangement with the Indian Agent at Kenora. The steel boxes can be opened with the whole back end to open quickly and on account of no caulking being necessary, their maintenance would be negligible and high first cost would be warranted.

Allowing for slow pumping with two teams and boxes used, the pumping would easily be completed in three days if carried on annually and charges would be as follows:

- Pump rental and transfer .................. $10.50
- Two drivers for tank wagons at $6.00 per day . 56.00
- Helper and tank cleaner at $1.00 per hr. . 24.00
- Pump-mac at $1.00 per hour ................. 24.00 $94.50

Much depend on the willingness of the pump man to regularly clear the pump of various articles that stick in the two drop gates and pump diaphragm. A fisherman's rubber trousers and jacket with sou-wester hat are necessary for use with hip boots by a tank cleaner.

RE: ENCLOSED ESTIMATE FROM P.A. SHOP.

Dear Mr. Patterson:

As you will remember from previous correspondence, the visiting Dietician and Inspectors Hamilton both recognized the need for a new floor in the scullery. Mr. Bert Wilson, of Hindstrom and Wilson was to give an estimate. His first reaction was about $250.00. However, when I asked him for a written estimate he said that he would prefer not to take on the job, and referred me to Mr. Shop.

Mr. Shop's estimate is for what should be a permanent finish. Because of the constant water and damp action, some finishes such as linoleum, or "Tromso" products will not stand up.

We should like to ask that Mr. Shop's estimate be now accepted.

Further, you will remember our discussion of the condition of occasional overflow at the toilets in the Dormitories. Since the floor is wood, this condition—even though only occasional—tends to create an odor. Besides the floor itself, the undercoat and the classroom ceilings below, suffer considerably.

We are requesting a small cement floor, with a floor drain, to catch any liquid other than overflow or spillage of the boys. (Such drains are installed in the dormitory toilets at the Mohawk Institute in Brantford.)

This second estimate from Mr. Shop, of $82.00 per toilet including all the plumbing necessary in connecting the floor drains to main sewer outlet seems quite reasonable. There are five such dormitory toilets.

We should like to request that these jobs be undertaken at the same time.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Paterson:

As mentioned to you over the phone this morning, the Disposal Bed has again given us trouble similar to the trouble of the past two years. Yesterday morning, I noticed a pool of open water in the bed. Upon further investigation I found that the water is erupting to the surface from one point, approximately the end of the tile line furthest from the Septic tank.

The similar trouble last year was found to be from the blocking of the tiles by sand and silt from the tank. It is hard to believe that the same thing has happened already, since the bed was ransomed during the summer of 1947. It is hard to believe that the line is frozen, since it has withstood the coldest parts of the winter.

May I again draw to the attention of the department the necessity of considering the installation of individual flush type toilets instead of the present "battery" type. As previously pointed out, the present type is obsolete, uncleanly and therefore unsanitary, wasteful of water, and imposes too much burden on the Septic tank and disposal bed.

You have already received a letter from us requesting that the department would consider sending a competent Engineer to look at the Pump and Chlorine system. Could they tie in with that, a complete check of the possibilities of changing the toilet system and also helping to clear up this matter of the new disposal bed overflow.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Sewage Disposal and Water Supply System,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School
near Kenora, Ont.

Referring to your notation on copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs dated April 6th, 1948, we are now in receipt of a report from Mr. J.T. Rose dated June 23rd, forwarded here by Mr. Gow. This report deals with the sewage disposal system as well as the flush toilets and pump and chlorine system. A copy of this report is attached herewith.

Mr. Rose found that the effluent from the septic tank was not running over the ground surface, but a break in a tile line apparently was allowing the effluent to form a small pond at one spot. This was probably partly due to the fact that the siphons were found to be out of action.

The siphons and the general operation of the septic tank should be frequently inspected. While the school is open, an inspection every day, and certainly not less than once per week would not be too often if trouble is to be prevented.

The partly unsatisfactory past operation of the sewage disposal system is, no doubt, largely due to the enormous load of discharge from the automatic battery type of toilets, which puts a strain on the disposal system. New manually operated independent closets should be installed.

The Wilson Chemical Hypo-Chlorinator appears to be unsatisfactory as repair parts and service are not available. The Wallace & Tiernan Hypo-Chlorinator should give more satisfaction.

The following is the estimate of cost for the suggested changes:

- Sewage disposal bed tile replacement, covering and reseeding: $1,000.00
- Gang Closets replacement: $1,750.00
- Pumping Plant repairs: $400.00
- Chlorination plant replacement: $400.00
- Contingencies: $200.00

Total: $2,000.00

It is also recommended that $200.00 be supplied for repair work and testing units.

At the sewage disposal plant at the school visited June 18 there was a pool in a slight depression in the disposal field, about 100 square feet in area and it averaged one inch deep. No overflow ran off the bed downhill. It is thought that during wet spring conditions the bed may have been saturated and under drainage become reduced, so that the flush of water started spread out of a loosely closed end of tile line, or a joint tipped by horse-drawn apparatus used to backfill the bed. Since the break-out this outlet has been in contact with free air on the siphon discharge. Thus the flow from same is taken up by transpiration and evaporation, as there is no flow off the bed. The siphons were found to be stopped. The double bell and equalizer pipe unit was removed, raised above ground and tested, and after it was replaced the siphons operated. Siphon chamber liquids were sampled by use of a bailer past in the presence of the School Principal and his mechanical operator, and the liquid was seen to contain a red-brown scum which resembled almost the same when the plant was retested in operation last fall. The septic tank sludge accumulation was checked at the clean-out man-hole near the tank inlet. Eighteen inches of top sludge, two and a half feet of this liquid and one foot bottom sludge seemed to be in place. Continual flooding due to cessation of siphon action probably allowed the bed to become sour, and a slimy mass may have formed which would reduce absorption. This should be corrected by aerobic bacterial action when breathing spells occur and air can get into
the lime from the breather pipe. Besides screen cleaning school attendants should be sure the siphons operate regularly, and they should periodically wash out "Elsco" flush bent of siphon chamber effluents. Annual removal of most of the septic tank solids should be required as regular practice. Special steel dump boxes for fresh haulage are required for this operation, which has previously been outlined.

As it is not feasible to shut down the disposal unit, a check of the actual cause of overflow from the tile line or lines, and resetting any displaced pipes or pipes, refilling any openings with new soil is advised to be done later on. This would provide a better seed bed for a good grass growth. The operation would cost about $100.00, if done in July or August.

2. Gang Closets.

On the boys' side these are operated as a "U" shaped trough with five seats separated by walls with h-joint filled, framed partitions. A slight overflow prevents the tank periodically flushing. The trough is about four inches above the marble-covered floor and discharge is through a vented 6" S-trap, also above the floor. The flush of water does not adequately clean the trough and unsatisfactory sanitary conditions result, requiring frequent scrubbing down further, leaving open possibilities for insect spread of disease like typhoid, dysentery and polio. The use of water is excessive and should be avoided as far as possible by the use of manually flushed closets. Also, the possibility of leakage of the disposal field and septic tank. Might lead sticks, rulers and books would get into the sewer from the closets of the separate type. A special refuse container of the lid type should be provided in the room, which is divided by a partition from the gang wash basins. Overhead a fuse canopy covering the closets is wanted to the same system as the ventilation system in the class rooms. The class room ventilation openings were closed because of the noise resulting from blow-back of odors, so that it appears advisable to rent the canopies in each of the boys' and girls' washrooms directly through fans on the wall opposite the closets. Then the class-room ventilators can be used again. There are two urinals of the vertical type installed on the wall at right angles to the gang closets nearest their discharge end. These operate most satisfactorily and permit space used by an old urinal to be used for a sixth closet, if this were considered necessary. The Principal of the school considered the boys needed four closets, only, as the pair of stall urinals are available.

A replacement installation, running to least expense, would be to install the new individual flush-tank type closets on a concrete platform which would contain the horizontal soil pipe connection to the present vented S-trap. Present vents would suffice. The partitions need not be moved. As there are 9 washbasins and baths in the same room it is considered the ventilator canopy overhead should stay and be vented across the room directly outside.

In the girls' washroom there are six closets, where replacement with individual flush-tank units would involve work similar to that for the boys' side, but the six closets instead of four would mean a cost proportionately higher. In each case the partitions would remain. The cost of the new installation in the boys' section would be $450.00 and in the girls' $350.00, a total of $800.00, including concrete base. No expenditures for ventilation units are included.
In the girls' toilet the double gong, which basin unit was in noticeable disrepair and the drain often blocks up. Slip joints under basins were in some places disconnected and basin brackets broken off on most units. The connectors to the main drain are opposed instead of being into double "T"s. The main drain under the floor is too little slope and the traps at the end, instead of being a proper "U" trap, is made up of a lot of fittings, including a slanting bend located at the upper end of the basin drain. All this prevents easy drainage and could readily be corrected. The mastick-covered floors are subject to continual deterioration by scaly water, so it was recommended a waterproof plastic be applied to resist soap action. Due to amount of work barring brackets, besides plumbing, cost on basins would be $158.00.

3 - General Building Maintenance Issues.

Partly detached eave trough sections along the roof edges hang dangerously above both boys' and girls' dormitories. The whole system of troughing and down pipes should be salvaged, if it is not to be repaired. Water has been getting under the roof metal, particularly at the valleys where the wings are joined to the main building and inside places where falling off underneath. No defect is in any way obvious or evident, but caulking with roofing cement should be tried. A limited amount of insulation should be placed over dorm frames, with a clear varnish spray over upper storey tapestry brick will improve heat retention and exclude excessive moisture that tends to beat in when winds accompany heavy rainfall. The damaged part of the roof over the furnace room and adjoining areas can also be replaced, now that more metal is available. Partly on account of war shortages faulty taps have not been replaced and many leak badly. Probably much waste of water could be saved by removals, or at least by resetting the taps.

4 - Pumping and Chlorination System.

The two 5,000 gallon Typhoon Pumps obtained of Fairbanks-Morse and installed in 1926 have had considerable repair work done and both its vertical studs connecting the water box bracket and base together pull out due to rust and chlorin accumulation. Double Arc lead and electric welding has been done to reinforce them, but without lasting success. Fairbanks-Morse provided these do not handle the 5,000 gallon size pump or spare parts now and 2,500 gallon size is the next largest stocked, so further repairs should be tried.

Repairs may be done at a cost of $100.00 to $150.00 for each pump to open out and re-tap with larger size end nuts up six special studs to hold down the water box bracket, with extra size nuts threaded. The base may be hardened by the elastic welding done and "doxy" due to chlorine action, so that it is only advisable to try out repairs on one pump at a time.

The whole pump room and machinery several years ago was damaged by chlorine gas and the pump and valves are continually subject to corrosion by chlorine solution, which do doubt has damaged the valves. The unplated pipes are badly corroded. Wrenches have apparently been used on the valves, as their seating is poor, and the seat and stems are damaged. Replacement is recommended of two 3/4", two 3" valves and two 3/4" checks and a 3" pipe in suction lines as pump prime is generally lost. Besides this a 4' foot length of 4" pipe and 6' feet of 6" suction line are badly corroded on the outside. Red lead paint on the piping has kept the exterior in good appearance, so all the piping should be repainted with red lead paint regularly.
One of the pump meters had recently been burnt out, probably due to simple plugging as no fuses were blown in the protective switch connections, and the power supplying company could not explain the cause of the trouble. The meter has been rewound. The company went to the expense of putting in two new line wires and overhauled the line generally to prevent short circuits. For the above mentioned conditions it is considered advisable a check by one of our local offices electrical engineers might show the source of this type of trouble. Recommendation of remedial or control measures would be appreciated.

The cost of this pump house work on two pumps, piping and fittings would amount to about $200.00.

5 - Chlorination System

The chlorination of the water supply by the Wilson Chemical Hypo-Chlorinator at the pump house is irregular; as the sight feeder builds up a chemical deposit which gradually reduces flow and makes the flow difficult to judge. Besides that, this Wilson type runs continuously with excessive waste of chlorine solution. There is no local representative or channel through which new parts or service are available, so that this machine and others in the area around Lenore have been lately replaced with more satisfactory by Wallace & Tieman Type-Chlorinators, for which there is a regular supply of parts and equipment. In addition, this equipment is automatically shut off and run during pumping only. This Hypo-Chlorinator, Type BHF, has proved satisfactory in many R.C.A.F. water supply plants. It is of a type recently put in to replace the Wilson unit at Norman river, and service for it can be readily arranged, which is an important consideration where operators change often and need supervision for dependable operation and standard tests by orthotolidin type tester.

As the elimination of this Wilson chlorinator was recommended in a letter of April 8, 1948 from this office, and no suitable replacement units have been obtainable from "our Assets", it is advised the Type BHF sold by Wallace & Tieman at $675.00 be purchased. The installation could use the present auxiliary piping, namely, but retapping and connections would cost about $15.00. The provision of an electrically driven water and convenience outlet combination with installation would cost not more than $200.00. The total replacement would therefore be about $900.00. An OTO Junior Type Test Unit costing $18.50 is also required for checking the quantity of the chlorine in the water at the school.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, September 21, 1948.

Re: Sewage Disposal and Water Supply System,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School,
Renore, Ontario.

In connection with Mr. Rees's memorandum of September 8th, which bears your marginal notation of the 9th instant, together with a copy of Principal T.C. Ross's letter of September 1st, with reference to the above, you are advised as follows:

On September 7th, our Mr. Hargreaves called at the above school on his way back from a trip through the West to inspect the water pumps; and the following report is submitted for your information and for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

In condensed summary, the water supply system may be described as follows:

There are two Fairbanks Morse Typhoon double acting belt driven water pumps, each having capacity to deliver 5000 Imperial gallons of water per hour against 100 lbs per square inch. Each pump is driven by a 7½ horsepower, 220 volt, 3 phase, 60 cycle, A.C. Motor. The pumps are set up on concrete bases which extend approximately 1½ inches above the pump house floor and approximately 5 feet below the pump house floor. A 1 inch suction line extends approximately 1½ feet from the pump house to the intake and about 150 feet from the intake line to the intake. The suction line extending from the pump pit, is fitted with a foot valve and upon rising through the floor, branches to each pump through a double sweep elbow.

No fault is to be found with the piping arrangement, except that from time to time it has been found necessary to renew certain sections owing to rust and deterioration. Much trouble has been experienced in keeping these units primed, but following Mr. Ross's last efforts, this condition has been overcome and at the time this inspection was carried out, the units were working as satisfactorily as could be expected.

The pumps were installed in 1928, and are therefore 20 years old. They are not of modern design and are not capable of equalling the performance of a similar unit. While they are anchored to substantial concrete bases, considerable vibration was noted, due largely to the fact that shimming was needed. As a result of these vibrations and gradual wear and tear, the vertical studs which connect the water box bottom to the base, have pulled out from time to time. Various attempts have been made to replace these studs, but it has not been found possible to keep them tight, and unless these studs can be made to hold, undesirable results will follow. As this type of pump is no longer manufactured, vitally necessary replacement parts are impossible to obtain, and it follows that a satisfactory repair job cannot be made.

After having given careful consideration to the requirements, it is felt that one new pump of modern design should be installed as soon as possible. This unit should be of a size calculated to handle the entire load and should be of a type specifically designed for this service.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Director
Indian Affairs branch

For your consideration
23/9/48 Director...
One of the existing pumps should be left in place to provide for stand-by service. At a later date, it would be good policy to replace this stand-by unit with one similar to the suggested new pump.

It is therefore, recommended that the following operations be carried out:

Provide and install one shallow well type pump, equal to Duro series, 2000 Oilt-Rite for total suction lift of 25 feet or pump No. 2088 having a capacity to deliver 2500 Imperial gallons of water per hour against 160 lbs per square inch working pressure.

This pump shall be connected through V belt drive to one 7½ horsepower 220 volt, 3 phase, 60 cycle A.C. Motor and supplied with all necessary starting switches and overload protection. The V belt shall have not less than 4 belts.

One of the existing pumps shall be removed from its base, and new holes shall be drilled into the base to permit installation of new anchor bolts which shall be located to suit the new pump base. Anchor bolts should be extended at least a distance of 4 feet into the basement and be thoroughly coated with a rich concrete mix. Extreme care will be taken to provide an absolutely firm foundation, using steel shims etc., where necessary.

The above pump including the motor, will cost approximately $550.00 and the installation charges which will include the dismantling and removal of the old pump along with minor changes to the piping, will cost approximately $350.00. It is felt that with contingencies, this work can be carried out for approximately $1,000.00.

At the time this work is done, the existing pressure switch on the pressure tank should be adjusted to cut in and cut out within the range of 20 to 60 lbs.

It is felt that nothing can be done to improve the sewage disposal system, short of removing the gang toilets and installing manual operating individual units.

The existing gang closets require continual flushing and huge quantities of water are used in order to obtain some degree of cleanliness. Under these circumstances, it can be taken for granted, that complete bacterial action does not take place in the first chamber of the septic tank; this is due to the excessive quantity of waste being continually admitted. The tank overflows to the siphon chamber and some of the solids are bound to pass over. This condition could result in the clogging of the siphon pipe, thereby stopping its action. In addition, the field tile bed being under continual discharge, does not have time to become aerated and thus the bed is at all times sodden and sour. Since the existing septic tank is judged to be somewhat on the small side, it should be cleaned at least twice a year.

Our memorandum of July 4th, outlines the procedure to relieve the difficulty and it also includes for the replacement of the chlorinator plant. The chlorinator plant has been requisitioned, and it is expected that its installation will be completed in the near future.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

I am greatly impressed by the wisdom shown by the Department of Indian Affairs in stressing competitive sports as a means of improving Indian morale. The directive recently received dealing with the subject of "Indian Athletics" is most illuminating. I sincerely appreciate having such valuable ideas brought clearly to my attention.

In seeking to make use of the suggestions made, by planning an active sports program for the pupils in this school, I find myself seriously handicapped by lack of equipment. With no facilities for indoor sport in this school, it is necessary for us to rely still upon outdoor sports. As we will be away from the closed reservations, we have only a very limited quantity of hockey equipment, skates for only a percentage of our pupils, and almost no equipment for skiing and tobogganing.

I fully realize that this requisition is being submitted at a very late date. Much of it should have been requested before my arrival at this school. I should have appreciated the need, and understood the paramount importance of sports for our Indian boys and girls, much earlier in this term. That I have failed to do so I sincerely regret.

Ottawa, December 27, 1948.

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of December 17th bearing your notation of the 20th instant, together with a copy of Principal T.C. Ross' letter to Indian Superintendent Paterson under date of December 6th, you are advised as follows:

No inspection of the heating system has been carried out by this Division and the only information we have in this connection has been supplied by the Donald Inspection Company who have recently submitted a report.

This report merely describes the heating system in general, in one short paragraph with no detailed information whatsoever. It is impossible to comment without full technical details and the data should be obtained during the heating season by an officer conversant with this phase of the work.

No previous complaints with regard to the heating system are noted on our files. We are not surprised however, to learn that trouble is developing after years of operation. It has been observed that normal yearly maintenance is seldom given the attention it merits in these schools and due to this omission and normal depreciation, it is not surprising to note that Mr. Ross has found it necessary to carry out some work immediately.

If the Indian Affairs Branch concur with our suggestion that an inspection of the heating system should be carried out, we will endeavour to assign one of our officers to the work when arrangements can be made. Until such a time as an inspection can be carried out, it will not be possible to provide any kind of an estimate of the cost of executing the necessary work.

In the meantime, while certain parts of the building may be uncomfortable as Mr. Ross has suggested, we see no prospect of grave consequences if this inspection should be delayed for several weeks or longer.

Ottawa, February 15, 1949.

24021

Res: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of January 25th, together with copy of Principal Ross' letter of the 19th instant and the Donald Inspection Company's letter of February 5th, all in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

It was expected that this Division would be able to make recommendations designed to improve the heating system at the above upon receipt of the Donald Inspection Company's report. However, the short paragraph in their report which refers to the heating system contains no data on what it does or the requirements. There is a mild suggestion that a vacuum pump be installed to improve matters. This suggestion is enlarged upon to some extent in their letter of February 5th, but there is no evidence of any analysis or examination of the heating system having been made to determine if the installation of a vacuum pump would accomplish the desired results.

Reference is made at this point, to a letter from the Donald Inspection Company dated May 12th, 1948, under heading "Re: Inspection and Maintenance Report for Indian Schools". Item E in this letter calls for a "full report covering electrical, water, plumbing and heating systems". The report received in connection with the above school, makes only casual reference to the services mentioned in item E, and most certainly can not be considered as a report on which technical advice can be offered.

For your information and in response to the Donald Inspection Company's suggestion covering the installation of a vacuum pump, we point out that since the present heating system has been in operation since the building was erected, there is every possibility that numerous leaks have developed in the return piping and under such circumstances, a vacuum pump would not perform satisfactorily until such lines were repaired or replaced. It will take far more than a casual inspection to determine how much piping is in need of renewal or repair, along with a complete check-up of all the auxiliary elements which go to make up the heating system. Such an inspection must be carried out by someone qualified in that line of work if the results are to be of any value.

The Indian Affairs Branch have concurred with our suggestion that an inspection should be carried out by one of our officers, as soon as his services can be spared. It is our intention to have this survey conducted before the present heating season ends, in order that the equipment may be tested and examined under working conditions.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

It should be borne in mind that the large and ever increasing volume of work which this Division is being called upon to handle, has made it impossible to assign an officer to visit Kenora up to this time. It is thought probable that our heating engineer may be assigned to this duty within the next two to three weeks.

Further to our meeting February 26th with reference to the heating system at the above school, an engineer carried out a survey of the heating system at the above school on March 18th.

The school was fitted to the same plan as the school at [redacted]. It was erected opposite the school building and heated by a steam boiler. The boiler was removed and replaced by a Vulcan Iron Works steam heating boiler having a capacity calculated to carry the entire load. The remaining Spencer boiler is now used only for hot water.

A new Vulcan boiler was installed with a control that can be controlled by an automatic pressure switch arranged to operate the fan to maintain a steady steam pressure in the boiler. This automatic switch has never been used or cared for, and is now plugged with dirt and rust and is inoperative. A manual control auxiliary switch is connected in such a manner that the fan may be run as desired, but it is evident that it has not been used recently.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re INSTALLATION OF PUMP

Lakeside Plumbing & Heating Co. have proceeded with the work of installing the pump, and it has proved to be considerably more than a half day job. It has been necessary to rearrange the piping somewhat in order to permit the new pump to rest upon the same base as the old—the new pump being quite different in design to the old.

Also, some of the old piping began to leak as soon as the plumbers started to dismantle it. This of course involved some additional work and expense.

Because your Department insists that the expense of this installation be kept to a minimum, I have not felt free to authorize any work being done to increase the size of the cement base upon which the new pump rests. But I feel sure that a competent engineer would agree with me that the installation of this pump can not be considered complete and correct until the size of the base has been increased to at least the same dimensions as the bottom of the metal frame which supports both pump and motor. As installed the metal frame supporting the motor and pump protrudes inches in each direction beyond the edges of the cement base. My knowledge of mechanics is fairly elementary, but it suggests that this is not a sufficiently sound support for a pump and motor of this type which must be considered permanent. I should be pleased to be given an early and authoritative opinion upon this.

It is very gratifying to feel that there is now one pump which may be depended upon to keep us supplied with water. I wish to express to your Department my sincere gratitude to them for having provided this school with this valuable piece of equipment.

Sgd. T. Ross.

Dear Miss Matthews:

We have your letter of the last instant with reference to payment towards the salary of the night watchman at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The usual period for which we allow a grant for the above purpose, is from 1st October to the subsequent April 30th. This covers the school season in practically all the schools. According to our records, we find that the cheque for $200.00 (paragraph 5 of your letter) was issued for the five months stated in your letter, namely September, October, November and December, 1947, and January, 1948, at $40.00 a month. As a matter of fact, we should only have issued a cheque for $160.00, as we do not pay for the month of September.

In April, 1948, you were forwarded a cheque for $120.00, being the amount due for January, February and March, 1948.

In July, 1948, we forwarded you a cheque for $40.00 for the month of April, 1948.

In December, 1948, we forwarded you a cheque for $120.00 for the amount due for October, November and December, 1948. This was a mistake, as we should have allowed you $60.00 a month for these three months.
In March you were forwarded a cheque for £240.00 being payment at $60.00 a month for the months of January, February and March, 1949, and $60.00 being the balance due for the months of October, November and December, 1948.

According to our records you have, therefore, been paid in full for the allowance towards the salary of the night watchman, namely $60.00 a month from October to the subsequent April 30th.

There will be another payment of $60.00 due you for the month of April. I trust the above has been of assistance to you.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Bupt. of Indian Education

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re HEATING SYSTEM

It was indeed satisfying to receive your letter and the extracts from Mr. Hargreaves' report. It is only such an efficient technical man who can really supply us with the correct answers to our problems. It was pleasing to note Mr. Hargreaves' fairness in commenting both on the limitations of our engineer-stoker and the need for repair to our heating system. The definite assurance that the Department is making plans for extensive repairs to the heating system during the coming summer removes a great deal of anxiety from my mind.

I am glad to have Mr. Hargreaves' opinion as confirmation to my own view that a younger and able man is needed for the caretaking job here. I had already decided that it would be advisable to make a change before next winter.

However, you will realize that it is not easy to obtain the most efficient of workmen at the salary we are able to pay. I do not anticipate being able to replace the present man overnight, but I shall certainly try to do so, and shall inform you as soon as I am able.

I am indeed grateful to Mr. Hargreaves for bringing the matter of the high pressure boiler to my attention. His instructions have of course been carried out. I might add that I myself was amazed to find when I arrived at this school that it has been customary for many years to have this boiler operated by the laundry matron. She has done so successfully for many years now, and, with the heating system in such poor shape, it has required no more of her engineering-stoker's time during the winter months to try to keep the building comfortable than she has been able on her own much of the time.

Since this matter has been brought so clearly to my attention, I have wondered if it might be advisable to obtain a little clearer direction on the subject. If it is necessary to have this boiler operated by an individual having first class steam engineering certificate, why should not provision be made by the Department for paying the salary which should reasonably be expected by an individual possessing those qualifications?

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re DORMITORY FLOORS

As you will remember, we have previously discussed the necessity for having these floors repaired and renewed in the near future. It was one of the subjects mentioned to the Regional Supervisor on the occasions of his visits to this school.

The recent visit of the Grand Jury, and their report on this school, has served as a further reminder to the necessity for having this work done soon. Their report, published by the press, was most unfavorable to this school as a whole, but referred to the condition of the dormitory floors as being "unsanitary". This is of course no exaggeration. The floors have worn through the top layer of varnish in several places. It is quite impossible to keep the floors clean in their present state. The rough surfaces produce numerous slivers for the many little feet which move daily over their surfaces. In fact it is imperative that these floors be renewed before the beginning of another term.

I have discussed this matter with more than one authority on flooring, and have been advised that the present floor surface has reached a state of wear so great that the only solution is to remove the pre-cut top layer of flooring completely, replace it with a complete new layer of flooring, and cover this with battle-hip linoleum. I wish to be given authority to have this work done during the summer holidays.

While making this request I am carefully considering the probable expense involved, and am avoiding asking to have any work done that is not badly needed. There is much more of the flooring that should be replaced, but I...
am prepared to wait for a year to do that, believing that most of the remaining flooring will stand a further year's use without being worn to such an extent that the cost of replacement or scrubbing will be unduly increased by the effect. However, the four large dormitory floors must be replaced during this summer. It is utterly impossible to consider trying to keep children clean and healthy with the floors of their living quarters in such condition.

If your Department will approve the purchase of the material for this work I believe that I can arrange to have much of the work involved done by members of my staff during the summer months. If I receive a prompt answer authorizing me to proceed with this, I shall try to arrange to keep the Manual Instructor throughout the summer. He does excellent work, and would be quite capable of doing this work.

In making this request, I am not asking for authority for a definite amount to be expended. I am asking for the material and I do not know what price flooring and linoleum, felt (or paper), glue, etc can be obtained by your Department for. If there are any further relevant details needed I shall be glad to furnish them. Your Department will be well aware of the dimensions of the dormitories referred to.

A prompt reply will be appreciated, and will greatly facilitate the carrying out of this important item of repair to this building.

Sincerely yours,

Principal.

It has been our experience based on the result of numerous inspections of Indian Residential Schools by our heating engineer, to note that in order to bring the heating and plumbing systems up to present day standards, much more work would be required than we have been in the habit of recommending, to carry out all the work necessary to achieve modern and up to date systems in every respect, would involve sums of money, which would be hard to justify. Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re DORMITORY FLOORS

In reply to your letter dated Aug 4th I

Is it possible that there has been some misunderstanding over the material supplied for these dormitory floors. The wire received from Col. Henry suggests that he believes that we have been supplied with flooring. If this had been so I could have gone ahead with laying the floors, and could have waited until a later date for the linoleum. However, as the material that we have acquired in what had been agreed was the most economical - simply sheathing - it is utterly useless to consider laying this without linoleum to cover it. You will likely be aware of the fact that this grade of plywood is not held together with waterproof glue. Thus, even a few weeks of wear will ruin the surface unless it is protected.

I do hope that your Department will give me assurance quickly that the remainder of the material asked for will be made available. I dare not face the possibility of going through another winter with such shockingly awful floors in the dormitories. They are splintered so badly that children can't help picking up slivers from them, and they are so badly worn that it is not possible for anyone to scrape them smooth, having water leak through the ceiling. Furthermore, I am ashamed to allow visitors to see the condition under which our Indian children are obliged to exist in their sleeping quarters.

If I am to complete this job before school opens, I must have prompt assurance that the materials asked for will be made available quickly. I am doing everything in my power to see that this job is done because it needs doing badly. It is getting no closer to the beginning of the year than in order to have this job finished, I personally shall be obliged to assist with the work. Please urge your Department to avoid any further delay.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Paterson:

NO DRAINAGE DITCH

I discovered, at very short notice, that the municipal authorities had gone ahead with plans for the construction of a drainage ditch, part of which will cross this school's property. It is evident that someone had omitted to ensure that permission had been obtained from your Department. I am not sure that the fault was altogether that of local officials, but I am inclined partly to blame. At any rate, although I have perfectly good reason for believing that the project had been discussed before my time, there is nothing on file here to prove that there was correspondence concerning the project.

If there had been any reasonable shadow of doubt in my mind that your Department would object to the construction of the above portion of this ditch on the school property, I should have refused to allow the work to proceed. However, as the construction of this ditch is obviously an improvement to the school property, and as it is part of an improvement program being carried out by the Department of Agriculture, I felt quite justified in allowing this work to be done. I was given less than twenty-four hours' notice by the municipality, and so was unable to obtain proper authority from your Department. This is regrettable but was unavoidable at the time.

The construction of this ditch has involved a small expenditure on our part, and I shall give you full details concerning this. The ditch must cross a road on our property. This road is in constant use. Oats are daily proceeding from our barn to pasture, and the farm manager is obliged to pass it frequently when taking farm machinery etc. From the school to the fields beyond. Because it is in constant use, a bridge or crossing has to be constructed as soon as the ditch is completed at this point. The most economical way of doing this is to install a suitable size of culvert, and construct a proper "fill" at the point where
the road and ditch intersect. This is in process of being done. The Department of Highways agreed to lend the necessary culvert at short notice, and I have agreed to replace it. I have taken members of my staff from other work in order to provide the necessary labour.

I sincerely regret the circumstances which have necessitated my incurring an expenditure such as this, without first obtaining authority from your Department. I telephoned you before making any of these arrangements, hoping that, under the circumstances, you would feel justified in concurring with my action and would feel justified in authorising what is a necessary expenditure and not a lavish one. The fact that you did not feel free to do so of course left me to make this decision alone. I have incurred this expenditure, believing that it was the only course at the time. I have done so believing that it was in the best interests of this school and your Department that I do so. I am fully aware of the fact that this expenditure may not be authorized, and that I may be obliged to meet it from my own resources. But I am confident that I have taken the only wise course.

As soon as I can obtain an exact price for the culvert used, I shall inform you. I believe that the cost is about $64.00. I request authority for this expenditure.

Sincerely yours,

Re: Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Your File 129/30-4-461

We have your letter of the last instant enclosing a letter from the Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey School with regard to the widening of the drainage ditch by the Municipality of Jeffrey.

Mr. Ross had no right to allow this work to proceed without informing the Department through your office, and obtaining our consent. However, there is nothing much we can do about the matter now, as the work has apparently already been completed. We trust, however, that Mr. Ross will not make a similar mistake in future.

Mr. Ross' letter mentions an amount of $64.00 for the new culvert. Your letter states $91.04. We cannot understand why we have received two different amounts, and consequently, we approve the amount mentioned by the Principal, namely $64.00.
